"NI1","Played Coronet, French horn, and percussion for Philadelphia or Chicago Symphony.  He also played for John Phillip Sousa's Band."
"N0","Still Living."
"NI3","Born at 7pm on 17-Apr-1858.<br>Christened by Reverend. Mr. Mitchell, Rector."
"NI8","High Sheriff in Fermanagh in 1690, and represented the County in the<br>Parliaments of 1695 and 1703."
"NI13","Born at 5am on 1-Aug-1860.<br>Christened by Reverend. Mr. Mitchell, Rector.<br>Margaret Bray was a sponsor at his christening."
"NI15","M.P. for Augher and Tyrone"
"NI23","Bishop of Killmore"
"NI24","Born at 7:30pm on 10-Jan-1863.<br>Drowned in the St. Lawrence River near Brockville<br>Frederick Bray was a sponsor at his christening."
"NI35","Born at 8:30 on 11-Feb-1867.<br>Christened by Reverend Mr. Lauder, Rector."
"NI42","Esq. of Abbeville House, Co. Tyrone."
"NI44","Died unmarried."
"NI46","Born at 11pm on 12-Jul-1870.<br>Christened by Reverend Mr. Lauder, Rector."
"NI53","Eldest daughter of James, 3rd Earl of Morton."
"NI57","-- Military Service --<br>A volunteer, he was commisioned 2nd Lieutenant in the Royal Welsh Fusiliers on 22nd Dec 1761.  He is recorded as having recieved an award of five quineas from the Justices of the Peace for his assistance in preserving the Ship 'Dolphin', which was stranded in the Port of Penzance, Cornwall, in 1765.<br>Promoted to Lieutenant of the newly formed Light Company on the 26th of December 1770, he sailed for service with the Regiment in North America in 1773.  He was present at the officers St. David's Day Dinner at Boston in 1775, and was later wounded at the Battle of Bunker Hill on 17th June 1775.<br>Promoted to Captain-Lieutenant on 22nd November 1777.<br>Promoted to Captain on 30th May 1778.<br>Exchanged to be Captain of an Independant Company of Invalids in North Britain on 12 May 1779.<br>--<br>Introduction to the Wills of Thomas Cochrane<br>The will of Capt Thomas Cochrane and its codicils<br>Copies of the following are included:<br>1. A will dated 17 July 1809 made prior to his marriage.<br>2. An undated and unsigned document written after his marriage which adds to his will some property located in Ireland.<br>3. A will dated 7 October 1813.  The document is badly creased and one line at the middle is largely obliterated. At some later date it was glued to burlap.<br>4. A codicil dated 18 May 1814.<br>5. Another codicil dated 15 May 1818, seven days before he died and which would explain his mark rather than his signature. This document is on vellum.<br>On another copy of the fifth document listed above JCT Cochrane has written in the margin, I was born on May 8/18<br>The description of the property seems to vary between documents and I am not sure of the correct spelling of some of the place names. The same property is listed in Volume 1 of JCT Cochrane's Private Land Register and Mortages under the heading Irish Property in the County of Fermanagh Ireland  Willed to me by my Father. In the same book is a copy of a letter written by JCT Cochrane which indicates that his mother authorized his stepbrother Lt. Col Cochrane of Fort William (Scotland) to sell the property and which he contends she did not have the power to do.<br>The letter was written 19th April 1844 but it was not sent; attached to it is a note:<br>Wrote to my brother Col Cochrane offering to give up the will _____ see letter above. This note has the same date as the letter.<br>The spelling of Mrs Cochrane's maiden name in these documents is always a very clear BROWNBILL instead of BROWNHILL as I had always supposed it to be. Katharine Cochrane uses the same spelling (BILL) in the chart which she drew.<br>These five documents were tied together along with a note by JCT Cochrane which reads as follows:<br>My fathers will dated Oct7/13 bequeathed to my mother and any child or children of the said S.S. Cochrane the Irish property therein described. I have no record of the actual date of my parents marriage but the marriage certificate was sent to *. A subsequent All of my father just before his death is dated May 15/18 giving my mother his furniture, property, cash, etc. and in his last will (a few days after my birth) I am referred to as John Thomas.''<br>Charles was added to the above at a later date at the request of his mother so that he was then known as JCT Cochrane.<br>* At this point there is a blank line. The certificate accompanied a petition for a widow's pension .<br>---<br>Will of Thomas Cochrane dated 17 Jul 1809<br>I Thomas Cochrane Capt retired list Royal Indp' t Invalids being in perfect health and sound judgement, considering the pension allowed to officers widows so small, that of a Capt not exceeding forty pounds per annum, and that for the love and respect I bear for Susan Sarah Brownbill, who is to be my lawful wife with the blessing a God I think it duly(?) incumbent on me to make further provision for the said Susan Sarah Brownbill, in ______ she survives me, therefore most solemnly settle six hundred pounds on the said Susan Brownbill and that if she survives me that I give her a dower __________ the said sum of six hundred money for herself for ever, but in ________ Thomas Cochrane ________ sixty pounds ________ on her and ________ the six hundred pounds is to ________ and I do further promise that if the said Susan Sarah Brownbill should bear children of the said Thomas Cochrane that they shall<br>and will be intitled to a _________ of one half of __________.<br>Given under my hand and seal in London this 17th day of July 1809.<br>Thomas Cochrane<br>Witness<br>________ Goodwin<br>W Nisbett of the Admiralty<br>---<br>Draft of Additional Paragraph for New Will<br>That in case Susan Cochrane my lawful wife should survive me Capt. T. Cochrane I do make over to the said S. S. Cochrane as jointure all of that part of the lands of Drumhunny which lands are bounded on the South East by the lands of Aughareny; on the East by the lands, with the appurtenances thereunto belonging, which lands are situate lying and being in the Barony of Lurg and county Fermanagh, likewise to grant unto the said S.S.C. any profits that may arise from mines minerals quarries and and all other royalties of what And or nature soever with full dower to receive the sums during her natural life.<br>---<br>Will of Thomas Cochrane dated 7 Oct 1813<br>In the name of God Amen. I Thomas Cochrane of His Majesty's Royal independent individuals now residing in Princes Row Pimlico near London considering the certainty of death and the uncertainty of the time thereof do make this my last will and testament as follows  Whereas upon my marriage with my wife Susan Sarah Daughter of Mrs. Mary Brownbill of Suffolk Street Charing Cross London it was stipulated and agreed that I should duly secure to be paid to her the sum of sixty pounds per annum sterling money for her natural life over and above the sum of forty pounds per annum as a pension from Government to which she was led to believe she would be intitled upon my decease and whereas I am desirous of fully confirming and carrying into effect such agreement and to provide for my wife accordingly and whereas I am now seized or possessed of certain lands hereinafter described absolutely as my property now I the said testator Thomas Cochrane do by this my will give devise and bequeath all those my lands being part of the lands of Drumkinny in Ireland as lately decreed and divided by His Majesty's Court of Exchequer there bounded on the south east by the lands of Aughareny on the east by ________ ________ and situate lying and being in the Barony of Lurg and County of Fermanagh and which lands so hereby devised and bequeathed are now held by lease granted thereof from my late brother William Cochrane on or about the fifteenth day of March one thousand seven hundred and ninety six in pursuance of a power given him as my attorney for that purpose by Archibald Johnson of Leehan in the said County of Fermanagh farmer for a term of twenty one years determinable with his natural life together with all and singular the rights members and appurtenances thereunto belonging unto and to the use of my said wife Susan Sarah to have and to hold the same devised lands and their appurtenances to my said wife Susan Sarah without impeachment of waste for and during the term of her natural life to and for her own proper use and benefit absolutely and from and after her decease then I give devise and beneath the same lands and appurtenances to and for the use of all and every the child and children of the said Susan Sarah Cochrane lawfully begotten during my said marriage if more than one as joint tenants with full benefit of survivorship in case of the death of either of them under the age of twenty one years _________ such only child and __________ and their heirs absolutely and respectively for ever. But in default of issue or in case of their all dying under the age of twenty one years and from and aftersuch the decease of the said Susan Sarah my wife then I give devise and bequeath the same lands and premises unto and to the use of my right heir for ever. And I do hereby will and direct that in case the said lands and premises upon the determination of the said lease and upon their being then let or leased at the most improved annual value should not equal in yearly income over and above all taxes and deductions the said sum of sixty pounds per annum so agreed to be settled on my wife before our marriage then and in that case that all and singular my estate and effects whatsoever and wheresoever shall be and become subject and liable to and with the annual payment of so much and such part of the said yearly sum of sixty pounds as the lands hereby devised shall be insufficient and 4B inadequate to make good and produce. And I do hereby constitute and appoint my said wife Susan Sarah and my friend Gwynn Vaughan Edward of Suffolk Street aforesaid gentleman executor and executrix of this my will hereby revoking all former wills and declaring this only to be my last will and testament as aforesaid. In witness whereof I the said testator Thomas Cochrane have hereunto set my hand and seal this seventh day of October in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirteen.<br>Signed sealed published and deaclared by the testator<br>Thomas Cochrane as and for his last will and testament contained in this one sheet of paper the seventh day of October one thousand eight hundred and thirteen in our presence who in his presence at his request and in the presence of each other have subscribed our names as witnesses thereto<br>Robt C King                         Thomas Cochrane<br>James Harris, Princess Row<br>________________________<br>Codicil to Previous Will dated 18 May 1814<br>This is a codicil to the last will and testament of me the undersigned Thomas Cochrane Esquire now of Princes Row Pimlico in the County of Middlesex Captain of Royal Invalids and I direct the same to be taken as part of such will dated or purpoting to bear date the seventh day of October now last pastvidelizet: I do hereby give and bequeath to my beloved wife Susan Sarah (in addition to the provision intended to be made for her by my said will) all my household furniture linen and effects whatsoever that now are or may be in or about the dwellinghouse and premises wherein I now reside or may happen to reside at the time of my death together with all my ready money of which I may be then possessed or which may be due to me from Government or be and remain in the hands of my present agent or any future agent or agents hereafter employed by me. To have and to hold same household furniture money and effects unto and to the use of my said wife Susan Sarah Cochrane her executors administrators and assigns absolutely for ever. And I do hereby in all respects ratify and confirm my said All. in witness whereof I the said Thomas Cochrane have to this codicil contained on one side of paper set my hand and seal the eighteenth day of May in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fourteen.<br>Signed sealed published and declared by the abovenamed Thomas Cochrane as and for a codicil to his last will in our presence who in his presence at his request and in the presence of each other have subscribed our names as witness thereto.<br>___________ Edwards                              Thomas Cochrane<br>__________________<br>---<br>Will or Codicil to Will dated 15 May 1818<br>I Captain Thomas Cochrane now living in the parish of St Pancras being of sound and disposing memory do will and devise as follows. To my dear wife Susan Sarah Cochrane all my household furniture of every description plate linen wearing apparel etc. in my dwelling house situate in Arlington Street Camden Town all money I may be possessed of at the time of my decease or may remain in the hands of my agent arising from my pension or other ways to my said wife Susan Sarah Cochrane for her use and my beloved infant son John Thomas Cochrane I do hereby further acknowledge this to be in addition to any provisions I have any time heretofore made in behalf of my aforesaid wife Susan Sarah Cochrane.<br>his<br>Captain Thomas + Cochrane<br>mark<br>Dated May 15th 1818. Signed in the presence of us<br>Nathaniel Pointer, Camden Town<br>Roger Smith, Camden Town<br>Extracted by Toller & Son<br>Proctors Doctors Commons"

"NI298","Summoned to Parliment from 26-Feb-1421 to 26-May-1455, but was granted<br>exemption in 1447.  He was Chief Justice and Chamberlain of South Wales.<br>Taking up arms on behalf of Henry VI, he was slain at the Battle of Blore<br>Blore Heath."
"NI302","4th Baron Audley.<br>Summond to Parliment from 21-Dec-1405 to 26-Aug-1408."
"NI304","2nd Baron Audley.<br>Had summons to Parliment from 25-Jan-1330 to 8-Aug-1386, but received<br>an exemption from attendance for the ramainder of his life 20-Apr-1353."
"NI305","Daughter of 1st Earl of March."
"NI306","3rd Baron Audley."
"NI313","1st Lord Audley."
"NI314","Widow of Henry Lacy, Earl of Lincoln.  Sister and co-heir of William,<br>Lord Martin."
"NI317","Built the castle at Heleigh and founded Hulton Abbey in 1223."
"NI318","Daughter of Roger, 5th Lord Strange"
"NI324","Earl of Kent."
"NI325","2nd Earl of Castlehaven, 12th Baron Audley.<br>By his first wife he had 3 sons and as many daughters.<br>Beheaded on Tower Hill for unnatural offenses after a trial by his peers.<br>---<br>THE VERDICTS OF EACH OF THE JURORS IN THE TRIAL OF MERVYN TOUCHET, LORD AUDLEY 1631<br>The vote on rape precedes the vote on sodomy under each juror name below.<br>Bio­graphical details from CP and DNB.<br>Richard Weston, Lord Western<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1576/77-1634/35). Lord Treasurer. Student at the Middle Temple in 1593/94. Member of Parliament for Essex in 1614; privy councilor from 1621; Lord Treasurer from 1628 until his death. Male heir born 1605. Created Baron Weston in 1628 and 1st Earl of Portland in 1633.<br>Henry Montagu, 1st Earl of Manchester<br>guilty/guilty<br>(ca. 1563-1642). Lord Privy Seal. In 1606 was a Reader at the Middle Temple. Member of Parliament for London, 1614; Sergeant-at-Law and King's Sergeant in 1611; Chief Justice of the King's Bench from 1616 to 1620; member of the Privy Council from 1620. Male heir bom 1602. Close ally of the Countess of Castlehaven's mother; father-in-law to Warwick's daughter. Cre­ated Earl of Manchester, 1626.<br>Thomas Howard, Earl of Arundel<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1585-1646). Earl Marshal. Privy councilor from 1616. Male heir born 1608. Restored to his father's earldom, 1604.<br>Philip Herbert, Earl of Pembroke<br>(KB8/63 lists his forename as John]<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(1584-1649/50) Lord Chamberlain. Member of the Privy Chamber; Lord Chamberlain of the Household from 1626 to 1641. Lord Lieutenant of Wiltshire and several other counties from 1630. Married (1) 1604, Susan, daughter of Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford, and Anne Cecil and sister to Elizabeth, Countess of Derby; (2) Anne, widow of Richard Sackville, Earl of Dorset, heir of George Clifford, Earl of Cumberland, and Margaret, daughter of Francis Russell, Earl of Bedford. Adulterous alliance with Berkshire's daughter. Male heir bom 1619. Created Earl of Montgomery 1605 and succeeded his brother as Earl of Pembroke in 1630.<br>Henry Grey, Earl of Kent<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(ca. 1583-1639). Member of Parliament for Bedfordshire 1614. Succeeded to the earldom, 1623.<br>Henry Somerset, Earl of Worcester<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(1576/77-1646). Attended the Middle Temple 1598/99. Married in 1600 to Ann, daughter of Lord Russell; male heir bom 1601. Brother-in-law of Petre. Succeeded to earldom, 1628.<br>Francis Russell, Earl of Bedford<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(1593-1641). In 1608/9, married Catherine, daughter and co-heir of Giles Brydges, 3rd Baron of Chandos, and Frances, daughter of Edward Clinton, Earl of Lincoln. Male heir bom 1616. Succeeded to the earldom, 1627.<br>Robert Devereux, Earl of Essex<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(1590/91-1646). Married (1) 1605/6 to Fiances Howard, daughter of Thomas Howard, Earl of Suffolk, and Katherine, daughter and co-heir of Sir Henry Knyvett; marriage dissolved in 1613; (2) 1630/31 to Elizabeth, daughter of Sir William Paulet of Eddington, Wiltshire. Former brother-in-law of Berk- shire and of Howard. Restored to his father's earldom, 1604.<br>Edward Sackville, Earl of Dorset<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(1590-1652). Chamberlain to the Queen from 1628. Member of the Privy Council from 1626. Married Mary, daughter and heir of Sir George Curzon, and governess to the children of Charles I. Male heir born 1622. Succeeded to the earldom, 1624.<br>William Cecil, Earl of Salisbury<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(1591-1664/65). Member of the Privy Council from 1626. Brother-in-law of Clifford, Howard, and Berkshire; father-in-law of Percy; first cousin of Wimbledon. Succeeded to the earldom, 1612.<br>Robert Sydney, Earl of Leicester<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(1595-1677). Member of Parliament for Wilton in 1614. In 1615, married Dorothy, daughter of Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland, and Dorothy, daughter of Walter Devereux, Earl of Essex; male heir bom 1619. Brother-in-law of Percy and of Carlisle; related by marriage to Holland and Warwick. Succeeded to the earldom, 1626.<br>Robert Rich, Earl of Warwick<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1587-1658). Admitted to the Inner Temple in 1604; member of Parliament for Essex in 1614; burgess of Southampton, 1626. Male heir bom 1611; older brother of Holland; related by marriage to Leicester and Carlisle. Succeeded to the earldom, 1619.<br>James Hay, Earl of Carlisle<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1580-1636). Bom in Scotland, educated in France. Gentleman of the Bed­chamber to James 11603-15; member of the Privy Council from 1616/17. He married (1) in 1606/7, Honora, only child of Edward Denny, Earl of Norwich, and Mary, daughter of Thomas Cecil, Earl of Exeter; (2) in 1617 Lucy, daugh­ter of Henry Percy, Earl of Northumberland, and Dorothy, daughter of Wal­ter Devereux, Earl of Essex. Brother-in-law of Leicester and of Percy; related by marriage to Holland and Warwick. Created Lord Hay, 1606, Earl of Carlisle, 1622.<br>Henry Rich, 1st Earl of Holland<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(1590-1648/49). Steward of the Queen's Household from 1629; member of Parliament for Leicester, 1614; member of the Privy Council from 1625; Gentleman of the Bedchamber from 1626. Male heir bom 1620. Brother of Warwick; related by marriage to Leicester and Carlisle. Created Earl of Hol­land, 1624.<br>Thomas Howard, Earl of Berkshire<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(ca. 1590-1669). Second son of Thomas, 1st Earl of Suffolk, and Catherine, daughter and co-heir of Sir Henry Knyvett of Charlton, Wiltshire. Member of Parliament for Wiltshire in 1614. Married Elizabeth, daughter and co-heir of William Cecil, 2nd Earl of Exeter, and niece of Viscount Wimbledon, in 1614. Designated in 1621/22 as the heir to his mother's Wiltshire estates and created Baron Howard of Charleton, Wiltshire. Male heir born 1615. Brother of Howard; brother-in-law of Salisbury; former brother-in-law of Essex: daughter was Pembroke's mistress. In 1625/26, created Earl of Berkshire.<br>Henry Danvers, 1st Earl ofDanby<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1573-1643/44). Second son of Sir John Danvers of Dauntsey, Wiltshire. Fought as a soldier in Europe and in Ireland; Lord President of Munster, 1607-15; member of the Privy Council from 1628. Created Baron Danvers of Dantsey,Wiltshire, 1603, and Earl of Danby, Yorkshire, 1625/26.<br>Edward Cecil, Viscount Wimbledon<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1571/72-1638). Gentleman of the Privy Chamber for James I. Third son ofThomas Cecil, 1st Earl of Exeter. Married in 1601 to Theodosia, sister of Edward Noel, 2nd ViscountCampden, and of the 1st Dowager Countess of Castlehaven, Elizabeth Noel Touchet Crosby; first cousin of Salisbury. Created Viscount Wimbledon, 1625.<br>Edward Conway, Viscount Conway<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1594-1655). Son and heir of the former Secretary of State. Married 1621 to Frances, daughter of Sir Francis Popham of Littlecote, Wiltshire. Male heir born 1623. Succeeded to the Viscountcy in January 1631.<br>Dudley Carleton, Viscount Dorchester<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1573/74-1631/32). Principal Secretary of State from 1628; member of the Privy Council from 1625. His second wife was Anne, daughter of Sir Henry Glenham, and Anne, daughter of Thomas Sackville, Earl of Dorset. Created Baron, 1626, Viscount, 1628.<br>Thomas, Viscount Wentworth<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1593-1641). Lord President of the North. Member of Parliament for Yorkshire, 1614; privy councilor from 1629. Male heir born 1626. Brother-in-law of Clifford. Created Baron in July 1628, 'Viscount in December 1628.<br>Henry Clifford, Lord Clifford<br>guilty/guilty<br>(ca. 1591/92-1643). Member of Parliament for Westmoreland, 1614. Son of the Earl of Cumberland (succeeded him 1641); brother-in-law of Salisbury and of Wentworth.<br>Algernon Percy, 4th Lord Percy<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1602-68). Third but first-surviving son of the Earl of Northumberland. Son-in-law of Salisbury; brother-in-law of Leicester. Took his seat in the House of Lords as Lord Percy in 1626 and succeeded his father as Earl of Northumberland in 1632.<br>James Stanley, Lord Strange<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1607-51). Son of William Stanley, Earl of Derby (succeeded in 1642). Summoned to Parliament as Lord Strange in 1627/28. Male heir bom 1628. First cousin of Anne, Countess of Castlehaven.<br>Dudley North, 3rd Lord North<br>not guilty/not guilty<br>(1582-1665/66). Male heir bom 1602. Succeeded as Lord North, 1600.<br>William Petre, 2nd Lord Petre<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1575-1637). Student at the Middle Temple in 1593. Married in 1596 to Katherine, 2nd daughter of Edward Somerset, 4th Earl of Worcester, and Elizabeth, daughter of Francis Hastings, 2nd Earl of Huntingdon. Male heir born 1599. Brother-in-law of Worcester. Succeeded 1613.<br>Edward Howard of Escrick<br>guilty/not guilty<br>(b.?-1675). Youngest son of Thomas, 1st Earl of Suffolk, and Catherine, daughter and co-heir of Sir Henry Knyvett of Charleton, Wiltshire. Male heir born 1625. Married to Mary, daughter of Sir John Boteler and niece of the Duke of Buckingham. Brother of Berkshire; brother-in-law of Salisbury; former brother-in-law of Essex. Created Baron Howard of Escrick in 1628.<br>George Goring, Lord Goring<br>guilty/guilty<br>(1585-1662/63). Master of the Queen's Horse since 1628; Gentleman of the<br>Privy Chamber to the Prince of Wales in 1610 and to the King in 1611; Vice-Chamberlain of the Queen's Household, 1626-28. Married Lettice, third daughter of the 1st Earl of Cork and once the intended spouse of James, Lord Audley Male heir bom 1615. Created Baron Goring, 1628 (succeeded his Uncle as 2nd Earl of Norwich in 1644).<br>---<br>Mervyn (or Mervin) Touchet (or Tuchet), (1592-1631), 2nd earl<br>Castlehaven, 9th lord Audley, was beheaded on Tower Hill for unnatural<br>offences, after a trial by his peers, on 14 May 1631 and his honours<br>forfeited. (Cobbett, State Trials, iii. 401-26; The Arraignment and<br>Conviction of Mervin Touchet, Earl of Castlehaven, with rough portrait<br>as frontpiece, London, 1642).<br>His eldest daughter, Lady Lucy Touchet, m. John Anketell of Farriby.<br>Their daughter, Frances Anketell, m. Thomas O'Grady ancestor of<br>Viscount Standish O'Grady.<br>His eldest son and heir, James, by his first wife, Elizabeth, daughter<br>and heiress of Benedict Barnham, alderman of London, was born about<br>1617. James Tuchet was restored to the dignities 1634, and became<br>the 3rd earl of Castlehaven, in Ireland, and 10th lord Audley, in<br>England; he had a command against the rebels in Ireland, under the<br>duke of Ormond, and has left an account of his warfare, entitled Lord<br>Castlehaven's Memoirs.<br>When a mere boy of thirteen or fourteen, James was married to<br>Elizabeth Brydges (daughter of his father's second wife, Anne, by her<br>first husband, Grey Brydges, fifth baron Chandos of Sudeley). When<br>scarcely twelve years of age, the girl was forced by her stepfather<br>(Mervyn Tuchet) into criminal intercourse with her mother's lover,<br>Henry Skipworth. She died in 1679, and was buried in St<br>Martin's-in-the-Fields. Utterly neglected as to his education, and<br>disgusted at the scenes of bestiality he was compelled to witness, but<br>preserving his natural sense of decency intact, he appealed for<br>protection from the earl, his natural father, to the father of his<br>country, the king's majesty, and was instrumental in bringing his<br>father to justice. (Cal. State Papers, Dom 1629-31 p.371, 1631-3<br>p.20). His conduct, though a severe strain on his filial duty, was<br>regarded with approval, and on 3 June 1633 he was created Baron Audley<br>of Heleigh, with a remainder to his heirs forever, and with the<br>place and precedency of George, his grandfather; but in the meantime<br>most of his father's estates in England had passed into the hands of<br>Lord Cottington and others. In so far as the creation was virtually a<br>restoration to an ancient dignity, it lay outside the power of the<br>crown alone to make it, but the necessary confirmation was obtained by<br>act of parliament in 1678. As for the Irish peerage, it was held to be<br>protected by the statute de donis, preserving all entailed honours<br>against forfeiture for felony. (cf. Cokayne, Peerage, and legal<br>authorities quoted).<br>Sources : The Dictionary of National Biography quoting from original<br>sources.<br>Executed by The Crown for unnatural acts."
"NI327","Benedict Barnham was a London Alderman and merchant, and was Sheriff<br>of London in 1592; his father had been Sheriff before him. A note in<br>the 'Genealogical Record of the Barnum Family' refers to St. Clement's<br>Church in connection with Benedict. The reference may be to his place<br>of burial, since his brother Sir Martin Barnham is buried there."
"NI328","13th Baron Audley<br>---<br>James Touchet (or Tuchet, or Audley) was restored to the dignities in<br>1634, following the trial and beheading of his father, and became the<br>3rd earl of Castlehaven, in Ireland, and 10th lord Audley, in England;<br>he had a command against the rebels in Ireland, under the duke of<br>Ormond, and has left an account of his warfare, entitled Lord<br>Castlehaven's Memoirs.<br>He was the eldest son and heir of Mervyn, lord Audley, second earl of<br>Castlehaven, by his first wife, Elizabeth, daughter and heiress of<br>Benedict Barnham, alderman of London, was born about 1617. His father<br>(1592-1631), a man of the most profligate life, who married for his<br>second wife Lady Anne, daughter of Ferdinando Stanley, fifth earl of<br>Derby, and widow of Grey Brydges, fifth baron Chandos, was executed<br>for unnatural offences, after a trial by his peers, on 14 may 1631.<br>He was the only son and heir of George Touchet, baron Audley<br>(1550-1617), sometime governor of Utrecht, who was wounded at the<br>siege of Kinsale on 24 December 1601, was an undertaker in the<br>plantation of Ulster, was summoned by writ to the Irish House of Lords<br>on 11 March 1613-14, was created a peer of Ireland as Baron Audley of<br>Orier, County Armagh, and Earl of Castlehaven, County Cork, on 6<br>September 1616, and died in March 1617.<br>When he was a boy of thirteen or fourteen, James, earl of Castlehaven,<br>was married to Elisabeth Brydges (daughter of his father's second<br>wife, Anne, by her first husband, Grey Brydges, fifth baron Chandos of<br>Sudeley). When she was barely twelve years of age, the girl had been<br>forced by her stepfather into criminal intercourse with her mother's<br>lover, Henry Skipworth. She died in 1679, and was buried on 16 March<br>at St. Martin's-in-the-fields. Utterly neglected as to his education,<br>and discusted at the scenes of bestiality he was compelled to witness,<br>but preserving his natural sense of decency intact, 'he appealed for<br>protection from the earl, his natural father, to the father of his<br>country, the king's majesty,' and was instrumental in bringing his<br>father to justice. His conduct, though a severe strain on his filial<br>duty, was regarded with approval, and on 3 June 1633 he was created<br>Baron Audley of Hely, with remainder 'to his heirs for ever,' and with<br>the place and precedency of George, his grandfather; but in the<br>meanwhile most of his father's estates in England had passed into the<br>possession of Lord Cottington and others. In so far as the creation<br>was virtually a restoration to an ancient dignity, it lay outside the<br>power of the crown alone to make it, but necessary confirmation was<br>obtained by act of parliament in 1678. As for the Irish peerage, it<br>was held to be protected by the statute 'de donis,' preserving all<br>entailed honours against forfeiture for felony.<br>Feeling attracted to a soldier's life, Castlehaven obtained permission<br>to visit the theater of war on the continent, and was at Rome in 1638<br>when, in consequence of the prospect of war between England and<br>Scotland, he was commanded to return home. Setting out immediately,<br>he reached England early in the following year. He attended Charles I<br>at Berwick, but after the first pacification he returned to the<br>continent and witnessed the capitulation of Arras by Owen Roe O'Neill<br>to the French. Returning to England to put his affairs there in<br>order, he afterwards proceeded for the same purpose to Ireland, and<br>was on the point of leaving the latter country when the rebellion<br>broke out on 23 october 1641. Hastening to Dublin, he offered his<br>services to the government; but the Lords justices, Sir William<br>Parsons and Sir John Borlase, suspecting his motives as a Roman<br>catholic, declined his offer, as likewise they did his request to be<br>permitted to repair to England, requiring him, on the contrary, to<br>retire to his house at Maddenstown in County Kildare, and if need were<br>'to make fair weather' with the rebels. Obeying their commands, he at<br>once proceeded thither, and was instrumental in relieving the<br>distressed English in those parts. But his hesitating conduct in not<br>joining the Earl of Ormonde at the battle of Kilrush on 15 April 1642,<br>and his undertaking to mediate between the Lords of the Pale and the<br>government, affording plausible grounds for doubting his loyalty, he<br>was towards the latter end of May indicted of high treason at Dublin.<br>'Amazed at this sad and unexpected news,' he posted to Dublin,<br>presented himself before the council, and after some debate was<br>committed to the custody of one of the sheriffs of the city. Several<br>month passed and, learning that it was intended to remove him into<br>stricter confinement in the castle, he resolved, 'with God's help, not<br>tamely to die butchered,' and, having managed to elude the vigilance<br>of his keeper, he escaped on 27 September into the Wicklow mountains.<br>His intention was 'to gain a passage by Wexford into France, and from<br>thence into England;' but coming to Kilkenny, the headquaters of the<br>confederate catholics, he was persuaded to accept a command in the<br>army, and was appointed general of horse under Sir Thomas Preston<br>(afterwards Viscount Tara). Such is his own account in the 'Memoirs'<br>and 'Remontrance;' but it was believed among the northern Irish that<br>his escape was a contrivance on the part of the Earl of Ormonde 'to<br>work and understanding' between him and his kindred in rebellion,<br>Castlehaven being related to him through the marriage of his sister<br>with Edmund Roe Butler.<br>Castlehaven served with Preston at the capture of Burros Castle on 30<br>December, and of Birr on 19 January following (1643), and, being<br>entrusted with the execution of the articles of capitulation of the<br>latter, he conveyed the garrison safely to Athy. He commanded the<br>horse at the battle of Ross on 18 March, where the confederates were<br>defeated by the Marquis of Ormonde, and when Preston, having rallied<br>his forces ,sat down before Ballynekill, he intercept and routed a<br>strong detachment sent to raise the siege under colonel Crawford near<br>Athy on 13 April. His main business was to cover Kilkenny, but, in<br>consequence of the progress Inchiquin (O'Brien, Murrough, first Earl<br>of Inchiquin) was making in Munster, he was sent with what forces he<br>could collect into that province. On 4 June he overtook Sir C.<br>Vavasour near Castle Lyons, and defeated him with heavy loss, killing<br>some six hundred men on the spot, taking Sir Charles himself and<br>several of his officers prisoners, and capturing all his cannon and<br>baggage, with little or no injury to himself. Returning to Kilkenny,<br>he was afterwards employed in reducing the outstanding fortresses in<br>County Kildare between the Barrow and the Liffey, when his further<br>progress was stopped by the conclusion of the cessation, in promoting<br>wich he had taken an active part, on 15 September. He was very useful<br>in providing shipping at Wexford to transport the Irish soldiers<br>furnished by Ormonde for the king's service into England, and, the<br>Scottish forces under major-general Robert Monro in Ulster refusing to<br>be bound by the cessation, he was appointed to the command of six<br>thousand foot and six hundred horse to be sent to the aid of Owen Roe<br>O'Neill in the following year (1644). But before he could proceed<br>thither he was ordered to suppress a local insurrection in County<br>Mayo. This done, he effected a junction with O'Neill at Portlester,<br>and toward the end of July Both armies marches towards Tanderagee.<br>But Monro avoided giving battle, and Castlehaven, after lying<br>intrenched near Charlemont for two months, and exhausting his<br>provisions, retired, 'taking a great round' to Ballyhaise in County<br>Cavan, much to the dissatisfaction of the northern Irish, who charged<br>him with cowardice. Havin seen his army into winter quarters, and<br>coming to Kilkenny, he found the Supreme Council in a state of<br>consternation owing to the defection of Lord Inchiquin and the<br>surrender of Duncannon Fort by sir Laurence Esmonde. He served as a<br>volunteer under Preston at the siege of Duncannon, and was present at<br>its rendition on 18 March 1645. But the truce with Inchiquin drawing<br>near its expiration, he was sent with five thousand foot and one<br>thousand horse into Munster, and speedily reduced all the castles in<br>the baronies of Imokilly and Barrimore, and, having wasted the country<br>up to the walls of Cork, he sat down before Youghal, 'thinking to<br>distress the place' into a surrender; but the town being relieved he<br>marched off, and, having 'triffled out the remains of the campain in<br>destroying the harvest,' put his army into winter quarters and<br>returned to Kilkenny towards the latter end of November. He was one<br>of the signatories to the contract with the Papal Nuncio, Giovanni<br>Battista Rinuccini, on 19 February 1646, not to conclude a peace till<br>provision had been made for the full exercise of the catholic<br>religion; but, after the publication of the peace between the<br>confederates and Ormonde on 30 July, he was deputed by the latter to<br>proceed to Waterford for the purpose of persuading the Papal Nuncio's<br>acceptance of it. Failing in this, he threw himself unreservedly on<br>Ormonde's side, and when the latter, in consequence of O'Neill's<br>determination to support the Nuncio with his army, was compelled to<br>fall back on Dublin, he accompanied him thither, bearing the sword of<br>state before him on his entrance into the city on 13 September.<br>Afterwards, when the question arose whether terms should be made with<br>the parliament or with the supreme council, he gave his opinion in<br>favour of the former - 'for giving up to parliament, when the King<br>should have England, he would have Ireland with it; but to the Nuncio<br>and his party it might prove far other ways, and the two kingdoms<br>remain separate.'<br>He quit Ireland apparently before the parliamentary commissioners<br>arrived, and, repairing to France, was present at the battle of<br>Landrecies, fighting in Prince Rupert's troop, commanded by Captain<br>Somerset Fox. Afterwards going to St. Germain, he remained there in<br>attendance on the Queen and Prince of Wales till latter end of<br>September 1648, when he returned with the Marquis of Ormonde to<br>Ireland. A peace having been concluded with the confederates in<br>January 1659, he was appointed general of th horse, and, with five<br>thousand foot and one thousand horse, employed in reducing the<br>fortresses holding out for O'Neill in Queen's county. But his<br>half-starved soldiers deserted in shoals, and after the capture of<br>Athy on 21 May he complained that the fifteen hundred foot that<br>remainded with him were only kept alive by stealing cows. Worn out<br>with fatigue and dissatisfied at the preference shown by some of the<br>general assembly for Lord Taaffe, his competitor for the generalship<br>of the horse, he obtained permission to retire to Kilkenny, where he<br>was instrumental in suppressing a revolt of friars. But the<br>difficulties connected with his command being shortly afterwards<br>removed, he joined the army under Ormonde at Rathmines, and shared his<br>defeat by Jones on 2 August. He signed the order for the defence of<br>Drogheda, and, having been entrusted by Ormonde with a special command<br>over the forces destined for the relief of the southern towns, he<br>succeeded on 6 October in throwing fifteen hundred men into Wexford,<br>thereby enabling Synnot to break of his correspondance with Cromwell.<br>A few day later he forced Ireton to raise the siege of Duncannon; but<br>being appointed governor of waterford, with one thousand men to<br>reinforce the garrison, he was refused admittance by the citizens, and<br>'after several days' dispute marched away.' During the winter he<br>amused himself in his favorite pastime, fox-hunting. He was appointed<br>commander-in-chief of the Leinster forces by Ormonde, whom the<br>exigencies of the situation drove to Limerick early in the following<br>year for the purpose of raising reinforcements 'to attend Cromwell's<br>motions,' and in March 1650 Castlehaven took the field with some four<br>thousand men. Finding himself too weak to assume the offensive, he<br>contended himself with watching Hewson's movements, and indeed managed<br>the wrest Athy out his hands. But after the surrender of Kilkenny to<br>Cromwell on 28 March 1650, he withdrew to the borders of King's<br>County, and in June made an unsuccessful attempt to relieve Tecroghan,<br>which 'was by the confession of all parties, even of the enemy,<br>allowed to be the gallantest action that had been performed since the<br>beginning of the war.'<br>Afterwards finding it impossible to keep an army together, he granted<br>commission for horse and foot to all that applied for them, whereby,<br>although managing to keep up an appearance of war, he gave to it the<br>character of a freebooting campaign, wich caused as much arm to his<br>own party as to the enemy. Meanwhile, the Lord-Lieutenant, having<br>been foiled in his efforts to recruit his army through the obstinacy<br>of the citizens of Limerick refusing to receive a garrison, and seeing<br>no hope of effecting a compromise with the extreme Irish, had come to<br>the determination to quit the kingdom. Castlehaven did his utmost to<br>combat his resolution, urging him to 'make friendship with the bishops<br>and the nation.' But his overtures were treated with disdain; 'the<br>bishop and the nation' were bent on managing theirs affairs in their<br>own way, and so, having appointed Clanricarde his Lord-deputy and<br>Castlehaven commander-in-chief in the province of Munster and county<br>of Clare, Ormonde sailed from Galway Bay for France in December. The<br>approach of Ireton however, causing the citizens of Limerick somewhat<br>to relax their opposition, they admitted Castlehaven himself 'with the<br>matter of one troup of horse.' The concession enabled him to<br>transport two thousand men into Kerry and clear that county almost<br>entirely of the enemy. Returning for Christmas to Portumna, he early<br>in following year (1651) crossed the shannon into County Tipperary;<br>but the object of the expedition was frustrated by the plundering<br>propensities of his officers, and, being compelled to retreat before<br>Ireton and Broghill, he recrossed the Shannon at Athlone. Failing to<br>prevent Ireton sitting down before Limerick,the capitulation of that<br>city on 27 October, followed by the loss of County Clare, forced him<br>and Clanricarde into Iar Connaught. But, the situation growing daily<br>more desesperate, he was on 10 April despatched by Clanricarde to<br>France for the purpose of soliciting aid to enable the latter to<br>maintain 'a mountain war.'<br>Reaching Brest after a sharp encounter with an English vessel in the<br>Channel, he posted to Saint Germain, but, failing to obtain the<br>supplies required, he was granted permission to enter the service of<br>the Prince of Condé in the war of the Fronde. Being appointed to the<br>command of a regiment of horse, he was present at the fight in the<br>Faubourg-St- Antoine on 2 July, and, quitting Paris with Condé, he was<br>taken prisoner by Turenne at Comercy. Owing to the intervention of<br>the Duke of York he was shortly afterwards exchanged, and being placed<br>at the head of the Irish regiment in the Spanish service with the rank<br>of Maréchal-de-camp or major-general, he was present at the siege of<br>Rocroy (1653), of Arras (1654), the relief of Valenciennes and the<br>capture of Condé (1656), the siege of St Guislain and the relief of<br>Cambrai (1657), and the battle of the Dunes on 14 June 1658. The<br>peace of the Pyrenees putting an end to the war in the following year<br>(7 November 1659), and Charles II being shortly afterwards restored,<br>he returned to England. But the confiscation of his property by the<br>Commonwealth rendering it impossible to support his dignity, he<br>obtained a grant in September 1660 of all wastes and encroached lands<br>to be discovered by him in the counties of Surrey, Berks, Stafford,<br>Devon, and Cornwall, and either then or subsequently received a<br>pension out of the Irish establishment. On the outbreak of the War<br>with Holland (1665-1667) he served as a volunteer in several naval<br>actions, and in June 1667 landed at Ostend with 2,400 recruits for the<br>old English Regiment, of which he was appointed colonel. His men were<br>used to strengthen the garrison at Nieuport, Lille, Courtrai,<br>Oudenarde, and other places; but, the peace of Aix-la-Chapelle (2 mai<br>1668) putting 'an end to our trouble, for it cannot be called a war,'<br>he shortly afterwards returned to England. Peace being concluded<br>between with Holland and England in 1674, he again repaired abroad,<br>and was present at the battle of Senef on 11 August. He commanded the<br>Spanish foot in 1676, and served in the trenches at Maastricht, 'by<br>much to bloodiest siege that I ever saw.' The following year he was<br>at the siege of Charleroi, and on 14 August 1678 at the battle before<br>Mons; but returning to England after the peace of Nimeguen, he<br>published in 1680 his 'memoirs,' 'from the year 1642 to the year<br>1651.'<br>The book, a small octavo volume with a dedication to Charles II, is,<br>on the whole, what it claims to be, a trustworthy account of the War<br>in Ireland from a Catholic-Royalist standpoint. But, being written<br>from memory, it is not wholly free from accidental inaccuracies, while<br>the very biased view taken of the conduct of the lords justicies<br>Parsons and Borlase at the beginning of the rebellion, and of the<br>peace of 1643, renders a circumspect use of it necessary. Appearing<br>as it did during the heat of the 'popish plot,' 'a very unseasonable<br>time,' remarks Carte, 'for reviving or canvasing such a subject,' it<br>was attacked by Arthur Annesley, earl of Anglesey, at that time lord<br>privy seal, in 'A letter from a person of honour in the country,'<br>London, 1681. At Charles II's request, Ormonde replied to Annesley in<br>'A letter ...in answer to the...Earl of Anglesey...his observations<br>and reflections upon the Earl of Castlehaven's Memoirs,' 12 November<br>1681. Anglesey retorted in another 'Letter,' 7 December 1681, where<br>upon Ormonde appealed to the Pprivy Council on 17 June 1682 to appoint<br>a committee to examine Anglesey's 'letter.' The matter ended, as it<br>was probably intended it should do, in the dissimal of Anglesey and<br>the transfer of the privy seal to Lord Halifax. The charges prefered<br>by Anglesey were repeated in 'Brief reflections on the Earl of<br>Castlehaven's memoirs,' by Edmund Borlase, London, 1682. In the<br>spring of 1683 it was rumoured that Castlehaven, Lansdowne, and other<br>noblemen intended 'to go as volunteers to the holy war in Hungary'.<br>But he seems to have occupied himself preparing a fresh edition of his<br>'memoirs,' published in 1685, bringing the narrative down to the peace<br>of Nimeguen. An edition with an anonymous preface by Charles<br>O'Conor, was published at Waterford in 1753, and another at Dublin in<br>1815.<br>Castlehaven died at Kilcash, County Tipperary, his sister Butler's<br>house, on 11 October 1684, and was succeeded by his youngest brother<br>Mervyn (the second son, George, a Benedictine monk, being expressly<br>passed over in the act of 1678). Of his three sisters, Frances became<br>the wife of Richard Butler of Kilcash, brother of the Duke Ormonde;<br>Dorothy, the wife of Edmund Butler, son and heir of Lord Mountgarret;<br>and Lucy, the wife of Gerald Fitzmaurice, son of Lord Kerry."
"NI330","14th Baron Audley"
"NI331","Daughter of 5th Lord Chandos."
"NI335","Widow of Charles Arundell. 3rd daughter of 10th Earl of Shrewsberry."
"NI336","15th Baron Audley.  3rd Earl of Castlehaven."
"NI339","4th Earl of Castlehaven and 16th Baron Audley."

"NI342","6th Earl of Castlehaven and 18th Baron Audley."
"NI344","Lt. Gov. of Fort of Langaurd Point."
"NI346","Rector of Farthingoe, Northants."
"NI347","19th Baron Audley.<br>In 1784, by Royal Permission, he assumed the additional surname of Tuchet."
"NI349","Daughter and co-heir of 2nd Lord Deleval"
"NI350","20th Baron Audley."
"NI360","Of Tralee, Co. Kerry."
"NI362","Died unmarried."
"NI366","Assumed name of Tuchet-Jesson in lieu of Jesson 9-Aug-1937."
"XI381","Ashes Spread over the Pacific Ocean out of Astoria Oregon"
"NI386","Biography for G. C. Betz, Bureau County, Illinois:<br>G. C. Betz, Lamoille, is a native of the Grand Duchy of Darmstadt, Germany, as were his parents, Adam and Elizabeth Betz.  Adam Betz was a soldier under Napoleon Bonapart 1, the great emperor and conqueror, and with him participated in the world-famous battles of Austerlitz and Jena and a number of other engagements.  He was a farmer and came to the United States in 1844.  He died in Peru, Ill., in March 1864, aged 82 years.  Our subject went to school in the old country and there learned the shoemaker trade..  He immigrated to the United States in 1840, and followed his trade in Philadelphia till 1848, when he removed to Lamoille, Ill., where he worked at his trade till 1861, when he became a successful farmer.  He yet owns a farm of ninety acres.  Politically Mr. Betz has been a Republican and filled the office of Postmaster from 1858 to 1875; the office of Commissioner for six years; and Justice of the Peace and Police Magistrate almost from 1870 to the present time. Religiously he is an earnest member of the Congregational Church. He was married November 23, 1843, in Philadelphia, to Fredericka Stelz, a native of Wurtemberg, Germany.  She died here February 3, 1876, aged fifty-five years.  Her two children now living are Charles H., of York County, Neb. and Mrs. Lillie I. Morrison, also a resident of Nebraska. She is the mother of Mr. Betz's two grandchildren, George and Herman Morrison.<br>---<br>From Illinois Public Domain Land Tract Sales Database: Name of Purchaser: Betz George C Sale Type: RR Legal Description: SENE Section: 22 Twnship: 18N Range: 10E Meridian: 4 Acres Bought: 39.27 Price Per Acre: 15.00 Total Price: 589.00 Date Purchased: 2/28/1871<br>Name of Purchaser: Betz George C Sale Type: RR Legal Description: NENE Section: 22 Twnship: 18N Range: 10E Meridian: 4 Acres Bought: 40.00 Price Per Acre: 15.00 Total Price: 600.00 Date Purchased: 2/28/1871"
"NI392","Died of yellow fever on a selling trip to Mobile, Alabama."
"NI393","Moved to Athens, Ohio in 1836."
"NI394","In 1776 he enlisted during the American Revolution as a private in Captain John Dean's company of the Flying Camp.<br>In 1777 he volunteered under Captain John Hawkins as a private and was wounded at the battle of Brandywine, Pennsylvania.<br>At the time of his enlistment he was living in Queen Anne Co., Maryland. After the war he returned to Queen Anne Co. and later moved to Caroline Co., Maryland. In 1797 he moved to Fayette Co., Pennsylvania and in 1802 moved to the Northwest territory (Ohio). In January of 1812 he moved back to Fayette Co., Pennsylvania. On August 6, 1832 he applied for a war pension as a resident of Franklin Twp., Fayette Co., Pennsylvania. In his pension application he stated he was a minister for more than 30 years (Methodist, as was his brother Charles).<br>On November 10, 1804 he bought 54 acres from Arron Hogland (NE Sec.19, Twp.15, Range 2, Hazard, Warren Twp., Jefferson Co., Ohio) for $200.<br>On March 25, 1807 bought 7 acres from William Lewis (part of Sec. 12, Twp.5, Range 2, called Hazard's Outlet in Warren Twp., Jefferson Co., Ohio) for $15.62&1/2.<br>He was listed in Warren Twp., Jefferson Co., Ohio tax list of 1809."
"NI404","- 3rd son of James Johnstone.<br>- Served in the army under Col. Mervyn Archdale and Capt. Fitzmaurice Caldwell"

"NI555","From Prairie Sod and Goldenrod (Crossfield History Committee, 1977, Page 72):<br>The Cochrane Family - by W. G. Cochrane<br>In 1904, the Cochrane family came to the Crossfield district with Mother, brother Douglas, sister Mary and myself.  We homesteaded 25 miles east of town.  In 1912, I married Margaret Story, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Story.  In the fall of 1912 we sold out and my wife and I moved to Red Deer where I went into the Farm Implement business.  While there, two of our four children were born, Marjorie and Gordon.  In 1916 we moved to Calgary and I was employed as a commercial traveller.  Our other two children, Dorothy and Pauline, were born there.<br>Some of the oldtimers I recall are: Mr. and Mrs Seville and sons, Bill Clark, Joe Oswald, Tom McGee, the Copley Bros., Herb Stewart, Levi Bone, Mr. and Mrs. Gunsolly and family Rill, Maude, and Forrest, Matt Morrison and wife, also the Knight family, Walter, Pete and a sister."
"NI607","Twin with Alexander."
"NI608","Twin with David."
"NI616","Died young."
"NI617","Died young."
"NI625","1st Marquess of Tweedale."
"NI635","Of Drumelzier."
"NI636","Died unmarried."
"NI654","The following information was given to me by John Cunningham.  It is from the Erne Packet newspaper dated October 27th, 1810:<br>TO BE SOLD BY AUCTION. For ready money, at Lissingle, (beside Kesh) on Thursday the 8th day of November next, and the succeeding days. The entire household furniture, stock of cattle, and farm utensils of every kind, the property of the late William Cochran, Esq. deceased. The house and lands of Lissingle and twelve acres of the lands of Drumhunny adjoining Lissingle will be set for a term of seven years from the 1st of November next. Written proposals will be received by Christopher Humphrys of Drummard and Charles Humphrys of Clareview.<br>---<br>From Leigh Saddington:<br>From Enniskillen Library.  Erne Packet Newspaper. 1810.<br>William Cochran died age 74 years at Blackheath.<br>---"

"NI1050","William got into financial difficulties.  He was made bankrupt and, eventually, his estate of Ferguslie was purchased by the Burgh of Paisley in 1748.  He had been a staunch Jacobite supporter and had been out in the '45, ie. he had taken part in the 1745 Rebellion.  (Whether his estate was 'forfeited' as a result of that or whether it was sequestered as a result of his bankruptcy is a debatable point, but it is immaterial because he lost his estate anyway.)"

"NI1177","Appointed governor of Fort William (a position his father also held) on his return to England from Canada.<br>PENINSULA ROLL CALL 1814:<br>37th (North Hampshire Regt of Foot)<br>Major George Germaine Cochrane - Landed at March 1814 and served to end of War.  Present at Bayonne.<br>---<br>Dates of Commissions:<br>Ensign 28th Foot         1793<br>Lt. Royal Glasgow Regt.  1794<br>Lt. Royal Glasgow 37th Foot   1795<br>Captain             1803<br>Major               1813<br>Lt. Colonel         1830<br>Served in Gibralter until the year 1800.<br>From 1800 to 1805 in the West Indies-Saint Vincent & Trinidad.<br>In 1812 he again served in Gibralter.<br>In 1814 he joined the army of Lord Wellington as Regimental Major of the 37th at Bayonne and was in the same Brigade with Sir John Hope, when that distinguished officer was made prisoner.<br>From 1814-1817 served in Canada.<br>In 1817 he came home to Fort William in bad health and soon retired on half pay.<br>In 1838 (having obtained the rank of Lt. Colonel in 1830 by the Brevet occassioned by the accession of William IV to the Throne) he sold out of the army.  The money obtained for his commission was lost by the Bankruptcy of the person to whom he unfortunately lent it."
"XI1181","Ashes Spread over the Pacific Ocean"
"NI1187","Lieutenant in the 39th Regiment was killed 1794 in Guadeloupe."
"NI1188","A Lieutenant in the Royal Rifle Regt, died at sea in 1797, a passenger<br>to Lisbon."

"NI1194","Although lame and blind, Hope had some musical talent and played the organ in the Episcopal Chapel at Fort William.  He had some instruction at the Blind Assylum, Edinburgh."
