"NI1297","Lived at Green Point, Gosford, and Nemingah and had a timber mill at Erin, NSW.  Francis was a very religious man.  One day he visited ho some George and was on his way home but was going the wrong way.  His grandson, John, ran after him and said Grandfather, you are going the wrong way.  To which the old man replied, God will guide me on track. John said Well Grandfather, he's put you on the wrong track this time."
"NI1306","Died as a child."
"NI1311","Possibly lived near Glasgow."
"NI1312","William was a surgeon of Fort William, Scotland."
"NI1314","Archibald was a tacksman of Leanachan."
"NI1318","Married twice & had 4 children."
"NI1319","Moved to New Zealand."
"NI1322","Married twice & no children."
"NI1326","Never married."
"NI1328","George's first and second wives were cousins.<br>The following information is from Roma Dorothy Cameron:<br>When George Cameron was a young lad, his mother died and his father Francis remarried to Lucy Jennings who had a couple of boys a few years younger than George.  The only way they could get to school was to cross a river in a small row boat.  George didn't like the other boys much and was a bit of a bully when his father and step-mother was out of sight. Nearly every day on the way to school, when they were half way across the river, George would tip them out of the boat and laugh like mad.  Every day the boys would go to school like little drowned rats.<br>In 1930 George (my Grandfather), married Cinderella Delaney nee Bennett.  My father Jack, never liked her and used to call her Old Black Tot.  Dad always said if he ever saw her he would run over with the car. (I really don't think he would have).  Cinderella used to foster kids and one day in the middle of winter my father came home from work to find 3 or 4 of the foster kids outside without jumpers or shoes.  The poor kids were freezing and this made my dad very angry.  He asked them why they weren't in by the fire keeping warm and one kid aged about 6 said Mrs. Cameron won't let us in.  Dad was fuming and took the kids inside and blew the proverbial out of her.  After that, he disliked her even more. Apparently she also drove George up the wall, but being a devoted husband, he put up with it.  Cinderella was nothing like her namesake, but was a real nag, etc.  George had a massive heart attack and died in hospital and my dad blamed her and said it was her fault that he'd had a heart attack.  This was when he tried to strangle her.<br>My father didn't get too much from his father's will, it all went to his brothers as George owned race horses and dad being a farmer had no interest in them.  I don't think my father ever went to a race meeting."
"NI1330","Had 6 children."
"NI1331","Had 5 children."
"NI1334","Priest in 1896 in Calcutta, India.  Church Missionary at Shikarpur, India 1895 - 1897.  Assistaint Chaplain to the Mission of Seaman in San Francisco, California and in Sydney, Australia 1902 - 1903.  Chaplain at Newcastle Harbour 1903 - 1907.  Priest in Charge of Wyong 1907 - 1909. Rector of Wollombi 1909 - 1912.  Rector of Raymond Terrace 1921 - 1935. Canon of Newcastle Cathedral 1924 - 1947."
"NI1339","Had 6 children."
"NI1340","Had 7 children."
"NI1344","Had 9 children."
"NI1353","Never married."
"NI1354","Died as a child."
"NI1366","Had 4 children."
"NI1367","Had 2 children."
"NI1370","Had 3 children."
"NI1424","Rev. Gapper was the second Rev. Edmund Gapper to be the rector of Charleton Adam, in Somerset, England.  B.A. from Pembroke College, Cambridge.  He was ordained curate of Keignton Manderville church in 1776  and of Charlton Adam church in 1777.  He presided in both churches as well as the one in High Ham (1803) concurrently until his death in 1809. He married Mary Barrett of High Ham in 1781. When Edmund died in 1809 he left the whole of his effects to his wife, Mary, for the purposes of raising and educating their children, except for £ 2000 which he left to his sister, Lucy. Mary Barrett and her son, William Southby, then parceled up the land and sold it. It is not known if the family had the use of the vicarage, 'The Abbey', in Charlton Adam or had to leave when he died. They sold the last of the land in 1819 when the eldest sister Lucy Anne married the Reverend William Sharpe of Charlton Mackrell. Mary Barrett and Richard's sister, Mary Sophia, moved in with the young couple at Charlynch, a tiny hamlet near the village of Spaxton in the foothills of the Quantocks west of Bridgewater.<br>---<br>Interestingly, there is an entry in the Sherborne and Yeovil Mercury newspaper from Sept, 2 1776 regarding Reverend Gapper losing his pocket book.<br>--- <br>Gapper, Edmund<br>(Male) <br>Title(s): Reverend <br>Address(es): Charlton Adam, Somerset<br>Date: 1789 <br>Occupation(s): cleric(a) <br>Subscribed to The History and Antiquities of Bristol ... Illustrated with copper-plate prints (Vol. 1), 1789, BARRETT, William. Bristol<br>Subject: topography <br>---"
"NI1425","Build home in Markham, Ontario, Canada in 1828.<br>In 1828, Richard returned to Somerset to marry his fiancée, Frances. On their return to Canada they were accompanied by his mother and sister, Mary Sophia, whose intention was to look after William Southby and his daughter Lucy, while his wife Mary had their second child, after which they would return to live with Mr. and Mrs. Sharpe in Charlynch. Unfortunately Mary Southby miscarried.<br>---<br>In 1828 Richard and his wife Frances (Fanny) moved into their newly built house 'Levellands'. Besides being farmers Richard and brother William Southby served on juries, were members of the local militia, and formed an agricultural association. They were friends with many prominent citizens including Lt. Governor Colbourne and his wife and Mr. Thorne of Thornhill.<br>The Gappers were politically and personally opposed to William Lyon Mackenzie, Samuel Lount and the Reform movement. There was a famous occasion when Richard and his brother-in-law, Edward O'Brien, physically ejected William Lyon Mackenzie from a meeting of the Agricultural Assembly. William Lyon Mackenzie accused them, falsely, of striking him. He mistakenly served William Southby, who was not present at the meeting with a writ instead of Richard.<br>There are many descriptions of the activities of the Gapper family in Canada in the Journals of Mary O'Brien. Richard returned to England around 1852. In 1853 he sold his Canadian house to William Duncan from whose family name Duncan road takes its name. It has been suggested that Richard and Fanny Gapper, and Mary Southby, left Canada as a result of his disenchantment with Canadian politics once some of Mackenzie's Reform ideas had begun to be implemented.<br>Richard and Fanny had no children.<br>---<br>Richard appears in the 1861 census thus:<br>Richard C. Gapper. Head of household. Widower. Age 56. Fundholder. Born Charlton Adam, Somerset. Address 119 Mill Lane, Batheaston (on the north fringes of Bath).<br>Richard appears again in the 1881 census:<br>Gapper, Richard C. Age 78. Head of household. Widower. Born Charlton.<br>He died of old age 7th February 1882 aged 79 at Batheaston. His niece, Lucy O'Brien, was present at his death.<br>His occupation given on the death certificate was 'Gentleman'.<br>Richard's death notice in the Bath Evening Chronicle of Friday, February 17th 1882 reads: February 7th at Batheaston, Richard Colston Gapper, Esquire, Aged 79. Son of the late Edmund Gapper, rector of Keignton, Somerset."
"NI1430","No. 343 Oxford Street, London, England."
"NI1431","Came to Canada with Thomas Cochrane and Susan Brownbill in 1836."
"NI1444","Died as a child."
"NI1692","High Sherrif of Londonderry 1709-1712"
"NI1695","Died unmarried."
"NI1697","Of Clareview."
"NI1700","Henry had been High Sheriff of Fermanagh in 1658 and 1661 and became a member of the Irish House of Parliament on April 11th, 1662 in place of William Davys who had died. He had married Phoebe Hume in 1664 and they had two daughters but no male heir. In his will he leaves his wife an income of £250 per year from his Estate which is entirely enfeoffed in trust other than the townlands of the two Goshedies (Gushedy) and Drumgrisan (Drumbristan). Failing any male heirs he leaves his entire estate to his wife and after her death to be divided among his two daughters Deborah and Mary and their heirs.<br>To his brothers Rorie Magueer (Maguire) and Philip Magueer all his horses and mares to be divided equally except his wife's saddle nag, a chestnut gelding and a horse called Swannie. Also to Rorie Maguire, Henry Blennerhassett bequeathed a case of pistols and his own sword. To his sister Marie Maguire he leaves fourteen cows. His wife Phoebe was appointed sole executrix of his will made on March 26th, 1677. The will was signed by, Sydney Hume, James Corry, John Leslie, William Johnston, Alexander Johnston, John Hume, Henry Mervyn, George Hume and Thomas Humphry.<br>During his lifetime Henry had sold Aghenma and Aghana to Thomas Humphrys of Dromard and in 1670 sold the Lack Estate to William Irvine of Ballindullagh. This family later became the Irvines of Killadeas. Their seat is now the Manor House Hotel. In 1673, Henry sold the island of Crevenishkilleu (Crevenishaughy ?) in Lough Erne to William Cosby of Drumneragh, County Fermanagh and John Archdall of Trinity College Dublin. Deborah's son Henry Cochran succeeded to the Castle."
"NI1701","Cousin of William Archdall (#782)"
"NI1702","Leonard was granted land at Crevanish, Co. Fermanagh in 1630 and was knighted 6 March1635.<br>In his will, dated three days before his death, Leonard instructed his wife that he was to be buried in the chapel beside Castle Hasset, at the foot of his father's grave.  He left one third of his lands to his wife and the other two thirds to his son Audley when he would be 21 years old.<br>His will specified that his son Audley was to be provided with £20 per year until he was fourteen and £30 annually until he was 21 years old. His sons Henry and Leonard were to be given £400 at the age of 21 and in the meantime were to receive £10 per annum until they were 12 and then £16 annually until they were 21 years old. His daughter Elizabeth was to get £600 at the age of nineteen and until then £10 per year for her maintenance. Daughters Catherine and Lucie were to be given £10 per year for their maintenance until they were 21 and £300 each when they were respectively 21 and 22 years old. If either died her portion was to be divided among the surviving daughters.<br>Deborah was given permission to remain on in Castle Hasset as long as she wished and also was given the stone house of Robert Fflackes together with the lands known as the two Hunsters belonging to it in Mr Fflackes time and Cooberron [or Coolberrow] (Gubbaroe) while also paying the rent due together with all debts owed.  If his wife be in child he or she is to receive £400. All servants wages are to be paid plus an additional £1 each.<br>James O'Moylan, Owen Mc Caffery, William Savage and Richard Spick are to be given a mourning cloak each and Peter Massie 20 shillings. The sum of eight pounds is to be given to the poor of the parish. The will was witnessed by Christopher Irving and William Savage. The Blennerhassett seal was affixed to the bottom of the will.  This was made up of concentric circles with a bleeding heart in the centre and PATIAR * DUM * POTIAR written around. The latin inscription means, I suffer until I obtain.<br>In a codicil to the will, he appoints William Hambleton of Lough Muck [near Omagh] County Tyrone and Christopher Erwin as overseers to his will and this is signed by William Savage and Robert Fflacke."
"NI1703","Educated at Cambridge without taking a degree. In the Army he was stationed as Captain at Guernsey Castle. Around 1600 he took service with the English in Ireland and in 1610 was an undertaker for the plantation of Ulster. In 1624 he was stated to own the Barony of Lurg and two proportions of Eernagh and Tullenageane in Co. Fermanagh."
"NI1704","Lived at Horsford Park, near Norwich."
"NI1712","Held a government position of trust in London, England."
"NI1713","Eldest son of Gerard.<br>Died without issue."
"NI1714","Died at the altar."
"NI1716","3rd Baronet of Luss."
"NI1718","Died without issue."
"NI1719","She and Christopher are cousins."
"NI1720","In 1610 he owned Bannaghmore"
"NI1724","Sherrif in 1622."
"NI1726","After her husband's death Deborah Blennerhassett married Rory Maguire and they had three of his children in addition to the six she had already borne to Sir Leonard Blennerhassett."
"NI1727","A distinguished naval officer."
"NI1737","Rory Maguire was part of the old Gaelic aristocracy of Fermanagh and although apparently part of the new Plantation order of things, he hankered for a return to the rule of the Maguires in Fermanagh. To achieve this it was obviously necessary to eliminate the new Plantation gentry and Rory decided to complete this in one fell swoop.  He planned either to capture or massacre the leading Fermanagh Planter families at a banquet to be held in Castle Hasset (Crevenish Castle).<br>He laid his plans carefully and on the appointed evening his unsuspecting guests arrived. On their way in a groom gave an unmistakable signal to their leader Sir William Cole, the Governor of Enniskillen that something was amiss.  He told him he would have their horses ready for them in ten minutes and should not be parted from their swords in the meantime.  Sir William had already been told to be on his guard by Brian Maguire of Tempo who had made his mind up to side with the new regime in Fermanagh. Their suspicions by now fully aroused Cole and the others determined not to stay and staying together made their way quickly to the safety of Enniskillen. T hey had had a lucky escape.<br>This massacre was intended as a preliminary to the full outbreak of the 1641 Rebellion in Fermanagh and despite its failure Rory and his men went ahead with the uprising. They set upon the local Plantation settlements and began years of destruction and death with the burning of the village of Lisnarick.  Some of the attacks on Fermanagh Planters are chronicled in the 1641 Depositions made soon after and preserved in the library of Trinity College Dublin.<br>Rory Maguire was the brother of Lord Maguire who had been captured attempting to seize Dublin Castle on October 23rd, 1641. He was later executed at Tyburn in London. Rory led the rebellion in Fermanagh and was one of the most prominent individuals in the campaign until his death in 1648. Before the rebellion began he enlisted the support of the O'Flanagans and O'Husseys of Magheraboy among many others of the old Gaelic families throughout Fermanagh.<br>After the burning of Lisnarick, Rory captured Neckarney (Irvinestown) and his brother-in-law, Richard Nugent along with the Mc Caffreys took Archdalestown. The Leitrim Mc Laughlins and Mc Murrays seized Garrison. This village had been the site of the first barrack in Fermanagh which had been erected by Sir John Dunbar. Before it became a garrison and later adopted the name Garrison this pleasant spot on the shores of Lough Melvin was known as Killawhoe according to a note in the Montgomery Mss. This is disputed by Pat Mc Guinness the author of a recent history of Garrison who believes that Killawhoe is actually nearby Kilcoo in County Leitrim.<br>In the end Rory Maguire was killed leading an attack at Jamestown, near Carrick-on-Shannon on November 13th, 1648. Another chapter had closed in the story of what has now become known as Crevenish Castle rather than Castle Hasset."
"NI1746","Made Baronet of Nova Scotia, 30 Aug 1625.  In 1632, a criminal process was<br>raised against him for the abduction of his sister-in-law, Katherine Graham.<br>He was in absence fugitated and excommunicated.<br>1st Baronet of Luss."
"NI1754","5th Baronet of Luss."
"NI1756","Of Fosford, Co. Mayo."
"DI1756","Battle of Aughram"
"NI1766","Name possibly Julian or Julie"
"NI1768","High Sheriff of Tyrone (1686)"
"NI1770","Cousin of Pheobe Hume (#711).<br>Fled the country during the Williamite Wars and Castle Archdale was burnt<br>in 1689.<br>A Captain William Archdale appears in the Inrolements (sic) of the Adjucations in favour of 1649 Officers.<br>Records prove he was in possession of his father's estate in April 1659/60.  Archdeacon John Archdale and his wife Elizabeth resigned to their nephew, William of Castle Archdale, all the lands of Drumgarragh etc., at Ballycassidy, which had been rented from William Archdale's father...<br>Described as one who delighted much in planting, building and improving, free from presumption or pride, kinder and merciful to his followers. He purchased Kiltierney, once a grange of the Abbey of Asharoc, Ballyshannon; the church lands of Devenish except the island itself; Killadeas and Lisgoole.  High Sherrif of Fermanagh 1667 and 1692 and was also a JP; and in that capacity he specially encouraged a certain Mulmurry O'Hossa to pursue and slay two notorious ruffians named Daniel O'Roarty and James O'Loughnane, who had become the terror of the neighbourhood.  Accordingly, on July 5th 1670 O'Hossa brought the outlaws' heads, all dripping with gore, into the Court Hose at Enniskillen, where several Justices, including William Archdale, were assembled in open court.  The two heads were set up, as a gruesome warning, in the town of Enniskillen (see Mr. Prendergast's paper on 'The Tory War of Ulster', in the Quarterly Journal of Kilkenny Architechtural Society. 1867).<br>He fled the country in 1688 with his family; old Castle Archdale was finally destroyed in his absence.  He returned with the Williamite succession and established a new home near the present Castle Archdale. Purchased Collidaises (Killadeas) and a handsome estate from William Wallace in 1689.  Purchased from Henry Broomer, of Dublin, the lands of Rahall and Cullenenesse in the parish of Derryvullen for £125.  In 1677, he purchased from Lord Folliott the quarter of land of Ballyhannah, Co Donegal.  Rented 8 quarters of land of Devenish (except Deveish Island) in 1697.  Died intestate."
"NI1771","No children.  Died unmarried.<br>Received his early education under Mr. Wade at Trillick.  For dates of entrance and graduation from TCD see Burtchaell and Sadlier's Alumni Dublinences.<br>Entered Trinity College, Dublin as a Pensioner on 22 Oct 1701.  He graduated BA from Tritity College in 1705.<br>Commissioned as Lt. Col. in a Militia Regiment of Dragoons, under the command of Colonel Irvine in 1708; and on Nov 2nd 1715 he himself was appointed Colonel of a Dragoon Regiment in Fermanagh.  High Sheriff of Fermanagh in 1714.<br>Mervyn inherited the family estates after his father's death in 1722.  He ran up heavy debts which were not paid off until many years later.  He died intestate."
"NI1772","Heiress of her brother Edward.  She accompanied her parents to England in 1688; so she was at least 36 years old at the time of her marriage in 1724 to Nicholas Montgomery, of Derrygonnelly, Co Fermanagh, a descendant  of the Braidstane branch of the Norman and Scottish family of Montgomery.  By him, she had an only child Mervyn, who was born in the lifetime of his two maternal uncles.  The marriage articles are dated 22 April 1724, Angel's portion being £1500.  Through this alliance, the greater part of the Montgomery and Dunbar property in Fermanagh became merged in the Archdale estates.<br>Under his father Hugh Montgomery's will, dated 10 February 1720, Nicholas inherited the Derrygonnelly property at his mother's death; and he also in herited from his uncle, Robert Montgomery, the Church lands at Derrybrusk in the same county, according to a deed of settlement executed before his marriage."
"NI1773","Educated under Mr Wade of Trillick.  14 Jun 1712 became Fellow Commoner of Trinity College Dublin,  graduating BA in 1716.  Served as a Captain in Sir Gustavus Hulme's Regiment of Dragoons and was High Sheriff of Fermanagh in 1772.<br>In his brother's lifetime, Edward lived for a few years at Cosbytown House, in Mageraboy.<br>In connection with his second marriage, he should have received £2000 (about £175,000 at 1998 prices), but died before any of it was paid. Died intestate and without issue, a jointure of £300 a year (about £25,000 at 1998 prices)  falling to his widow.  Administration of his estate was granted to his brother-in-law, Nicholas Archdall, on 10 Mar 1728/9."
"NI1774","Nicholas Montgomery took the name and arms of Archdall in 1728, in place of his own patronymic.  (It is not meant to suggest that there was a sudden change of spelling from Archdale to Archdall in 1728, but simply that the latter spelling was generally accepted about that time. Archdale was undoubted the older form of the name, but the two spellings existed together long before Nicholas Archdall's marriage.) 1723 High Sherrif of Fermanagh.<br>1731 elected MP for Co Fermanagh on the death of Sir Gustavus Hume, Bt, a position to be held continuously by the family until 1885.  Most active in local and parliamentary affairs, he assisted in the re-organisation of the militia against the threat of French invasion and pamphleteered against union with England and for the encouragement of the linen trade and local manufacturers.  He was appointed a Colonel of a Regiment of Dragoons in Fermanagh on 17 May 1740, having previously (by Commission, dated 24 May 1723) served as Major under Colonel Willoughby.  Appointed JP for Co Meath, 22 Mar 1745.  In 1748, he purchased an estate at Mount Eccles, Dublin, the value of which at the time, as he himself estimated, was about £300 a year.<br>On Angel's death, Nicholas re-married and moved with his new wife to his Mount Eccles property in Dublin which was on the north-east side of North Great George St.  On his death the Archdale estates passed to his only child, Mervyn Archdall, who was 38 at the time."
"NI1775","He attended the Dungannon Convention of 1782 which among other things resolved to work for the repeal of Poyning's Law (which stated that all laws passed in England applied equally to Ireland) and the relaxation of the Penal Laws against Roman Catholics.  He was elected a member of the Committee of the Volunteers.  He retired from politics in 1800 and died in 1813."
"NI1777","Only 16 years old at the date of her marriage, she was left a widow the same year."
"NI1780","4th Earl of Montrose."
"NI1781","First Marquess of Montrose."
"NI1782","2nd Baronet of Luss."
"NI1783","Earl of Kincardine."
"NI1784","2nd Marquess of Montrose"
"NI1785","3rd Marquess of Montrose."
"NI1787","Of Kilmaronock.  Joint Keeper of the Signet 1711.  Brother of John, 2nd Earl<br>of Dundonald."
"NI1788","Will proved 1779."
"NI1796","Of Dromard. He and Martha are cousins."
"NI1810","Also had 4 boys."
"XI1811","Plot C Row 10 Grave 23"
"NI1814","Had 8 children."
"NI1830","From page 540, volume, NEBRASKA, pub. 1912 Chicago, Alden Pub. Co.:<br>James Harvey Lewin, owner and operator of a fine grain and fruit farm, is one of the very early settlers of Custer county and in his earlier years there passed through the many trials and discouragements incident to pioneer life. He met these troubles undaunted and has triumphed over them to a gratifying degree. For the first three years of his residence in the state the grasshoppers ate most of his crops, for several years he was the victim of severe drouth, and he also suffered much from the destruction of crops by hail storms.<br>Mr. Lewin was born in Louisa county, Iowa, December 4, 1848, eldest of the seven children of John A. and Lucretia (Blake) Lewin. The father was of English parentage and born in the Shenandoah valley, Virginia. He served in the Civil war as a member of Company G, Third Iowa Infantry, and died in Andersonville prison. The mother, also of English extraction, born in Zanesville, Ohio, died in Elko, Nevada, July 12, 1884, while en route for California.<br>Mr. Lewin grew to manhood on the home farm in Iowa, receiving his education in local schools, and later engaged in farming. He was married in Warren county, Iowa, March 26, 1874, to Miss Julia Guthrie, a native of Frankfort, Kentucky, and soon afterward they came west, making their first home in Adams county, Nebraska, and three years later, in the spring of 1878, coming on to Custer county. Mr. Lewin had hunted and trapped over part of the state and was very favorably impressed with the prospects for obtaining good land in Custer county, deciding to locate there. He secured a homestead of one hundred and sixty acres of land and a timber claim of the same size adjoining, on section twenty-four, township nineteen, range seventeen, in Woods Park, which was the home place for a number of years. He did much to help in the early upbuilding and development of the region and became successful in his personal enterprises. He helped organize school district number six, serving as the first director of the school board. In 1892 he sold out and purchased two hundred acres of land on section nineteen, range seventeen, which is now the home place, being well improved and equipped for raising grain and fruit. He has found this line of farming very satisfactory and is one of the proserous [sic] men of the community.<br>Mr. and Mrs. Lewin have six children living: Newton A., of Arcadia, is married and has one child; Forest E., of Custer county, has four children; Lillian Edna, married Ernest Fuller, of Antelope county, Nebraska, and they have two children; Kate, wife of Bert Clark, of Comstock, has one child; William, of Comstock., and Nellie, at home. Mrs. Lewin's father, William P. Guthrie, was born in Shelbyville, Kentucky, and served during the civil war as a captain of Company G, Thirty-fourth Iowa Volunteer Infantry. He located in Nebraska in 1877, in 1878, located in Custer county, and now is a resident of Frontier county. He married Susan Hodges, a native of Kentucky, who died on the homestead in Custer county in 1882. Mrs. Lewin has a brother, James Guthrie, in Sargent; a sister, Mrs. Wallace Dye, in Custer county, and another brother, William B., of Broken Bow.<br>---<br>Mr. and Mrs. J.H. Lewin, who live a few miles north of Comstock, Nebraska, celebrate their 50th of Golden Wedding anniversary on March 26th, 1924.  Their younged daughter, Mrs. Ray Pool had her 25th birthday that same day.  Present were Mr. and Mrs. M.E. ? of Arcadia, Nebraska, Mr. and Mrs. W.W. Dye and Mr. and Mrs. C.D. Dye, Mr. and Mrs. Ray Pool, Bert Clark and Mr. and Mrs. Joe Woracek.<br>---<br>Living in Sargent, NE in 1886 according to the Nebraska State Gazetteer and Business Directory."
"NI1835","Newton was the first white child born in Custer County.<br>Had 3 children."
"NI1837","He had 3 children.<br>A veteran of WWI, he homesteaded 440 acres in Craig, Moffat County, Colorado and struck oil.<br>Had 3 children."
"NI1855","William P. Guthrie was born in Shelbyville, Kentucky.  He served during the Civil War as a Captain of Company G, 34th Iowa Volunteer Infantry. In 1877, he located as a true pioneer in Nebraska, and in 1878 he located in Custer County, Nebraska.  His wife was Susan Hodges, who was also a native of Kentucky.  She died in 1882 on their homestead in Custer County.  She died in 1882 on the homestead in Custer County.  Their children included James Guthrie who in 1912 resided in Sargent, Nebraska, and Mrs. Wallace Dye also in Custer County then, and another brother (half brother) was William E. Hodges who in 1912 lived at Broken Bow, Nebraska, and also Mrs. Julia Guthrie Lewin, who married on March 26, 1874 in Warren County, Iowa to James Harvey Lewin and they came to Custer County in spring of 1878 from Adams County, Nebraska.  They had six living children in 1912.  William P. Guthrie, 88, of Comstock, Nebraska, died first week of August, 1921, while at the home of relatives in Ord, Nebraska.<br>---<br>Roster and Record of Iowa Soldiers in the War of Rebellion<br>Published 1910<br>William P. Guthrie<br>Claimed residence: Hartford<br>Enlist Date: 11 Aug 1862<br>Enlist Rank: Captain<br>Enlist Age: 29<br>Served Iowa Commission B Co. 34th Inf Reg. IA.<br>Resigned at St. Louis, MO on 30 Jan 1863<br>---<br>3-014.<br>ACT OF FEBRUARY 6, 1907.<br>DECLARATION FOR PENSION<br>THE PENSION CERTIFICATE SHOULD NOT BE FORWARDED WITH THE APPLICATION.<br>State of Nebraska<br>County of Frontier<br>On this 20th day of April, A.D. one thousand nine hundred and eight, personally appeared before me, a County Clerk within and for the county and State aforesaid, William P. Guthrie, who, being duly sworn according to law, declares that he is 75 years of age, and a resident of Havana, county of Fronier, State of Nebraska; and that he is the identical person who was ENROLLED at Hartford, Iowa under the name of William P. Guthrie, on the 10 day of August, 1862 as a private, in afterwards elected Captain of company B in the service of the United States, in the Civil war, and was HONORABLY DISCHARGED at St. Louis Mo., on the 30 day of January, 1863<br>That he also served<br>That he was not employed in the military or naval service of the United States otherwise than as stated above. That his personal description at enlistment was as follows:  Height, 5 feet 10 inches;  complexion, light;  color of eyes, blue;  color of hair,  brown;  that his occupation was farmer;  that he was born 19th April, 1833, at Versailes Kentucky.<br>That his several places of residence since leaving the service have been as follows:<br>in Iowa until the fall of 1877<br>has resided in the State of Nebraska since that time<br>That he is a pensioner.  That he has heretofore applied for pension<br>Number 661017<br>That he makes his declaration for the purpose of being placed on the pension roll of the United States under the provisions of the act of February 6, 1907.<br>That his post-office address is Havana, county of Fronier, State of Nebraska<br>Signed William P. Guthrie"
"NI1859","Died in childhood."
"NI1860","Moved to Frontier Co, Nebraska in 1901 by covered wagon."
"NI1862","Cora became interested in Christian Science after her husband had a healing of stomach ulcers.  Se took instruction from an authorized teacher of Christian Science in 1903 in Omaha, Nebraska.  She became a practitioner and was known for her healing work through prayer."
"NI1868","In the early 1860's he and his father moved to Fayette Co, Iowa, where he lived until he was 21.  At that time he took a homestead in Longwood Co, Nebraska, where he met Cora Guthrie.<br>After marrying, he bought the Guthrie homestead which joined his property and he obtained a timber claim.  This gave him 480 acres.  He farmed until 1913 when he retired.  His son operated the farm after that."
"NI1869","Flora was born in Longwood, near Comstock.  She attended rural schools in the area.  Flora attended business school in Ord, and later worked in the Comstock Bank.  She was a member of the Christian Science Church.<br>She died at Valle Vista Manor at 94 years of age.  Flora had been ill for a long time.  Grave side services were conducted at the Judith Gap Cemetary in Judith Gap, Montana."
"NI1870","He was raised on the farm near Comstock, Nebraska that had been homesteaded by his grandfather and father.  He lived almost his entire life on the farm which he actively farmed for 46 years.<br>He died at 93 years of age.  Clint died at the Howard County Hospital. He had been a resident of the Greeley Rese Home in Greeley, Nebraska after suffering a stroke about two weeks prior.  Services were held at the Ord memorial Chapel and burial was at the Douglas Grove Cemetary in Comstock."
"NI1871","C.R. homesteaded near Depot Bay, OR in 1906.  He came to Montana in 1908, settling in Judith Gap. In November 1908 he returned to Nebraska to marry Flora Dye.  They returned to Judith Gap on the first through passenger train from Kansas City to Seattle on the Great Northern Railroad.  <br>C.R. Stone was one of the first pioneers in Judith Gap.  He has earlier established a small store at the Milwaukee U-Bet Station in June of 1908. When the store was built on the newly purchased lots of Judith Gap he moved and operated a store and restaurant with his sister, Nettie N. Stone (Haynes), later wife of George Haynes. The store still stands today across from the Legion building. <br>He and his brother-in-law, George S. Haynes established the 1st National Bank in 1916, which they operated until it was sold in 1949.<br>After the bank and hardware store had been sold, C.R.'s chief interest was in ranching which included the old Bower Ranch west of Judith Gap.  He was also active in the stock market."
"NI1873","Andrew was a very religious.  He made his living by farming.  He was a Union<br>Captain in the Civil War."
"NI1875","After her mother's death, Ella was raised by Mr. and Mrs. Adelia M. Carter<br>(friends of the family) of Kasata, Minnesota."
"NI1888","M.P. for Strabane 1695<br>M.P. for Tyrone 1703-1717"
"NI1897","M.P. Co. Fermanagh 1692-1718, High Sherriff 1671."
"NI1898","Resided in Maderston."
"NI1903","Resided in Manderston."
"NI1904","Resided in Polworth."
"NI1905","Lord Provost of Edinburg (1593)."
"NI1906","Lord Berwick, Earl of Dunbar."
"NI1910","Daughter of the Earl of Drogheda."
"NI1911","Killed by a fall from his horse."
"NI1914","Assumed the surname of Hume."
"NI1920","2nd Earl of Arran and 1st Duke of Chatelherault."
"NI1921","1st Baron of Paisley.<br>3rd Son of James Hamilton."
"NI1926","Only daughter of George, 6th Lord of Seton."
"NI1927","1st Earl of Abercorn."
"NI1928","Gov. of Ulster."
"NI1929","Eldest daughter of Thomas, 5th Lord Boyd"
"NI1930","Lord Strabane."
"NI1931","Christened: John Thomas.  Came to Canada with parents in 1836 (To Quebec from St. Hiliers, Jersey).<br>---<br>Baptism Certificate:<br>St. Pancras<br>John Thomas Charles Son of Thomas and Susan Sarah Cochrane, Arlington Street baptized August 30th, 1818.<br>This extract was made this 30th day of August, 1818.<br>Moffit Curate"
"NI1932","Taken prisoner in the rebellion of 1641 by Sir Phelim O'Neile, when he burnt<br>and destroyed the castle of Strabane.  She afterwards married him."
"NI1936","1st Viscount Boyne."
"NI1938","A Captain in the Irish army, privy-counsellor, and governor of the city and<br>county of Londonderry."
"NI1951","Married his cousin Blanche."
"NI1953","Born at 9:45am on 25-Nov-1948.<br>Christened by Revd. Dr. Leach"
"NI1959","Created a peer of Ireland by King Charles I of England."
"NI1962","He sold his estate and came to Ireland, having obtained a grant of land in the Ulster Plantation, dated 13-Jul-1612.  He was high sheriff of Fermanagh in 1616."
"NI1963","Merchant in the parish of Backing-by-the-Tower, London.<br>Master of Abbott;s Hall, Darsham in Suffolk"
"NI1964","Born at 6pm on 4-Sep-1850"
"NI1965","Bailiff of Stafford Borough in the 1530s."
"NI1966","Served in the Revolutionary Wars and won a gold medal from the Pope in 1794.<br>Became a Major-General in 1805."
"NI1969","Inherited the Archdale estate in 1857.  He owned the boat Lady of the Lake which has given its name to the local festival in Irvinestown."
"NI1979","died young."
"NI1984","Born at 3am on 29-Jul-1854<br>James Bray was a sponsor at her christening."
"NI1989","Daughter of Audley Mervyn, esq. of Trelick."
"NI1994","John was called to active service during the Civil War as a member of Company G, 3rd Iowa Infantry on May 31, 1861.  While foraging for food outside camp near Vicksburg, MS, he was taken prisoner by the Confederates and sent to Andersonville Prison in Georgia on Dec 10, 1863.  He died there on or about Aug 16, 1864.<br>---<br>Notes from Ellen Lewin:<br>The records I have for John Almer Lewin, Jr. are his military records.  I was quite surprised to find that he was considered a deserter not once but twice!  The first time he was 'brought back' to his unit.  He may have deserted in order to go home to at least help with spring planting-this was fairly common I am told.  The second time, he did not desert, but was actually taken prisoner. His widow, when applying for his pension was able to find people who served with him to refute the desertion charge and his name was cleared.  I think you will find the records interesting.<br>---<br>From The History of Warren County, IA, John Almer Lewin, Jr.  written by Sheryl Lewin Ledlie (Mrs. Richard Ledlie, 2683 E Pine Ave. Des Moines, IA 503 20-9355<br> Phone 515 287-1675<br>John Almer Lewin, Jr., was born in 1820 in Indiana, the son of John Sr., and Salome Clutter Lewin. John married Lucretia Blake on February 10, 1847 at Wapello, Louisa County, IA. Lucretia was born 1828 in Zanesville OH, the daughter of Nehemiah and Elizabeth (Padgett) Blake. Mr. Blake died March 28, 1876.<br>John and Lucretia had six children as follows: 1) James Harvey Lewin b. December 4, 1848, m. March 26 1874 to Julia F. Guthrie; 2) Francis Albert Lewin b. November 23, 1850, d. September 3, 1913, m. Niaome Catherine Prante b. April 14, 1873 in Clyde, OH, d. 1937; 3)  Joseph Dudley Lewin b.  April 1, 1853 near Morning Sun, Louisa County, IA. On July 10 1892 he was married to Alice Phillips; 4) Nancy Malissa b. April 12, 1855, m. Calvin L. Graves on Dec. 1, 1872. 5) Benjamin Franklin Lewin b. March 8, 1857; John William Arthur Lewin b. Oct. 1, 1860, d. April 5, 1926.<br>John was called to the Civil War May 31, 1861 when he joined Company G., 3rd Iowa Infantry. While near Vicksburg Mississippi he was taken prisoner on Dec. 10, 1863 and sent to Andersonville Prison in Georgia. He died there on August 16 [26] 1864. When Lucretia applied for her pension, she was denied on the grounds of desertion. It was later found through fellow officer's testimony that John and other men had gone outside the boundary of the camp to forage for food and while looking for this food he was captured. Lucretia was then granted her pension.<br>Lucretia married June 29, 1872 to Salem A. Belcher. They moved to Valley Co., NE on April 7, 1874 near Longwood. Lucretia was killed  in a train accident in Elko NV on July 19, 1884, on her way home from Sacramento, CA.<br>Civil War Military Records for John Almer Lewin, Jr.<br>June 8 to Oct 31 1861  Company Muster Roll. John A. Lewin, Wagoner, Co. G,             3rd Reg. Iowa Infantry Present. Sick in Hostpital Quincy IL<br>June 24, 1861  Company Muster-in Roll. John A Lewin, Pvt. Co. G, 3rd Reg,           Iowa Infantry age 40 yrs. Muster-in date June 8, 1861.           Joined for duty, When: May 31, 1861; Where Keokuk (Lee           County IA); Period: 3 years. Pay due from enrollment.<br>Nov & Dec 1861 Company Muster Roll. John A. Lewin, Wagoner, Col G. 3rd                Reg. Iows Inf. Present<br>Mar. & Apr. 1862    Company Muster Roll, John A. Lewin, Wag. Co. G. 3rd Reg't          Iowa Inf. Present<br>May-June 1862  Company Muster Roll. John A. Lewin, Wagoner, Co. G. 3           Reg't Iowa Infantry: Absent<br>          Remarks: Sick in hospital in Mt. Vernon Ind. Left camp sick                about 25th of April 1862. Entire entry cancelled by line.<br>Sept-Oct 1862  Company Muster Roll. John A. Lewin, Pvt. Co. G, 3 Reg't                Iowa Infantry. Present.<br>          Remarks: Said Lewin is entitled to Wagoners pay from Jan      1, 1862 to June 30/62 having been mustered as teamster up        to that date.<br>Nov-Dec 1862   Company Muster Roll. John A. Lewin, Teamster, Co. G., 3                Reg't, Iowa Infantry. Present<br>Jan-Feb 1863   Company Muster Roll. John A. Lewin, Teamster, Co. G., 3                Reg't Iowa Infantry. Present<br>Mar - Apr 1863 Company Muster Roll. John A. Lewin, Teamster, Co. G., 3                Reg't, Iowa Infantry, present<br>May-Jun 1863   Company Muster Roll, John A. Lewin, Wagoneer, Co. G., 3<br>          Reg't Iowa Infantry. Present<br>Jul-Aug 1863   Company Muster Roll, John A. Lewin, Wagoner, Co. G. 3           Reg't, Iowa Infantry; Present<br>Sept-Oct 1863  Company Muster Roll, John A. Lewin, Wagoneer, Co. G. 3                Reg't, Iowa Infantry, Present<br>Regimental Descriptive Book. John A. Lewin, Co. G. 3 Reg't Iowa Infantry.<br>          Description: Age 37 years; height 5 feet 10 inches;      Complexion Light; Eyes Blue; hair Brown; Where born: Vermilion Co OH (IN)<br>          Occupation Farmer.  Remarks: Deserted Dec. 10, 1863 near      Hebron Miss.<br>Memorandum From Prisoner of War Records<br>Lewin, John A, Private, Reg't 3, State: Iowa, Co.: G.  Information obtained from: M. R. Vol. 17, Page 78.<br>Captured at:-----------Admitted to Hospital at: Andersonville, GA Aug. 26, 1864 with Scorbutus __ Ret'd. Died Aug. 26, 1864. No. 9773, Harz 587-1865<br>NOTATION: War Department, Adjutant General's Office.<br>John A. Lewin, Co. G, 3 Reg't Ia Vols.<br>Book Mark: Harz 587-1865<br>June 29, 1870<br>Was captured on or about December 8, 1863. Charges of desertion removed.<br>NOTATION: War Department, Adjutant General's Office, Washington April 5, 1871. Supposed to have died on or about August 16, 1864 at Andersonville GA while a prisoner of war.<br>John A. Lewin, Wag. Co. G, 3 Reg't Iowa Infantry<br>Appears on Returns as follows:<br>May 1862, Absent sick or wounded in Hospital down the Tenn. River.<br>June 1862 Deserted June 30 LaGrange<br>July 1862 Gained from desertion<br>Dec. 1863 Loss Dec. 10  Camp was captured by the enemy while stealing from camp without authority.<br>Descriptive List of Deserters<br>dated Dec. 31, 1863<br>John A. Lewin, Privt, Co. G, 3 Reg't Iowa Infantry<br>Deserted: When-Dec 10 1863<br>Where: From Camp<br>Remarks: This man left camp on the 10th of Dec. 1863 without permission, passed outside picket lines and was captured by the enemy as straggler.<br>Charges of desertion removed. Captured on or about Dec. 8, 1863. Supposed to have died on or about Aug. 16, 1864 at Andersonville Ga. while a prisoner of war. Harz 587-1865 A.G.O. June 21, 1865"
"NI1995","Born at 1am on 9-Jun-1856.<br>Christened by Revd. Mr. Mitchell, Rector."
"NI1996","Lucretia moved to Valley County, Nebraska in 1874.  She was killed in a train accident in Elko, Nevada on July 12, 1884, on her way home from Sacramento, CA."
"NI2000","Had 5 children."
"NI2050","From History of Warren County, IA F599<br>Joseph Dudley Lewin was born April 1, 1853, the son of John Almer Jr. and Lucretia (Blake) Lewin.  He was born near Morning Sun, Louisa Co., IA. On July 10, 1892 he was married to Alice Phillips at the home of her parents.  Alice, the daughter of John and Lydia (Rickett) Phillips was born August 2, 1868 near Swan, Warren Co., IA.<br>...<br>Joseph Dudley died of cancer of the mouth on October 7, 1917 and was buried in Black Cemetary, near Hartford, Warren Co., IA.  Alice Lewin was a member of the United Brethren Church, near Beech, IA.  She married Arthur Lewin (Joseph's brother) on March 26, 1921.  Arthur preceded Alice in death on April 5, 1926.  Alice passed away at the Burbank Hospital in Pleasantville, Marrion Co., IA. on July 5, 1946.  She also is buried in Black Cemetary."
"NI2055","Joseph helped to build the Union Pacific Railroad to California."
"NI2056","From Ellen Lewin:<br>John Almer LEWIN b. 7 August 1791 (Shenandoah County, VA) migrated to Pickaway County, OH with William Renick. John married Salome CLUTTER (b. 17 July 1791 Loudoun Co., VA). Salome's family were also with Mr. Renick, as were a number of other families. John and Salome's was the first marriage in Harrison Township, on 24 May 1810 by Squire James Denny. I have no other information on Salome (still trying to find her parents/siblings), except the names of her children, the date of her death ( Jan. 1854) and the place of her burial-Warren County, IA.<br>---<br>Mary recieved a widow's pension based upon John's service in the war of 1812<br>John Almer Lewin Sr., lost three sons in the Civil War.<br>Silas, John Jr, and Oliver.<br>John moved to Warren Co. IA using a bounty land warrant for his service in the war of 1812<br>---<br>From History of Warren County, IA F596<br>John Almer Lewin, an early Pioneer in Iowa, was born Aug 7, 1791 at Gooney Manor, near Front Royal, Sheandoah County VA. He was the sixth of eleven children of Samuel Lewin and Mabel Timartha Hunt. He is described as being six feet tall with black hair, blue eyes and fair complexion.<br>While yet a young man, John went west to Pickaway Co. OH with a party of settlers led by William Renick. In 1810, he was married to Salome Clutter of Loudoun County VA who also was a member of that group of settlers from Virginia. Their marriage was the first in Harrison Township of Pickaway County.<br>There were twelve children born to John and Salome: Samuel, Mabel Timartha, Charles C., Washington, Nancy M., Mary, John A. Jr., Silas W., Martha Jane, Joseph, Aaron F. and Oliver P.<br>During the war of 1812, John served in the 1st Regiment of Ohio Militia under Captain Pinney. His unit was captured by the British and he was still a prisoner fro some time after his year of enlistment had expired.<br>The first four children of the family were born in Ohio. It is not known if they lived in areas other than Pickaway Co. The are listed in the 1820 Census in Vigo County Indiana. A History of Vermillion Co., IN states that J. A. Lewin settled in Mound Prairie, Oakwood Township in the spring of 1822. An obituary for daughter Maria Jane says that she was born there in September 1828. According to cenus records she was the last of the five children born in Indiana.<br>Joseph and Aaron F. were born in Illinois, likely Vermillion Co. as this is where the marriages of Mabel and Samuel occurred in 1829 and 1830 respectively. It is likely the family was living in that area until they moved to Iowa in late 1833 or early 1834. While it is not recorded, it seems reasonable to assume that they would have traveled by boat down the Wabash and Ohio Rivers, the up the Mississippi to the vicinity of the future sight of Burlington, IA. It was necessary for them to camp on the Illinois side of the river for a time before they were allowed to cross over to settle the land newly acquired from the Indians. This took place in the spring of 1834. It may be that a few of the settlers were on the site of Burlington before that time, however.<br>John A. Lewin is reported to have made the shingles for the roof of the first store building in the town of Burlington.  Des Moines County, Iowa where Burlington is situated, was organized in 1834 from Wisconsin Territory. Later, in 1836, it was divided and parts of it became Lee, Van Buren, Louisa, Muscatine, and Johnson Counties. A history of Louisa County lists John A. Lewin among the first settlers in that County in Morning Sun township in 1836. The first Territorial Census taken that year lists John and his son-in-law, Riley Driskell (see separate story), in Louisa County. The First Federal Census taken in 1840 shows John, Riley as well as the Lewin sons, Samuel, Charles C. and Washington all established in the area with their own families. It was at this time that the twelfth child of John and Salome, Oliver P. was born.<br>In 1852, and  1856, as a consequence of his service in the War of 1812, John was awarded land grants of eighty acres each, in Sections 25 and 26 in Richland Township, Warren County IA, southeast of the town of Hartford.<br>Salome died in January 1854 at the age of 62 years, 6 months. She is buried in Hartford Cemetery. In 1855, John married Mary Woddell, a widow with three children.<br>Three of Lewin's sons, John A., Jr., Silas W., and Oliver P., lost their lives in the Civil war, leaving numerous family members to mourn their loss.<br>John is listed as living in the home of his son Charles in Sandyville, Warren Co, according to the 1870 Census. It was there that he departed this life on Jan. 14, 1871, and was buried beside his wife, Salome, in Hartford Cemetery.<br>F598<br>John Almer Lewin, Sr., was born Aug. 7, 1791 in Shenandoah County VA, the son of Samuel and Mabel Timartha (Hunt) Lewin. Samuel Lewin was born about 1749 and died in August of 1833 in Shenandoah Co. Va. Research by someone unknown to me and passed on to me by a mutual descendant gives the following information on the Samuel Lewin family. Samuel married Mabel Hunt who was born in Loudoun Co. VA. She died Feb. 23, 1844 in Warren Co. VA. Both  Samuel and Mabel are buried in Lewin Cemetery, Glen Echo, Va.<br>Eleven children were born to this union: 1) William b. March 18, 1784, d. Aug. 2, 1859. m. Ann Rebecca Gordon; 2) Mary; 3) Nancy m. Nov. 8, 1805 to Charles A. Collins; 4) Maria md. January 5, 1812 to John Lawson; 5) Susannah; 6) John Almer; 7) Samuel Jr.; 8) Mildred m. April 13, 1816 to Robert Rogers; 9) Percilla C. md. March 16, 1865 to Mordicai Tidball; 10) Elizabeth md. Aug. 17, 1818 to John Shipe; 11) Mabel Timartha m. June 11, 1821 to Alexander Cain. All marriages were recorded in Shenandoah County except John Almer and Percilla. Percilla was married in Warren Co., IA.<br>John Almer was married to Salome Clutter on May 24, 1810 in Pickaway Co. OH. It was printed in a county history that his marriage was the first to be recorded in that county. John was a private with the Ohio volunteers in the War of 1812. A brief  mention in the history of Vermillion Co. IN says that John Lewin and family were one of the first settlers to build a house or sorts in Oakwood Township in the spring of 1822. Another brief mention in a write up in Burlington IA history says that John Lewin helped build the first general store in Burlington. These three brief mentions in history books lead me to believe that John and Salome Lewin were true pioneers.<br>John and Salome had fourteen children as follows: 1) Samuel b. Jan. 20, 1811 in OH, m. Ann McKee: 2) William b. Nov. 5, 1811; 3) Mabel Timartha b. Aug. 11, 1813 m. Jan. 22, 1829 to William Riley Driskell; 4) Charles C., d. Aug. 10 1890, buried at Hartford IA; 5) Washington, b. March 11, 1818, m. Sept. 7, 1841 to Lucinda Jane Woods; 6) Nancy M., b. Feb. 16, 1820, m. Oct. 9, 1859 to Cyrus O. Whetzel; 7) Mary, b. Mar. 12, 1822, d. July 14, 1896 in Benton Harbor, MI.  m.<br> Sept. 23, 1841 to James F. Higbee,  8) John Almer, Jr.; 9) Silas W. b. Aug 25,  1826, d.  Jan. 28, 1862 in Missouri during the Civil War, m. Aug. 18, 1853 to Eliza Davis; 10) Mariah Jane b. Sept 3, 1828, d. April 19, 1917, m. Nov. 18, 1847 to  Silas Hamilton. The Hamiltons were residents of White Breast Township in this county; 11) Joseph P., b. March 16, 1831, d. April 1918 and buried at Hartford Cemetery. He married three times; 12) Aaron Foster b. Feb. 13, 1833, md. March 13, 1856 to Olive R. Whetzel. both are buried at Hartford IA; 13) Oliver Commodore Perry (Doolittle) b. July 13, 1836, d. Jan. 8, 1862 in Missouri during the Civil War. On Dec. 6, 1855 me married Sabra S. Whetzel. After the death of Oliver, Sabra married Washington Lewin on Apr. 24, 1866; 14) Gerusha, m. to a man by the surname Newell. This child of John and Salome has not been found in any official records by me, but was recalled by two different family sources.<br>John and Salome lived southeast of Hartford from about 1854 until Salome died on January 15, 1854. She is buried in Hartford Cemetery. John remarried May 28, 1855 to Mary Waddle. John and Mary had one daughter, Sarah Priscilla b. Feb. 23, 1856. John died January 12, 1871 an is buried in Hartford Cemetery. Mary died July 27, 1888.to have died on or about Aug. 16, 1864 at Andersonville Ga. while a prisoner of war. Harz 587-1865 A.G.O. June 21, 1865"
"XI2063","unmarked grave"
"NI2067","Cyrus served in the 10th Iowa Vol. Co. G.  He was age 25 at the time of his enrollement and was discharged in 1865 at Little Rock, Arkansas."
"NI2070","Died in battle during the Civil War in Missouri."
"NI2080","During the Civil War, Oliver enlisted Aug 29, 1861 in the 10th Iowa Infantry, Company G.  He was killed in battle at Roan's Tan Yard, Rudolph County, MO on Jan 8 1862.<br>The following is taken from the  Official Records of the War of Rebellion, published by the US Government of correspondence between the officers during the actual battles. These letters deal with the battle at Roan's Tan Yard in Silver Creek, MO, and make for some very interesting reading. Thanks to Mike Ruddy for sharing this information with me.<br>JANUARY 8, 1862.--Action at Roan's Tan-Yard, Silver Creek, Mo.<br> 1] Report of General Palmer OTTERVILLE, January 10, 1862. On the 8th, at 4 o'clock p.m., Majors Terrence and Hubbard, with 450 men, attacked Poindexter, with from 1,000 to 1,300 men, on Silver Creek. The enemy were totally routed, with heavy loss. Seven left dead on the field; many carried off. From 50 to 75 wounded. Our loss reported at 4 killed. The rebel camp was destroyed, and a large number of horses and arms taken. A heavy fog alone saved them from complete destruction. The number of prisoners is reported at 30. JOHN M. PALMER, Brigadier-General.<br>  2] Report of Col. Thomas J. Turner, Fifteenth Illinois Infantry HEADQUARTERS LA MINE CANTONMENT, Otterville, Mo., January 14, 1862. CAPTAIN: Major Hubbard, of the First Missouri Cavalry, returned to this place last night. He left his command on the north side of the river, opposite Booneville. Ice in the river prevented his crossing. He reports that on the 8th instant, at Silver Creek, in Howard County, he attacked the rebels, 900 strong, under command of Colonel Poindexter. After a brisk engagement, which lasted forty minutes, he completely routed the enemy. The enemy's loss was 40 killed and 60 wounded. His loss 6 killed and 19 wounded. He captured 160 horses, 60 wagons, 105 tents, 80 kegs powder, about 200 rifles and shot-guns, and a large quantity of clothing, blankets, and bed-quilts. He has in his possession 160 captured horses and 28 prisoners. The wagons, powder, and other property captured he was compelled to destroy for want of help to remove them. I directed him to bring the prisoners and horses here, unless he received orders to take them to some other point. Major Hubbard is greatly in need of ammunition, as is also all the cavalry at this post. I have been informed that requisitions have been forwarded to Saint Louis for a supply, but they have not been attended to. I would respectfully suggest that an ordnance officer be appointed for the post. I am, very respectfully, your obedient servant, THOS. J. TURNER, Colonel, Commanding Cantonment. Capt. J. C. KELTON, Assistant Adjutant-General.<br>3] Report of Major Torrence, 1st Iowa Cavalry CAMP NEAR FAYETTE, MO., January 10, 1862. GENERAL: I have the honor to report that in compliance with your order I marched my command to Booneville, and was there joined by three companies of Merrill's Horse, under Major Hunt, and at the earliest day possible crossed the Missouri River, and reached camp near Fayette on the evening of the 5th instant, when I was there joined by four companies of the First Missouri, under command of Major Hubbard, and one company of the Fourth Ohio, Captain Foster. We proceeded at once to gather information of the enemy's movements by sending scouts through different portions of this and adjoining counties. On the 7th instant reconnaissances in force were made to Glasgow, Roanoke, and surrounding country, and information received that one Colonel Poindexter was recruiting in this and other counties, and that he had his principal camp somewhere on the headwaters of Silver Creek, with a force of regularly enlisted men from 600 to 800 strong, together with an equal number of aiders and abettors of rebellion. Early upon the morning of the 8th instant we moved out of camp with 500 mounted men in search of their camp, and marched to Roanoke, 15 miles distant, and then in the direction of Silver Creek. When within 4 miles of where the camp was reported to be the column was halted, and the following disposition made of our forces: To Major Hunt was assigned the command of that portion of his forces armed with carbines, and with Major Hubbard's command and Captain Foster's company to  form the advance of the column, to attack the camp, draw their fire, and reply with carbines, when the First Iowa and a portion of Merrill's Horse were to charge upon the camp, mounted, if possible, and if not practicable charge with revolver and saber on foot. To Lieutenant Dustin, of Company F, First Iowa, was assigned the advance guard, supported by Lieutenant Burrows, First Missouri. All being in readiness the column moved forward rapidly, the advance guard driving the enemy's pickets and rushing to the entrance of the camp. The column followed soon after, dismounted, and drew the enemy's fire. They were in a strong position, being protected by ravines, thick underbrush, and timber. Their volley was promptly answered by our forces pouring in a galling fire. Three companies of the First Iowa and a part of a company of Merrill's Horse were then ordered forward to charge the camp, which was promptly done. The enemy were now thrown into confusion and soon began to retreat, leaving horses, guns, together with camp and garrison equipage. It was a complete rout, as the appearance of the camp fully attested. Two companies from the rear were ordered to cut off their retreat, but the darkness and heavy fog, together with the thick underbrush, rendered it<br> impossible. To avoid surprise and to be able to move all our forces forward an order was given to destroy the camp and look up dead and wounded. This was soon accomplished, and the darkness forbidding further pursuit, the whole command was then moved to camp, 23 miles distant. The prompt action of the troops throughout is worthy of the highest praise. Lieutenant Dustin is worthy of honorable mention for his gallant conduct in leading the advance guard; also Major Hunt, of Merrill's Horse; Captains Clinton and Mondell, of the First Missouri, for their gallant and cool bearing during the entire action. The loss of the enemy cannot be actually ascertained, but from the most reliable information their loss in killed and wounded cannot be less than 80 to 100. Yours, most obediently, W. M. G. TORRENCE, Major, First Battalion, First Iowa Cavalry. Brigadier-General Pope., Otterille, Mo.<br>  4] Report of Col. Lewis Merrill, Second Missouri Cavalry HEADQUARTERS MERRILL'S HORSE: Columbia, Mo., January 10, 1862. CAPTAIN: I have the honor to report that on the night of Sunday, the 5th, nearly at daylight, I received a dispatch from Colonel Birge (at Sturgeon), stating that a party of some 300 or 400 rebels had camped that night at Renick, and were to move next morning to Roanoke, some 12 or 15 miles from there, with the object of crossing the river at Arrow Rock or Brunswick, and stating that he would attempt to overtake them by daylight of the 6th, and requesting me to co-operate. Not approving the plan proposed for me by Colonel Birge, I sent Lieutenant-Colonel Shaffer, with all the men I could spare, to go by way of Fayette and thence north towards Roanoke and cut off the retreat of the enemy, should Colonel Birge's command not succeed in overtaking him at Renick. Colonel Birge, I understand, went to Renick, and not finding the enemy, returned to Sturgeon the same day. Lieutenant-Colo-nel Shaffer reached Fayette late the night of the 6th, and there found a large cavalry force, consisting of detachments from the First Missouri Cavalry, under command of Major Hubbard, First Iowa Cavalry, under Major Torrence, and Merrill's Horse, under Major Hunt. He then learned during the night that the enemy, variously estimated at from 1,300 to 2,500, were encamped on Smith s farm, about o miles from Roanoke. At the same time he received information that the remains of the command of Colonel Dorsey, which had been engaged in the Mount Zion fight, was then marching to attack me at Columbia. I had only part of one company left when Colonel Shaffer left me, and he knew that part of that would be sent to Jefferson City<br>  to escort the provision train. Early next morning he sent the command of Major Hubbard, which he had found at Fayette, re-enforced by one company of his own   command, to find the enemy's camp, and returned at once to Columbia with the rest of his command. Major Hubbard found the enemy's camp about 14 miles northwest of Fayette about 3 o'clock p.m., and immediately attacked them, routing them completely and taking possession of their camp, which he entirely destroyed. I have no official reports of the engagement from the part of my regiment engaged, and I presume before this Major Hubbard's reports have been received. The loss of my regiment was 2 killed and 3 wounded. The enemy's loss is not positively reported, but 5 are known to have been killed and 14 taken prisoners. This is only what is certainly known. Capt. J. B. Watson, of the rebel army (and believed to have been concerned in the Magi burning), now on recruiting service near here, was captured, with two of his men, to-day by a part of my command. I have the honor to be, sir, very respectfully, your obedient servant, LEWIS MERRILL, Colonel, Commanding Merrill's Horse. Capt. J. C. KELTON, Assistant Adjutant-General."
"NI2128","Moved to Shenendoah County, Virginia.<br>Shenendoah County changed to Warren County in 1836."
"NI2143","Mary was a widow with 3 children from a previous marriage."
"NI2184","Jean lived in the Parish of St. Johns, Berkley until 1750, managing her plantation of 534 acres of rice and indigo.<br>- The Huguenots of Colonial South Carolina page 24, 155"
"NI2185","One of the original Huguenot emigres to South Carolina.<br>- The Huguenots of Colonial South Carolina page 24, 155"
"NI2199","William Floyd Chancellor fought as a private in Company A 14th Regiment, Georgia Infantry during the War For Southern Independence. He fought in many battles including the battles of Williamsburg, Seven Pines, Mechanicsville, Gaines' Mill, Frazier's Farm and Malvern Hill-which ended the seven days fight around Richmond. He also fought in the Battle of Cedar Run under Stonewall Jackson. William was wounded several times. His name appears on a List of Prisoners of War belonging to the Army of Northern Virginia, who have been this day surrendered by General Robert E. Lee, C.S.A., commanding said Army to Lieut. Genl. U.S. Grant, commanding Armies of the United States, done at Appomattox Court House, Virginia, April 9. 1865. We have many letters William wrote the woman who eventually became his wife, his cousin, Q. Elizabeth Allen. Here are two such letters, exactly as he wrote them.<br>---<br>Camp Near Orange Va Sept 27 1863<br>Dear Cousin according to promise I write you a few lines to let you know that I am still in the land of the living and emjoying good health and hoping you will be enjoying the same great gods blessings. I have not any news of interest to write you. I arrived here last Wednesday evening. My rgt was on the march when I got to it. There was a bitter (little?) fight here the Thursday before I got here was the reason that they were on the march but we have got in camp now I think we will be here a good while before we leave I was six days on my way a coming I had very good luck in getting my boxes through I never lost or broke anything at all. Missy I have not had the chance of going to see Gillam (NOTE: Gilliam was Elizabeth's brother) yet. His camp is ten miles from me I want to go & see him as soon as possible Missy I had to one thing yesterday which I did not like There was a man in our Rgt shot to death with musketry* There was ten of us shot at him five with blank cartridges and five with ball cartridges I did not know whether there was a ball in my gun but there was five balls through his breast. Poor fellow was due his death he has deserted twice in the face of the enemy and tried to go home once he was the first Georgian that was ever shot in this army and I hope the last you must write soon as you get these words and let me know how are I hope you will think of me and write soon I can not write more at this time I remain your Loving Cousin as ever<br>*The young man referred to in this letter was Private Roe Dickson, who although proclaimed his innocence died bravely and is buried somewhere near Orange VA.<br>Nov the 1st 1863<br>Dear Cousin Once more I seat myself to write you a few lines to let you that I am well and enjoying good health hope these few lines may find you enjoying the same gods blessing. Missy your letter was received the 29th of last month and was read with the greatest of pleasure. I had given up that you was not going to write at all. You wrote to me for a ballet of the bonny blue flag I have not got the song now but I will send it as soon as I can get it. I am going to send to Richmond for one of the books the first chance that I have I will be sure and send it for I like to be spoken well of by the girls. Missy I have no news to write of interest at the present You said that you hoped I would not forget the pretty looks and beaut. I am sure that I will never forget pretty loks if it be ever so long before I see her again. Dear Cousin I have been to see Gillam twice and failed each time but I saw one of his cousin------(?) the boys in his company said he was well. I was very sorry that I did not get to see him for my own part and more so on account of you. Missy I would have written to you sooner but wanted to see Gillam before I wrote. Missy I reckon you will think there is a good deal of differeence between the writing above and this below but it is because I got a new pen. Missy I think I could have enjoyed myself very well with you on your trip after muscadines. At least I have spent a few days with you with as much pleasure as I ever did with anyone. Missy you wrote who it was that I helped to shoot his name was Romelous Dickson he was from Wilkerson County Georgia. It is nearly dark now and I will quit for the night & see what news there will be in camps tomorrow. No news yet only we are looking to move shortly we will go back 3 or 4 miles & put up winter quarters we are drawing winter clothes this morning------Rgt has gone back near Culpepper (?) Court House & are putting up winter quarters there Missy I want you to send me the ballet of Dixie Land the same words that you & Mary sung at grand Pas if you will, you will oblige me very much. The reason that I did not get to see Gillum was the first time that I went over there his regt was on picket the second time he had moved into winter quarters some 4 or 5 miles from his original camp. Missy you must excuse the bad writing & speling for I have a very bad chance to write here Tell Mary that I shall not write any more to her untill she writes to me Nothing more at this time Write soon & write all the news concerning the family give my best respects to all the family connection Yours Rec William F Chancely<br>William Floyd Chancellor died at his home in Macon, GA at the age of 81 of influenza on 8 March 1923."
"NI2214","WM. R. BROWN, carpenter and farmer, residence west side of Sherman avenue, north of Elm. He was born in Indiana in 1836, marrying in 1859 Miss Margaret L. Lewin. They have six children, named respectively, Charles O., James M., Mary, Bertie A., Mabel A. and Margaret E. From 1854 to 1862 he followed carpentering and farming, when he came to Omaha. For three years he was engaged in farming and teaming. He then returned to his trade, which he followed until 1874, working the greater part of the time in the U. P. Car shops. Since then, however, he has engaged almost exclusively in farming. Mr. Brown knows much pertaining to the history of the State."

"NI2257","Died at birth."
"NI2264","Had 10 children."
"NI2290","Christian Usselmann emigrated to America at the age of 20 on Werra which arrived in New York on October 23, 1885.  His home was listed as Selz. Kutschurgan."
"NI2291","Anna Usselmann, 19 arrived aboard the Trave which arrived in New York on October 23, 1889 there were 14 other Usselmans on the ship.  The only male listed that was old enough to be the father of Anna was Alexander age 45.  Several women are possibilties as her mother:<br>Magdalena age 40<br>Egidie age 38<br>Agathe age 36"
