"NI2334","In 1172 many English nobles rose against the King in protest of his attempt to increase his royal authority.  It was the same year that he had done penance at Arvanches in Normandy for his responsibliity for the death of Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury.  Popular feelings in England were running against King Henry.<br>It was not only the English noblemen who rebelled but the Norman Barons as well.  We need to remember that the important country of those times was Normandy, not England, and the King preferred to live in the former, the more civilized and cultured."
"NI2343","Earl of Hereford"
"NI2430","Moved by covered wagon, to near Stocksville, Nebraska in 1901.He was a farmer, and also worked on the railroad."
"NI2432","Rollie was a farmer.  He later took up barbering, and finally became a chef, working in North Plate and Ogalalla.  He was seperated from his wife and spent his last days with his brother Jesse, in Arapahoe, Nebraska."
"NI2434","He was a mason and carpenter by trade, but also did some farming in his earlier years. Most of his married life was spent in Indianola."
"NI2436","Kem spent most of his life in the farming business.  First, about 8 miles southwest of Stockville, Nebraska where he built a new Bungalow type home for his family in 1919.  The family remained there until March of 1944, when the family moved to near Wilcox, Nebraska, later moving to Ragan. and Maude retired to Alma, Nebraska until they both passed away."
"NI2438","Jesse never married, but stayed home and helped his father with farming. He served in the army during World War I.  He played the violin and accordian.  He loved to trap and hunt, and was much beloved by his many nieces and nephews.<br>When his parents died, the place was sold and he moved to Orifino, Nebraska; later to Arapahoe; and finally to Evans, Colorado, where he spent the last two years of his life with his sister Mildred."
"NI2441","Flossie loved flowers and music.  She was very artistic and much loved by all, young people especially.  She married late in life, staying home to help Jesse care for their aging parents.  After their deaths she married and made her home near Curtis, Nebraska."
"NI2443","Maudie had suffered Rheumatic fever as a child and was left with a diseased heart. She died quietly in her sleep at home."
"NI2469","Omer graduated from the 8th grade and became a farm hand.  In 1944 Omer and Wanda moved to North Platte, Nebraska, and he worked during the corn harvest season.  Then they moved to Wisconsin and he worked on a dairy farm.  In 1946 they moved back to Nebraska and in 1947 they moved to Arvada, Colorado where they made their home until Omer's death.<br>Omer worked for the Union Pacific Railroad for 35 years, retiring in 1985.  He worked in the yard, as a switchman, and the last few years on the road as a brakeman.  Omer worked two jobs most of his life, he worked at Shoenberg Dairy farm, and later owned and operated his barbershop.<br>Omer enjoyed gardening, carpentry, boating, fishing, pheasant hunting, bowling, and playing cards.  To the end Omer was a Nebraska farm boy at heart, and missed that way of life."
"NI2491","Died as a child."
"NI2573","Burnt to death the day before Mary Alice was born."
"NI2713","Died in childhood."
"NI2714","Died in childhood."
"NI2715","Died in childhood."
"NI2716","Died in childhood."
"NI2756","Never married."
"NI2760","Reverend Canon of Christ Church Cathedral at Armidale."
"NI2768","Died in childhood."
"NI2780","Died in childhood."
"NI2815","KIA in World War 2."
"NI2824","KIA in World War 2."
"NI3057","Died at age 14."
"NI3217","Inheirted land Low Neck in 1729. In 1738 pur. 100 acres Bares Thicket from Benjamin Larkin, his brother-in-law. In 1740 sold Low Neck to Benjamin Fowler. In 1749 conveyed Lucky Hole to Vachel Oley."
"NI3219","On Sept. 9, 1775 he was listed as a member of the Co. Militia of Aquila Hall, Capt. #4.<br>August 1776 census- married living in Harford lower hundred, Harford Co., Maryland.<br>Sept. 19, 1776 serving as a seaman aboard the ship Defence under Capt. George Cooke.<br>In 1783 listed living at Middle River lower hundred, Baltimore Co., Maryland.<br>About 1800 moved to Fayette Co., Pennsylvania.<br>About 1805 moved to Jefferson (now Harrison) Co., Ohio. His brother Samuel bought land there on November 10, 1804.<br>---<br>Here is an interesting story concerning the early life of Michael Conaway:<br>Michael Conaway grew to manhood on the eastern shore of the Chesapeake Bay, and became a successful sportsman, winning prizes in contests, shooting duck on the wing, etc. He was also a sailor, commanding a small boat on the bay. One day, while crossing, his boat was struck by a cyclone that carried a waterspout, sinking the frail craft, and the passengers all went down with her, except Conaway and one other man, who rose and commenced to swim. They secured an oar to ride on, but Conaway gave it to the other man, and told him to save his life, as he had a family to support. This happened about 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and they swam until 3 o'clock the next morning, when they heard a fiddle playing on a passing ship. Having shouted for help, there was a yawl with two men in her sent to their assistance, but these men told them they could not take them in, whereupon Conaway grabbed the craft, told them to take in the other man or he would sink them. They did so, leaving him, but a long rope hung from the ship, which he got hold of, and the swift motion of the ship made him skip upon the water until he was taken in. Both were so badly exhausted that they could not stand when rescued. This adventure caused Mr. Conaway to leave the water."
"NI3223","He served in the American Revolution from September of 1777 till April of 1779 in Capt. David Grier's York Co. Company in Col. Wm. Irwin's 6th Pennsylvania Battallion. He was a drummer at the battle of Brandywine, Pennsylvania (where his brother Samuel was wounded).<br>His father died when he was 2 years old and his mother moved the family to Queen Anne Co., Maryland where he still lived at the time of his enlistment. In 1787 he moved to Fayette Co., Pennsylvania and in 1817 moved to Adams Co., Ohio where he applied for a war pension on October 20, 1834. In 1839 he was living in Harrison Co, Ohio.<br>He was a methodist preacher. In 1788 he was the first Methodist preacher appointed to Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania where he served seven years; in 1792 he was in charge of the Methodist Union School in Pittsburgh (which developed into the Smithfield Avenue Congregation); he was the first circuit rider of the Methodist meetings in all of western Pennsylvania; after 1834 he moved to Harrison Co, Ohio (where his older brother Michael had settled) with his daughter Sallie (Sarah?) and joined the Bethel Methodist Church.<br>Buried on the old Conaway farm with his brother Michael and Michael's wife Elizabeth."
"NI3224","On Nov. 1, 1830 he purchased 80 acres (W 1/2 SW Sec. 33, TWP 11, Range 5) in Harrison Co, Ohio.<br>He served during the War of 1812 as a private in Capt. Allen Scroggs Co. from Harrison Co, Ohio between Sept. 21 and Nov. 30, 1812."
"NI3229","Had 14 children"
"NI3231","He was a teacher. Land records (from Jan. 1, 1833?) show he purchased 80 acres (E 1/2 SW Sec. 34, Twp. 11, Range 5) in Harrison Co, Ohio. Possibly recorded after his death?"
"NI3233","He was a teacher and a doctor. In the 1830's he helped layout part of the town of Rogersville, Ohio; from 1851-1855 and from 1857-1861 he served as the Tuscarawas Co., Ohio Coroner. He praticed medicine in Rogersville.<br>He had 1 son and 2 daughters."
"NI3235","He was a doctor. He had two daughters, one by each wife."
"NI3261","Probate: 9 Jun 1842<br>Estate inventory entered by Elijah Searcy and Francis Norvell.  One note was to Joseph Ramsey.<br>Probate: 17 Feb 1844<br>Annual settlement.<br>Probate: 4 Oct 1845<br>Appears to be final settlement.<br>---<br>His will apparently not recorded, but the first inventory of his estate took place on 9 Jun 1842. Administrators were Elijah Searcy and Francis Norvell.<br>---<br>Seth RAMSEY listed on Tax List of Woodford County, KY, 1800."
"NI3364","According to the 1856 Iowa census, he moved into the state 9 years earlier, so about 1847.<br>---<br>From the Biography of Henry C. Blake in the Portrait and Biographical Album of Louisa County, Iowa (Acme Publishing Co, Chicago, 1889):<br>..was a soldier in the War of 1812, and was at the surrender of Hull; he also participated in the late Rebellion, enlisting in the old Greybeard regiment of Iowa.  He had previously become a resident of this state, having located in Louisa County in 1847, wher his death occured on the 28th of March, 1876."
"NI3370","From the Biography of Henry C. Blake in the Portrait and Biographical Album of Louisa County, Iowa (Acme Publishing Co, Chicago, 1889):<br>Henry C. Blake, deceased, was one of the honored pioneers of Louisa County, born in Muskingum County, Ohio, July 11, 1819, and was a son of Nehemiah Elizabeth (Pagett) Blake. His father was a soldier in the War of 1812, and was at the surrender of Hull; he also participated in the late Rebellion, enlisting in the old Graybeard regiment of Iowa.  He had previously become a resident of this State, having located in Louisa County in 1847, where his death occurred on the 28th of March, 1876. Mrs. Blake departed this life when Henry was but a small child, and he was reared by Judge Chamberlain, a relative of the family, residing in Cattaraugus County, N. Y.,  where be received a liberal education. He subsequently returned to Ohio, locating in Preble County, where he became acquainted with and married Miss Ann Wilson, their union being celebrated May 18, 1843. She is a daughter of Daniel and Catherine (Rock) Wilson, natives of South Carolina. Her parents being opposed to slavery, and not wishing to rear a family under the influences of that institution, emigrated to Ohio about 1821. They were the parents of nine children, seven of whom are still living: Mary A., widow of H. C. Blake, of this sketch; John R, of Louisa County; David S.. a resident of Preble County, Ohio; William, whose home is in Louisa, County, Iowa; Rosanna, wife of A. P. Paxton, of Preble County, Ohio; Thomas, who is residing in Warren County, Iowa, and Sarah, who wedded J. M. Lee of Furnas County, Neb.  Mr. Wilson's death occurred in 1845, his wife surviving him until 1877.  She was a member of the Covenanter Church, and both were highly respected people.<br>Henry C. Blake migrated to Morning Sun, Iowa in 1845 ,and purchased a farm north of the village. On the 2nd of June, 1861, he enlisted in Company C, 1st Iowa Cavalry, participated in several engagements, and served for three years, when he was honorably discarged, at Davenport, Iowa, Sept. 9, 1864. He was a brave, true soldier, and could always be found at his post. After being mustered out of service he returned to his family in Morning Sun, broken down in health, which he never again recovered, his death occuring April 9, 1876. He was honored and revered by his comrades, who named the organization of the Grand Army Post in Morning Sun for him and his father.<br>Mr. and Mrs. Blake were the parents of three children: William E., now an attorney-at-law, of the firm of Newman & Blake, of Burlington, Iowa; Wilson W., editor of the Two Republics, of the City of Mexico, and Melville E., an attorney-at-law, also of the above-named firm. Henry C. Blake was an honored pioneer, an enterprising citizen a consistent Christian and was highly respected. His widow still resides at Morning Sun, where she has many warm friends.<br>--- <br>The Obituary of Henry Clay Blake:<br>A SAD BEREAVEMENT<br>Death of Mr. H. C. Blake, of Morning Sun<br>It becomes our sad duty today to chronicle the death of Mr. H. C. Blake, of Morning Sun, this State, which occured yesterday (Sabbath)  morning at 6:45 a.m., at the family residence, surrounded by his family and near relatives.<br>Mr. Blake's last illness was very brief, he being confined to his room but ten days and as nothing serious was apprehended, the blow came with a more saddening effect.  His death was hastened by exposure at the funeral of his father who was buried in the old church yard, Wednesday, March 29th.  He passed away quietly, without a struggle.<br>Henry Clay Blake was born July 11th, 1819, in Morgan Co, Ohio.  His early life was spent in Cattaraugus county, New York, and Preble county, Ohio.  At the latter he married to Mary Ann Wilson on the 18th of May, 1843.  They moved to Iowa in 1845, and settled on a homestead near the present town of Morning Sun, and were among the pioneers of Louisa county.  In 1853 they removed to the village which had then just been laid out.  Theirs was the first house erected on the town site.  Mr. Blake here followed the business of a retail merchant for several years with that success which honest, upright dealing always secures.  When the rebellion broke out, he enlisted in Company C, First Iowa Cavalry, and served until the regiment was mustered out of service - three years and three months.  He leaves a widow and three children - W. E. Blake, Attorney at Law, in this city; W. W. Blake, one of the proprieters of the Gazatte, and M. E. Blake, student in the Law Department of the State University at Iowa City."
"NI3372","From Portrait and Biographical Album of Des Moines County, Iowa (Acme Publishing Co, Chicago, 1888):<br>William E. Blake, a member of the law firm of Newman & Blake, 307 Jefferson street, Burlington, Iowa, is a native of Preble County, Ohio, and was born in Morning Sun, June 27, 1844. His parents were H. C. and Mary A. (Wilson) Blake, also natives of Ohio. His father's ancestors were from Maine and his mother's from South Carolina. <br>Our subject came to Iowa, with his parents, in 1845, the family settling in Louisa County, where they remained for two years, and then removed to Burlington. William E. Blake received his primary education in the common schools, and in 1864 entered Monmouth College, at Monmouth, Ill., graduating from the literary department in 1867. He then took a law course at the University of Iowa, and, graduated in June, 1869. In the following August he began practicing at Burlington, and still occupies the office where he first hung out his shingle. He formed a law partnership, Jan. 1, 1870, with judge T. W. Newman, which has continued to this date, with the exception of four years, during which time the Judge was on the bench. Mr. Blake is a Republican in politics, and a member of the Presbyterian Church. He helped to organize the Young Men's Christian Association of Burlington, of which he was President for three years, and has been a member of the Official Board since his connection with that society. <br>Mr. Blake was united in marriage at Morning Sun, Louisa Co., Iowa, July 4, 1867, with Miss Sarah Lucretia Hurd, daughter of James L. and Nancy C. Hurd. Mrs. Blake was born in Muskingum County, Ohio, and like her husband is a member of the Presbyterian Church. They are the parents of two children, both daughters--Eva W. and Lucretia B. <br>Mr. Blake's father, who was an early settler of Iowa, was a soldier in the late war, and served three years as a member of Company C, 1st Iowa Cavalry. His death occurred April 10, 1876, at Morning Sun, where his widow still resides. <br>The law firm of Newman & Blake has a wide business connection and has built up an extensive practice. Its members are able lawyers and gentlemen of high moral standing. The senior partner, Mr. T. W. Newman, had been a resident of the city since 1850, and has been Judge of the county and district courts. Mr. W. E. Blake has resided here since 1869, is thoroughly versed in his profession, and is highly esteemed as an upright Christian gentleman. <br>As a representative attorney, we are pleased to present his portrait to the readers of the Portrait and Biographical ALBUM of Des Moines County. <br>-- <br>From A Memorial and Biographical Record of Iowa (The Lewis Publishing Company, Chicago, 1896):<br>WILLIAM EDGAR BLAKE -The city of Burlington, Iowa, has many able representatives of the legal pro­ fession, and prominent among the leading members of the bar at that place is found the gentleman whose name forms the heading of this sketch. He is a member of the popular firm of Blake & Blake.<br>For his birth-place we turn to the Buck­eye State, and there, in the town of Morning Sun, June 27, 1844, he was born, his parents being Henry Clay Blake and Mary A., nee Wil­son, both natives of Ohio. He is the eldest of their family of five children, the others being as follows: Wilson .V., of the City of Mexico, editor of the Two Republics; and Mel­ville E., of the firm of Blake & Blake. The other two died in infancy. Henry Clay Blake, the father, was a farmer and merchant. He came to Iowa in the year 1845 and settled in Louisa county, where he was engaged in both merchandising and farming. During the late war he served three years as a member of Company C, First Iowa Cavalry, and his father was at the same time a member of Company B, Thirty-seventh Iowa Infantry. The latter was a veteran of the war of 1812. At the close of the Rebellion Henry C. Blake returned to his home in Iowa, Morning Sun, which he had named after his old Ohio home, and here he spent the residue of his life, dying in 1876, at the age of fifty-seven years. His widow still maintains her residence at that place. She is a member of the United Presbyterian Church, with which he also was identified. For years he figured as one of the leading citizens of his community. He served as a member of the hoard of Supervisors of the county, was a public-spirited and useful man, and for his many excellent traits of character was es­teemed by all who - knew him. Having thus referred to .the parents of Mr. Blake, we now turn for some history of his grandparents. <br>The Blakes originally came to this country from England, and Nehemiah Blake, the grandfather of our subject, was a New Eng­lander, Maine his native State. He was a man of fine physique, and, as already stated, served in both the war of I812 and the Civil war. He had a large family and lived to a good old age, being ninety at the time of his death, which occurred at the home of his son, Henry C., and ten days before his son's death. Dan­iel Wilson, the maternal grandfather of Will­iam E. Blake, was a native of South Carolina, and was a farmer. He was drowned in Ohio in 1844, while in the prime of life. <br>At the time of his father's removal to Iowa, William E. Blake was a little over a year old, and here he has since lived, having passed half a century in the Hawkeye State. He grew up in Louisa county. At Monmouth College, Monmouth, Illinois, he spent some time as a student, and then, having selected the law for his profession, entered the law department of the State University of Iowa, at Iowa City, where, in due time, he completed his course, and in June, 1869, was admitted to the bar. Since August of that year he has been engaged in the practice of his profession at Burlington, where he has won distinction. Also he has been interested in banking. He is a director in both the Merchants' National Bank, of Bur­lington, and the National State Bank, of Mount Pleasant, Iowa. <br>Mr. Blake has a beautiful home in this city, No. 902 College avenue, and, when not engrossed with business, is usually found there, happy in the society of his family. He was married July 4, 1867, to Miss Sarah Lucretia Hurd, daughter of James L. and Nancy (Green) Hurd. They have two daughters, Mrs. Eva B. Swan, wife of W. B. Swan, of Burlington, and Miss Lucretia Barnes Blake. His political views are in harmony with the principles advanced by the Republican party, to which party he has given his support ever since he was a voter. He and his family wor­ship at the Presbyterian Church, in which he is an Elder, and of which he is a liberal sup­porter."
"NI3462","born in either Indiana or Kentucky (conflicting census info)"
"NI3466","From Biographical Sketches of the Nebraska Legislature (1895, Page 111):<br>HON. J. B. CONAWAY<br>York, Nebraska<br>One of the two republican representatives from York county, the thirty-eigth district, was born September 17, 1840.  His parents, Aaron and Dorcas Conaway, are of Scotch-Irish descent and are still living.  Dr. Conaway was raised on a farm near Lacysville, O. and there received a common school education.  After the close of the Rebellion he had a thorough training at Hopedale College, which ten years later, conferred upon him the honorary degree of A.M.  He was a member of the 5th Ind. Batt. O. V. C., and helped recruit the 13th Regiment O. V. C.  His promotions were for meritorious service from the battle of the Wilderness to Five Forks, Va. He graduated from medicine and surgery from the eclectic Medical Institute in Cincinnati, O. and also from the Rush Medical College, Chicago, Ill.  Dr. Conaway is a gentleman os social disposition and pleasant manners, a ready speaker, and an earnest servant of his constituency.  He is chairman of the house special relief committee and of the standing committee on engrossed and enrolled bills.  He is also a member of the committees on railroads, insane hospitals, university and normal schools, and medical societies."
"NI3467","Obituary from The Ottumwa Courier dated July 20, 1906<br>page 4, column 3<br>THOMAS EVANS COLE PASSES<br>AWAY AT HIS HOME ON WEST<br>FOURTH STREET<br>Was Sanitary Policeman Until Last<br>Illness - Has Lived in Wapello and<br>Mahaska Counties Since Early Date<br>- The Jefferson Journal<br>  Thomas Evans Cole, and aged and respected resident of Ottumwa, passed away at his home, 805 West Fourth Street, at 4:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon.  At the time of his death Mr. Cole was 63 years of age.   He is survived by his wife, a daughter, Miss Minnie M. Cole, and two sons, W.B. and T.W. Cole.  He also leaves one brother and three sisters.  These are W.W. Cole of Chetopa, Kas., Mrs. E.A. Kirkpatrick, Winchester, Kas., Mrs. Irene Kline of Oskaloosa, Kas., and Mrs. R.E. Holloway of Cedar, Ia.<br>  Brief funeral services will be held at the family residence Saturday morning at 8:30 o'clock.  The interment will be made in the Kirkville cemetary.<br>  Dr. Julian P. Johnston of Chicago, will conduct the services.<br>  Mr. Cole was born in Marietta, Ohio, November 14, 1842.  In 1844, his family moved to Burlington in this state, and after residing there for a year or so, moved to Kirkville.  Since that time, Mr. Cole has resided in Mahaska and Wapello counties, except during a period of three years, when he made his home in Ridgeway, Missouri.<br>  He was a highly respected citizen, and was acting as a sanitary officer under the resent city administration up to the time of his illness.<br>---<br>From History of Wapello County<br>page 328<br>T.E. Cole is running a creamery on section 8, Richland Township, where he manufactures about 5,000 pounds of butter per month.  He was born in Washington County, Ohio, Nove. 14, 1842, and is a son of William and Elizabeth Cole.  His father was a stonemason by trade, which occupation he followed for many years, much of the time being spent in farming.  He is now living a retired life in Kirkville, Iowa.  The mother died in 1881.<br>The subject of this sketch came with his parents to Wapello County in 1854, and has since continued to make this his home.  He was reared upon a farm and educated in the district schools of the county.  In 1863 he enlisted in Co. C 47th Iowa Vol. Inf., served out his full time, was paid off, and discharged at Davenport, Iowa.  In 1866 he was united in marriage with Miss M. J. Picken, born in Harrison County, Ohio, Aug. 11, 1840, and the daughter of Alexander and Rachel (Conaway) Picken.  Her father now resides in Mahaska County, this state; her mother died in that county in 1856.  Mr. and Mrs. Cole are the parents of four children: Minnie M., born May 20, 1868; Ohma L., born Jan. 17, 1870, died Feb. 22, 1875; Bruner W., born Jan. 12, 1872; and Thomas W., Dec. 25, 1874.  Mr. Cole is a member of the G.A.R., and is politically a Republican.<br>---<br>From Ottumwa Courier, July 21, 1906, Page 11, column 6<br>The Cole Obsequies.<br>     The last sad rites over the remains of Thomas Evans Cole were held this morning at the family residence, 803 West Fourth street, at 8:30 o'clock.  The services were conducted by Dr. Julian P. Johnson.  Mrs. Robert Johnson and Miss Virgie Zaring sang two sacred duets.  After the services the funeral cortege proceeded to Kirkville, where the interment was made in the Kirkville cemetery."
"NI3468","Jessie's DAR Submitter ID Number: 117699"
"NI3469","Cora's DAR Submitter ID Number: 117698"
"NI3540","In 1840, 1850, 1860 census listed farming in Archer Twp., Harrison Co, Ohio. In 1861 moved to Richland Co., Ohio. At time of death had 140 acre farm in Mifflin Twp., Richland Co., Ohio and owned lots # 67 and 68 in the town of Lucas with a 24' X 24' single story<br>gothic style house.<br>---<br>Ohio-Richland Co.-Abstracts of Wills<br>Title: Abstracts of Wills, Richland Co., Ohio<br>Page: page 182 Conaway, Charles, Sr., Mifflin Twp. (RW III, p. 283) 11 October 1866 19 October 1868. To wife Frances, 72 acres of the 140 acres in Mifflin Twp.; also buildings, timber, stock, household good, furniture, chattels. To son Alonzo M., 68 acres, providing he pay $1, 443.00; $1, 413.00 already paid. Land sold at $42.00 per acre. To oldest son Benjamin, enough money for a comfortable living from sale of farm after decease of wife. To daughter, Mary Thompson, $20.00. To children John, Charles D., William, Alonzo M., Sophia A., Elizabeth Ferrell, Rachel Johnston, Susan Lovelace, and Jane Busby, residue of estate equally after decease of wife. Executors: Charles Conaway, Jacob Leiter. Witnesses: Marcus McDermott, Jacob Leiter. <br>---<br>Ohio-Richland Co.-Abstracts of Wills<br>Title: Abstracts of Wills, Richland Co., Ohio<br>Page: page 182<br>Codicil: 11 January 1868. Testor sold his farm to William and David Ballets (Author's note: This name perhaps should be Balliett.) Testor purchased lots # 66 & 67 in Lucas from Dr. N. Baker. The house was 24 feet square, one story high, Gothic style. Benjamin to continue to have his support. After decease of testor and wife, the house is to go to daughter Sophronn. Witnesses John Conaway, Jacob Leiter, A.M. Conaway."
"NI3542","He was listed on the 1850 census as idiotic. In 1870 he was living with his mother and sister, Sophia, in Monroe Twp., Richland Co., Ohio and was working as a laborer."

"NI3554","During the Civil War, he was in the 98th Ohio Volunteer Infantry. Died at the battle of Perryville."
"NI3555","He moved from Kent Co, Maryland to Warren Twp., Jefferson Co., Ohio and then to Harrison Co, Ohio. He owned parts of Sec. 16 and Sec. 17 in Stock Twp., Harrison Co, Ohio. Member of the Whig and later Republican parties. Served as Justice of the Peace for Stock Twp. for 20 years and as a Township trustee and as Director of the Infirmary. He and his wife were members of the Methodist Episcopal church. In 1810 living in Warren Twp., Jefferson Co., Ohio.<br>He served as a corporal in Capt. John Allen Scrogg's Co. (part of the Maumee Company under William H. Harrison) from Sept. 21 to Nov. 30, 1812.<br>His will was probated in 1861. The final account was most interesting. It<br>mentioned his wife Betty had died, and listed what each child received by<br>inheritance. It also showed that John A. Bingham, the prosecutor of<br>Lincoln's assassin, was one of the attorneys."
"NI3556","Her cousin Martha Hoagland married John's brother Michael."
"NI3558","Her obituary was found in the CADIZ REPUBLICAN, Thursday, June 20, 1901:<br>Death of Mrs. Whittaker<br>Mrs. Whittaker, widow of William W. Sr., formerly of North township, this<br>county, died at her home of her son, Mr. Moffett Whittaker, at Jefferson,<br>Ashtabula County, Ohio, on Friday evening, June 14, 1901, aged 84 years.<br>She was brought back to her old home for burial, and was laid to rest,<br>besides her husband in the churchyard aat Hanover, on Monday, the 17th.<br>the funeral services being conducted by Reverends Conkle and Beetham, her former pastors, in the presence of a large company of former neighbors<br>and friends. Among those present at her funeral were sons, Mr. W. K.<br>Whittaker of Ashtabula, Mr. Moffett Whittaker of Jefferson, and her<br>daughter, Mrs. Jacob Palmer, of Mansfield, Ohio."
"NI3654","Casper Clutter, was confirmed in the German village of Birkenau at the age of 14.  In 1709 he came with his father Johan Paulus Klotter, with other Palatine immigrants, down the Rhine to Rotterdam and across to London, where they are enumerated in the camps.  They came on to New York colony, but apparently the father must have died along the way, for the subsistence lists by the Govenor of NY show the widow Susanna and children.  In 1710 she (Casper's mother) remarried to Johan Poeler(Bohler) and they probably moved to upstate NY.  Casper however was old enough to be on his own, listed in the tax lists as a single man.  In 1715 he served in the NJ Militia.  He then Married Jannetje (Jane) --and they had two children baptized at the Dutch Church in Readington Township, Hunterdon Co., NJ, Paulus and Magdalena in 1724.  They apparently lived in central NJ in 1739-1742 when he had an account at Jacob Janeways store in Bound Brook, with a son old enough to to buy on his fathers account.  By July 1748 the family had moved to Plumstead Twp, Bucks Co, PA where Casper died at aged about 55 years.  He made his will 25 July 1748 and names wife Jane, adult son Paul, son Simeon, minor sons, William, Jacob, and John, and daughters Leanah, Cateren, and Elizabeth ( at least Elizabeth was under 18)."
"NI3670","Marquis of Atholl"
"NI3672","Count of Derby"
"NI3696","9th Duke of Hamilton"

"NI4272","Lived in Cadiz, Harrison Co, Ohio. Member of the Mt. Hope Methodist Episcopal Church of Stock Twp., Harrison Co, Ohio. Served as Stock Township Clerk for 4 years before being elected to two terms (1916-1920) as Recorder of Deeds for Harrison Co, Ohio. Attended Sampson Rural School. He was a teacher for 3 years and worked as a carpenter and mechanic."

"NI4373","In 1963 she was living at 2952 No. Marmora Ave. in Chicago."
"NI4374","Family tradition is that he worked in the coal mines in Irwin when he was younger.<br>In 1880 he was living at home and working as a mason;<br>from 1892 till 1907/09 he was living in Dennison, Tuscarawas Co., Ohio;<br>1900 he was living on Bank Street in Dennison and working as a conductor for the railroad;<br>1910 he was living in Fort Worth, Texas;<br>about 1912 he moved to Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois;<br>1934 he was living at 811 No. Mozart in Chicago and working as a watchman for the Coles Stove Company."
"NI4375","He worked as a metal polisher, buffer and machinist.Sometimes used the name Frank.<br>1923 he was living at 3026 5th Ave. in Chicago;<br>1943 at 3145 W. Madison in Chicago;<br>1957 at 417 No. Avers in Chicago."
"NI4392","In 1712 pur 80 acres Friendship from his brother Joseph and his wife Rebecca.<br>In 1713 sold 120 acres to Robert Cross.<br>Jan. 16, 1723 purchased 100 acres from Charles Macarty.<br>Left property Low Neck to son John. Left property Lucky Hole to son Charles. His will mentions a cousin Joseph Conaway.<br>Was a minor in 1705 when his father wrote his will.<br>---<br>From MARYLAND CALENDAR OF WILLS: Volume 6<br>Conaway (Conoway), John, planter,A. A. Co.,29th March, 1728;<br>12th Aug., 1729.<br>To son John and hrs., dwell. plan. Low Neck and personalty.<br>To son Charles and hrs., Luckey Hole.<br>To daus. Jane and Sarah and cousin Joseph, personalty.<br>To 4 child. afsd., residue of personal estate after wife's thirds are deducted.<br>Extx.: Wife Catherine.<br>Test: Mordecai Hammond, William Houchin, Sebastian Oley. 19, 805."
"NI4394","He inherited Lucky Hole in Anne Arundel Co. in 1729 from his father."
"NI4397","In 1738 he sold 100 acres called Bares Thicket to his wife's brother John Connoway."
"NI4400","Paid rent on Friendship (Surveyed Oct. 3, 1678 for Joseph Freind and Wm. Cook) located south side of the Maggoty River in Anne Arundel Co., Maryland.<br>1695- purchased 200 acres from John Bennett who had purchased it from John and Providence Reynolds, Providence being the widow of Davids (Davis?)<br>In May of 1698 sold Davis' Lot to Alexander Lumley. Purchased 80 acres Friendship from Edmund Talbot. Purchased 80 acres of a 160 acre tract from William Travelle. Left Friendship to son Joseph, other lands to sons John and James.<br>May 9, 1698 sold 200 acres on west side of Patapsco River to Alexander Sumley.<br>---<br>Abbrev: Maryland Rent Rolls<br>Title: Maryland Rent Rolls: Baltimore and Anne Arundel Counties, 1700-1707, 1705-1724<br>A Consolidation of Articles from the Maryland Historical Magazine<br>Author: Preface by Robert Barnes; Foreword by George B. Scriven<br>Publication: Genealogical Publishing Co., Inc. Baltimore 1976<br>Page: page 250- 160 acres called Friendship<br>Abbrev: Maryland-Baltimore Co.-Families 1659-1759<br>Title: Baltimore County Families 1659-1759<br>Author: Robert W. Barnes<br>Publication: Genealogical Publishing Co., Inc.<br>Page: page 128<br>Conaway, Joseph (1), d. in A.A. Co. by 4 June 1707, when his will, signed 1 May 1705, was proved; m. Jane (-----), who joined him in a sale of Davis' Lot to Alexander Lumley in May 1698; purch. 1 parcel of 80 a. of Friendship from Edmund Talbot, and 80 a. of the 160 a. tract from William Travelle; in his will he left the first parcel to son Joseph, and the second to sons John and James; had iss.: JOSEPH; JOHN; JAMES; ANNE (63:277; 122:88)<br>Abbrev: Maryland, Baltimore Co. Deeds<br>Title: Baltimore County, Maryland Deed Records Volume One 1659-1737<br>Author: John Davis<br>Publication: Heritage Books, Inc., 1996 Bowie, Maryland<br>Page: page 42<br>note records before dated Nov. 1695 and after dated May 1695.<br>John & Providence Reynolds, (said Providence widow of Davids) to John Bennett, 5,400 pounds of tobacco, said John Bennett to Joseph Connaway, 10,000 pounds of tobacco, 200 acres. Signed John Bennett. Wit: Charles Greenberry and Ballen Lambreist.<br>Abbrev: Maryland, Baltimore Co. Deeds<br>Title: Baltimore County, Maryland Deed Records Volume One 1659-1737<br>Author: John Davis<br>Publication: Heritage Books, Inc., 1996 Bowie, Maryland<br>Page: page 147<br>9 May 1698, Joseph & Jane Connaway, planter, of Anne Arundel Co., Maryland to Alexander Sumley, of Baltimore Co., Maryland, 12,000 pounds of tobacco, 200 acres... west side of Patapsco River. Signed Joseph Connaway and Jane (X) Connaway. Wit: Robert Parker and Mary (X) Stokes.<br>---<br>MARYLAND CALENDAR OF WILLS: Volume 3<br>VOLUME III.<br>Conaway, Joseph,A. A. Co.,1st May, 1705;<br>4th June, 1707.<br>To son Joseph and hrs., 80 A., Friendship bought of Edmond Taubott, on s. side Maggetie River.<br>To 2 sons John and James and hrs., 80 A., Friendship on s. side Maggetie R. bought from William Traveele; either of 2 last named sons dying during minority, deceased's portion to pass to survivrr and hrs.<br>To 3 sons afsd. and dau. Anne, personalty.<br>Test: Henry Hillyard, Daniell Hillyard, Elizabeth Hillyard.<br>12. 130."
"NI4402","1710, July 9 bought land from Richard & Zipporah Gist (100 acres at mouth of Swan Creek). Listed as being of Anne Arundel Co. and as a capenter.<br>He moved to Baltimore Co., Maryland before 1712 when he sold his share of Friendship in Anne Arundel Co. to his brother John.<br>1719, Feb 26 living in Baltimore Co. when he and wife Rebecca sold to his brother? John 100 acres at head of Swan Creek in Anne Arundel Co.<br>1720, April 11 witnessed land sale from Robert & Elizabeth Chapman to John Hall.<br>1721, June of Baltimore Co. when he witnessed the will of George Hope.<br>1724, December of Baltimore Co. when he witnessed the will of Henry Hall.<br>---<br>Abbrev: Maryland-Baltimore Co.-Families 1659-1759<br>Title: Baltimore County Families 1659-1759<br>Author: Robert W. Barnes<br>Publication: Genealogical Publishing Co., Inc.<br>Page: page 128<br>Conaway, Joseph (2), s. of Joseph (1), m. Rebecca (?) and had moved to Balto. Co. by 1712 when he sold his share of Friendship, and was still there in June 1721 and Dec. 1724 when he wit. the wills of George Hope and Henry Hall (124:60, 199)<br>Abbrev: Maryland, Baltimore Co. Deeds<br>Title: Baltimore County, Maryland Deed Records Volume One 1659-1737<br>Author: John Davis<br>Publication: Heritage Books, Inc., 1996 Bowie, Maryland<br>Page: page 223<br>9 Jul 1710, Richard & Zipporah Gist, of Baltimore Co., Maryland to Joseph Conway, carpenter, of Anne Arundel Co., Maryland, L15 paide by John Sommerland, of Anne Arundel Co., Maryland, who received L18 from Henry Hillard, of Anne Arundel Co., Maryland, 100 acres... mouth of Swan creek. Signed Richard Gist. Wit: henry Hillard and William Talbot.<br>Abbrev: Maryland, Baltimore Co. Deeds<br>Title: Baltimore County, Maryland Deed Records Volume One 1659-1737<br>Author: John Davis<br>Publication: Heritage Books, Inc., 1996 Bowie, Maryland<br>Page: page 261<br>26 Feb 1719, Joseph & Rebecca Connaway, planter, of Baltimore Co., Maryland to John Connaway, planter, of Anne Arundel Co., Maryland, L30, 100 acres... head of Swan creek. Signed Joseph Connaway. Wit: Benjamin Howard and Nicholas (X) Horner.<br>Abbrev: Maryland, Baltimore Co. Deeds<br>Title: Baltimore County, Maryland Deed Records Volume One 1659-1737<br>Author: John Davis<br>Publication: Heritage Books, Inc., 1996 Bowie, Maryland<br>Page: page 264<br>11 Apr 1720, Robert & Elizabeth Chapman, of Baltimore Co., maryland to John Hall, of same, L10, 100 acres... east side of Curtis creek. Signed Robert (X) Chapman. Wit: Joseph Connaway and John (X) Jobson."
"NI4404","Was a minor in 1705 when his father wrote his will.<br>---<br>Abbrev: Maryland-Baltimore Co.-Families 1659-1759<br>Title: Baltimore County Families 1659-1759<br>Author: Robert W. Barnes<br>Publication: Genealogical Publishing Co., Inc.<br>Page: page 128-129<br>Conaway, James (4), s. of Joseph, (1), d. in A.A. Co., by 1 march 1748, having m. on 11 May 1714 Sarah Chappell; had iss.; John (on 10 Feb. 1733/4 John Conaway of James was left prop by the will of Edward Fuller); Anna, b. 5 Sept. 1715; Joseph, b. 21 April 1718 (mentioned in the will of Edward Fuller); Charles b. 12 Aug. 1723 (inherited Narrows and Roberson's Addition from his father); James, b. 8 Jan. 1721; George, b. 6 Aug. 1725 (126:88; 210-26:30; 219-4)."
"NI4407","He inherited property in Ed Fuller's will dated Feb. 10, 1733/34."
"NI4409","He is mentioned in Ed Fuller's will dated Feb. 10, 1733/34."
"NI4411","He inherited Narrows and Roberson's Addition from his father."
"NI4412","His will mentions Aldridge, Bakers Folly, The Narrows, Point Lookout and Roberson's Addition. Mentions children George, Delilah Moss, Ara, Amelia and Vachel."
"NI4419","Before May 22,1667 he purchased 300 acres Swan Neck from Thomas Turner on May 22 it was resurveyed and was found to contain 471 acres which he later sold or rented to a Coll. (John) Hammond.<br>July 3, 1668 he and Thomas Turner sur. a 400 acre tract Addition on the north side of the Severn River which was also rented to Coll. John Hammond.<br>In 1668 he assigned back the right for 1,000 acres to George Yate.<br>In 1668 he also proved his rights for bringing James Dorsey and others to the province (Maryland, Patent Book II, 337-land office Annapolis,Md.)<br>Oct.23,1670 he collected rent on Forked Neck from John Hammond. Forked Neck was located on the south side of the Maggoty River and he owned it with Thomas Turner.<br>NOTE: Rev. War Vet. Samuel Conaway (brother of Charles and Michael) listed his birthplace as Swan Creek in Kent Co., MD in 1748/49.<br>Nov. 21, 1694 living in parish of Stepney, at Stobbunheath in the county of Middlesex, England when he granted a power of attorney to Nicholas Smith to sell two parcels of land (100 acres and 200 acres) in Maryland.<br>---<br>Abbrev: Maryland Rent Rolls<br>Title: Maryland Rent Rolls: Baltimore and Anne Arundel Counties, 1700-1707, 1705-1724<br>A Consolidation of Articles from the Maryland Historical Magazine<br>Author: Preface by Robert Barnes; Foreword by George B. Scriven<br>Publication: Genealogical Publishing Co., Inc. Baltimore 1976<br>Page: page 247- 50 acres called Forked Neck<br>page 245- 400 acres called Addition<br>page 229 & 230- 471 acres called Swan Neck<br>Abbrev: Maryland Genealogies<br>Title: Maryland Genealogies A Consolodation of Articles from the Maryland Historical Magazine Vol. 1 (of 2)<br>Author: Indexed by Thomas L. Hollowak<br>Publication: Genealogical Publishing Co., Inc. Baltimore 1980<br>Page: page 398<br>In the same year one James Connoway assigned back the 'right for 1000 acres' to George Yate, who transfers sixty acres to 'Darsy' .<br>Note:Ref to year is 1668.<br>Abbrev: Maryland Genealogies<br>Title: Maryland Genealogies A Consolodation of Articles from the Maryland Historical Magazine Vol. 1 (of 2)<br>Author: Indexed by Thomas L. Hollowak<br>Publication: Genealogical Publishing Co., Inc. Baltimore 1980<br>Page: page 410<br> In 1668 Captain James Connoway proved his rights for bringing James Dorsey and others into the province,  Patent Book, 11, 337. Land Office, Annapolis.<br>Abbrev: Maryland, Baltimore Co. Deeds<br>Title: Baltimore County, Maryland Deed Records Volume One 1659-1737<br>Author: John Davis<br>Publication: Heritage Books, Inc., 1996 Bowie, Maryland<br>Page: page 42<br>21 Nov. 1694, James Connaway, mariner, of parish of Stepney, at Stobbunheath in county of Middlesex power of attorney to Nicholas Smith, of the good ship Haperbell, now bound for Maryland, to sell 100 acres and 200 acres. Signed James Connaway. Wit: Thomas Quiter, George Phillips and Samuel Phillips Jr..<br>Abbrev: Maryland-Calendar of Wills Vol. 2<br>Title: Maryland Calendar of Wills: Volume 2<br>Page: page ? (need to look up again)<br>Tarr, John, Pogodenerton, Somerset Co., 11th May, 1695; 20th Aug., 1695.<br>To son Samuel, 200 A. (unnamed) on n. side Corker's Ck.<br>To sons Michael and John 400 A. (unnamed) equally on s. side Corker's Ck.<br>To dau. Mary, personalty.<br>To wife Mary, extx., and 4 child. afsd., residue of estate equally.<br>Overssers: Walter Read, Francis Joyce.<br>Test: Jas. Glens, Thos. Conaway, Nich. Lisney. 7. 131."
"NI4421","Adam Betz was a soldier under Napoleon Bonapart 1, the great emperor and conqueror, and with him participated in the world-famous battles of Austerlitz and Jena and a number of other engagements.  He was a farmer and came to the United States in 1844."
"NI4424","Of York County, Nebraska, USA."
"NI4425","10th Earl of Dundonald<br>Thomas Cochrane, the son of the ninth Earl of Dundonald, was born in Annsfield, Lanarkshire in 1775. He was educated at home and after a brief spell at the Chauvet Military Academy in London, he joined the Royal Navy. Cochrane became captain of H.M.S. Speedy in 1800 and he soon established a reputation for his daring and brilliant seamanship against the French Navy.<br>Cochrane came into conflict with the authorities when they refused to support his campaign against corruption in the navy. In 1806 Thomas Cochrane met the radical journalist William Cobbett, who had also been involved in attempting to expose corruption in the armed forces. The two men became close friends and Cobbett encouraged Cochrane to win election to the House of Commons where he would have an opportunity to expose those members of the armed forces who were misusing their power.<br>Cochrane was elected to represent Honiton in 1806. However, Cochrane's ideas were too progressive for the electors of Honiton and in 1807 he decided to accept the invitation to stand with Sir Francis Burdett as one of the two Radical candidates for the Westminster constituency.<br>After his election to the House of Commons Captain Cochrane spent much of his time at sea in the war against the French. When in Parliament, Cochrane made several speeches attacking corruption in the Royal Navy. The naval authorities were furious with Cochrane and he demoted. Aware that he had lost the opportunity of advancing his naval career, Cochrane concentrated his efforts on campaigning for parliamentary reform.<br>In 1814 Cochrane was accused with his uncle and his stockbroker of fraud on the stock market. Cochrane claimed he had been framed but he was found guilty of fraud and sentenced to a year's imprisonment, a fine of £1,000 and two hours in the pillory. When Sir Francis Burdett threatened to stand next to Cochrane in the pillory, this part of the sentence was withdrawn to avoid a riot taking place.<br>After his release from prison Cochrane gave support to Major John Cartwright and the formation of the Hampden Clubs. He also argued in favour of universal suffrage and spoke against the Gagging Acts.<br>In 1818 Cochrane resigned from the House of Commons and took up an appointment as commander of the Chilean Navy. After periods working for the governments of Peru and Brazil, Cochrane took command of the naval force that had been formed to assist the liberation of Greece.<br>In 1831 Thomas Cochrane became the tenth Earl of Dundonald. The following year, King William IV awarded him a free pardon for his alleged role in the 1814 stock market fraud. He was also reinstated as a Rear Admiral in the Royal Navy. Thomas Cochrane, Earl of Dundonald, died on 31st October 1860.<br>-------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------<br>(1) In his autobiography, Thomas Cochrane described how his defeat in the 1805 Honiton election led to his victory in the following year.<br>To the intense disgust of the majority of the electors, I refused to bribe at all, announcing my determination to stand on patriotic principles' which, in the electioneering parlance of those days, meant 'no bribery'. To my astonishment, however, a considerable number of the respectable inhabitants voted in my favour.<br>Having had decisive proof as to the nature of Honiton politics, I made up my mind that the next time there was a vacancy in the borough, the seat should be mine without bribery. Accordingly, immediately after my defeat, I sent the bellman round the town, having first primed him with an appropriate speech, intimating that all who had voted for me, might repair to my agent and receive ten pounds ten. The novelty of a defeated candidate paying double the current price expended by the successful one made a great sensation. The impression produced was simply this - that if I gave ten guineas for being beaten, my opponent had not paid half enough for being elected."
"NI4430","in household of John F. Cain & Mable T. Cain in 1870, Warren Co., VA"
"NI4703","Coronet in Army.<br>M.P. for Tyrone.<br>Died unmarried."
"NI4704","Died unmarried in 1721 or 1726."
"NI4705","Died unmarried."
"NI4757","Under his father's will, he inherited property in Gloucestershire and London, also all myne armour and other furniture for the warres. Became Receiver of Crown Rents for Suffolk.  Was granted Manor of Darsham 1575.  Obtained other Crown Grants in 1595 and 1598, Patron of the living of Darsham.  MP for Darsham 1579, and Eye 1589.  Receiver to the King."

Cavanaugh, Leod. Andrews, Angus Vawter<br>and<br>Boulware<br>Vawter<br>Proved 15 April 1771 by Angus Vawter and recorded<br>Further proved 17 June 1771 by Richard Noel, one of<br>the<br>executors, and<br>ordered to probate"

"NI4865","Clemens Magazine Genealogy gives the following data of one, Thomas Noell:<br>That he died in Bedford Co., Va. 1831, leaving a will dated 9th Sep., 1831; probated in same county, 26 Sep., 1831. In his will he mentions, daughters Polly, Parmelia Douglas, and Catherine Falls; sons, John C., and Zachary Noell; son-in-law, Uriah Hatcher who married his daughter Nancy Noell; his son Richards two daughters, Mary and Corrasinda; his daughter, Theodosia Baughns nine children:--Adeline Johnson, Sarah Gilliam, Samuel H., Richard C., Elizabeth, Frances, Willard, and Zachary Baughn."

Conaway, 51, IL<br>     Ada P., 41, MI<br>     Cleo R., 21, OK<br>     Gladys, 18, OK<br>     Lester E., 17, OK<br>     Velma L., 15, OK<br>     Elmer L., 5, AR"
"NI4959","Benjamin Guthrie came to Kentucky in 1783, with Richard Cave and Richard Johnson, and helped to build the Big (Great) Crossing Station (in present day Scott County) for Scott Johnson. He m Frances _______, and they were on Glen's Creek, W 1810, with a family of seven, including: 1,Sally, m Edward Carter, W 1804; 2, Dahuldy, m William Gardner, W 1811; 3, Benjamin, m Catherine Ramsey, W 1814; 4, Minerva Davis. Norman or Norbourne Guthrie also may have been a son. (See Forks of Elkhorn Church, by Ermina Jett Darnell, page 161.)  The Great Crossing got it's name from the great buffalo trace (path), from the southern part of Kentucky to the Ohio River, crossed North Elkhorn Creek. See Historical Sketches of Kentucky, by Lewis Collins, page 508.<br>Benjamin's coming to Kentucky, being a centenary of Simon Kenton and Daniel Boone is recorded in The Filson Club History Quarterly, Volume 5, Number 1, January 1931, Big Crossing Station, Built by Robert Johnson, recorded in John D. Shane's interview with pioneer Ben Guthrie, pages 1 through 15.<br>Benjamin Guttrey, Fayette County, Kentucky Tax List 1788.<br>August 1789, a large body of Indians were camped on the other side of the Ohio (River) and were continually coming over and doing a good deal of mischief. Robert Johnson took a Company; two Grants, Samuel and Isreal were killed there. Samuel Grant was looking from behind a tree to sight an Indian and was shot. Israel Grant, his brother, went to see if he really was killed and an Indian shot him. From an interview from Ben Guthrie, a contemporary of the Grants, by John Shane, quoted in Filson Club Quarterly, Vol. 5, No. 1, page 9. The ancient's memory was at fault as to the name. It was Moses not Israel who was killed.<br>The 1792 - 1795 Militia Tax Rolls, Woodford County, Kentucky also list Benjamin Guthrey.<br>The 1795 Census of Kentucky list Benjamin Guthrie in Woodford County, page 72.<br>January 27, 1796. By virtue of appointment from court of Woodford Co. to us directed as commissioners to examine witness to perpetuate testimony respecting claim of Mr. John Holly to 400 acres. We have cause to come before us W. Flanders Calloway at a Sinkhole Spring at Franklin Jarvis's in the aforesaid. county and duly qualifying him on the holy Evangelist of Almighty God this deponent saith: That in the year of our Lord Christ, 1777. in the month of December that he and Mr. John Holly and among other persons set out from Boonsborough to Lee's Town on the Kentucky River, on their passage they came to above mentioned spring and John Holly claimed that the spring and adjacent land. He abducted himself from the company and on returning Holly said he had improved the place by cutting his first two letters of his name on a tree near the spring. The despondent stated Reuben Searcy and William Maggeehee was in the company and this deponent was a pilot to conduct the company on their way. Witnessed Benjamine Guthrie. Woodford County, Kentucky Records Deed Book B, pg. 535.<br>August 10, 1798, John Craig, Robert Johnson, Elijah Craig, of Campbell Co., to Benjamin Guthrey (witness 200 pounds, John Craig and Sary, his wife) 182 acres, on waters of Glen Creek In Woodford Co., corner to Sam'l Estill's cabbin on bank of Spring Creek. Woodford County, Kentucky Deed Book C-2 pg. 243.<br>Court of Appeals Deeds-Grantees, Guthrey, Benj & Alex Jr., residence- Woodford, Date of deed- 10-26-1802, acres- 500, book-G, page 187, watercourse- Wolf Creek. Old Kentucky Entries and Deeds, Chapter VII, Court of Appeals, Deeds - Grantees, 1783-1909, page 417. Benjamin Guthrey received in 1802 one-half of land in Kentucky that was secured by James Harrod, Esq. Also, he received a small bore gun and a Negro slave named Tobias and a bay mare with her increase. (From Wilmer Kerns, Virginia.)<br>1804, Benjamin Guthrey and Frances, his wife, of Woodford County to Harman Bowmar and Moses Payne, of county aforesaid, $340, 109 acres, north side of Rough Spring, fork of Glens Creek as tenants in common. Woodford County Kentucky Deed Book C, pg. 579.<br>Benjamin Guthrie (Guthrey) is listed in the 1810, 1820, 1830 and 1840 Woodford County, Kentucky Census reports. (1810 pg. 13, 1820 pg. 15, 1830 pg. 14, 1840 pg. 14.)<br>Benjamin Guthrey did not leave a will, however, Woodford County, Kentucky, Will Book M pages 308-310 list the Inventory and Appraisement, Estate of Benjamin Guthrey, deceased. The sale list for the Estate of Benjamin Guthrey is on pages 310-312. An interesting note, Benjamin owned seven Negro slaves.<br>There are several (to many to mention here) entries in the Woodford County records of Benjamin Guthrie as a Guardian Bondsman."
"NI4970","The records of Orange County, Virginia (Deeds, Vol. 13, p. 5) show that Alexander King Guttrey of St. David's Parish, King William County purchased for one hundred pounds, 298 acres in St. Thomas Paris of said county, Feb. 19, 1759.  Also, (Deeds, Vol. 15, p. 415) that Alexander Guttrey and Sarah Guttrey his wife for five shillings conveyed the said land lying on both sides of Black Walnut Run, to Henry Oaks, June 25, 1765.  He was a witness in Cumberland County in 1766 to a deed made by Thomas, who in another record refers to his son as Alexander King Guthrey.  He was a Captain in the Revolutionary War, and lived in Cumberland the rest of his life.<br>Foot notes... Census 1782, Guthrey, Alexander, 10 whites, 12 blacks<br>Census 1784, Guthrey, Alexander, 7 whites, 1 dwelling, 2 other buildings.<br>The will of Alexander Guthrey of the County of Cumberland and Paris of Littleton, contains;<br>1- I give my loving son Benjamin...also half of my land in Kentucky which James Herrod Esq., took up for me , which land I gave to him, my aforesaid son Benjamin, by deed in 1802.<br>2- I give to my loving son Alexander Guthrey...also the other half of land in Kentucky, which I gave him by deed in 1802.<br>3- I give to my loving daughter Elizabeth Davis...negro man named Jack, who at my special request was given to my said daughter Betty by my grandmother, Elizabeth Oaks, instead of being given to me as was the expressed intention of my aforesaid grandmother...<br>4-T o my grandson Anderson Maddox...my library.<br>Nothing further is known of this family, his sons, Benjamin and Alexander, are not mentioned in any later records of Cumberland County.<br>American Guthrie and Allied Families, by Laurence R. Guthrie, pages 38-39, and Appendix page 688."
"NI4979","From History of Woodford County, by William E. Railey, page 418:<br>Thomas Guthrie removed to Cumberland County, Virginia in 1750.  Thomas Guthrie had 8 children.  He was one of the Minute Men under the Cumberland County, Virginia Committee of Safley of which Edward Carrington, I think, was Chairman, and he was also a Captain of Militia during the Revolution (war)  Joseph A. Guthrie, a lawyer of Kansas City.<br>---<br>Thomas Guthrie filed his will in Cumberland County Virginia on October 6, 1790, and his was was proven on September 22, 1800, in which he mentions:<br>1- To daughter Susannah Moore, among other bequest, old large bible.<br>2- To son William Guthrey land and plantation where I now live.<br>3- To grand daughter Sarah Guthrey, daughter of son William, having promised the child the same, one mare colt named Kit.<br>---<br>Information on Thomas Guthrey and his children was provided by Wilmer Kerns of Virginia, and is also listed in American Guthrie and Allied Families, be Laurence R. Guthrie, 1933, page 38."
"NI4983","Thomas Moore and Edith Trent were Parents of Mary <br>Elizabeth, who Married Gimlin brothers, Samuel and David. <br>Thomas was a Revolutionary War Soldier and suffered much <br>at the hands of the Enemy. He received a pension for his <br>services in the year 1790 ($20 per year). While Thomas lived <br>in Kentucky, he was a slave owner and raised tobacco. In 1831 <br>he moved to Illinois. For a time he lived in a Squatters Cabin <br>Until he could get a better home built. There they spent the <br>remainer of their lives. <br>Children: <br>Henry Moore & (1) Mary Shipp <br>(2) Mary Parker <br>Mary Moore & David Gimlin <br>Susannah Moore & Thomas Hughes <br>Nancy Moore & Willie Whitworth <br>Guthrie Thomas Moore & Slvania Sublett <br>John Moore & (1) Mary Christian (2) Ann ? <br>Robert Moore & Elizabeth William or <br>Mary Brood <br>Travis Moore & Mary Chism <br>Edith Moore & Jeremiah Morgan"
"NI4984","About 1820 moved to Jackson Co MO.  Fought in the Revolutionary War, and the War of 1812."
"NI5033","Obituary of Seaton Alexander BLEVINS, Macoupin County IL<br>Name of Deceased: BLEVINS, Seaton Alexander<br>Name of Newspaper: Macoupin County Enquirer<br>Date of Obituary: April 7, 1897<br>Obituary: Death of S.A. BLEVINS Died Monday at his home in Shaw's Point township of old age, S. A. BLEVINS, age 83. The funeral will be held Wednesday at 11 a.m. from the family residence after which interment will be made in Bethel cemetery. The deceased was an upright citizen, respected by his friends and neighbors, a member of the Christian Church and leaves a wife and seven children to mourn his departure from earth."
"NI5119","John was father to 16 children, the oldest born in 1800 and the youngest born in 1855, an age range of 55 years, and his fourth wife was so young that she never called her husband by his first name, but addressed him as Mr. Guthrie. Actually, she was 14 years younger than her oldest step-son."
"NI5130","Had a total of 6 children from both marriages."
"NI5133","Had 9 children."
"NI5157","1860 census shows age as 62 which would indicate he was born in<br>1818<br>Arrived in Jackson Township, Linn Co., MO on 15 Nov 1845 -<br>according to Francis Hawkins NORVELL's obit.<br>From Dennis Norvell<br>Tombstone indicates died aged 83y 1/11m 27d, thus he was born<br>11 Mar 1820 or 12 Jan 1821. Date from Denny Norvell show hes<br>was born 11 Jan 1820, but this does not match the tombstone<br>dates. 1880 census age shows he was born about 1818. 2 SOUR S217<br>3 PAGE of Francis Fannie Norvell, Seth's wife.<br>Land Patent Cert. No. 6723, forty acres. 2 SOUR S61<br>3 PAGE NE 1/4 of NE 1/4 S34 T60 R22 in Linn Co, MO"
"NI5158","From Bible Records of Missouri, Volume III:<br>Children of Margaret J. Phillips and Thomas Norvell were: Stephen Norvell, George Norvell, William Norvell, Mary Norvell, Sarah Norvell, America Norvell, Thomas Norvell, and Marion Norvell."
"NI5160","twin to Martha"
"NI5161","Served during the Civil War in 23rd Missouri Volunteer Infantry Company B"
"NI5167","Obituary lists birth, death, father etc.<br>Left KY on 19 Oct 1845 and arrived in MO 15 Nov 1845.<br>Obit for Francis Norvel stated she bore nine children, four of which survive."
"NI5175","Convicted of 1st degree murder in Linn County in 1887 for the<br>murder of John T. Goddard (reported in papers as Jim or Tim).<br>Son Howard was found not guilty. Emmazella was initially<br>convicted of second degree murder in Linn Co, but on appeal<br>trial moved to Sullivan Co. Have not found the records for the<br>second trial of James and Emmazella. The retrial found James<br>guilty of second degree murder and he was sentenced in Oct.<br>1888 to 11 years in the Missouri State Pententiary. James<br>served 6 years of his sentence, it was commuted by the Governor<br>of MO on Nov 17, 1893. He was discharged on Jan. 5, 1894 under<br>the 3/4 law. Emmazella apprently found not guilty in Sullivan<br>County since no record of her sentence has been found.<br>Known in his later years by the residents of Humphreys as<br>Uncle Jimmie.<br>Milan Standard Obituary, 15 Sep 1932:<br>Uncle Jimmie Norvell, of north of town died Sunday Evening<br>after several weeks illness, aged 85 years. His wife preceded<br>him in death only 16 months ago. He left two sons, Howard and<br>Wesley, two grandson, whom he raised, Jimmie and Earl Norvell,<br>and many other grandchildren and great grandchildren. Uncle<br>Jimmie has been a familiar character on the streets of our town<br>for many years. This summer especially, he has been seen much,<br>with his little great grandson. The child's love for him, and<br>his love for the child was something out of the ordinary. The<br>funeral was held at the Methodist Church Monday p.m. by Rev.<br>Winney, of Galt. The pallbearers were his grandsons. Intement<br>in the Humphreys cemetery beside his wife.<br>James NORVELL, 60 acres valued at $600, 5 horses, 3 milch(sic)<br>cows, 5 other cattle, 26 swine, and 35 poultry. He produced<br>300 lbs of butter in 1879."
"NI5176","in the 1900 Census, the NORVELLs are shown as having had 8<br>children, 6 surviving. Believe that Henryetta and Seth are the<br>two that died before 1900. We have records of 7 chidren, but<br>we don't have any record of the missing child.<br>Obituary shows she was born in 1853, but census records of 1860<br>indicate 1854. She is in the 1870 census as Mezella, age 16,<br>wife of James which would indicate she was born in 1854. The<br>1900 census indicates she was born in Mar 1853, is age 47, and<br>has been married 33 years.<br>Obituary from Trenton Republican Times, Trenton, Missouri 16<br>May 1931:<br>Mrs. J. S. Norvell, Humphreys, Dead<br>End Came at 11 A.M. Today at Home Near There Following<br>Paralytic Stroke Sunday.<br>Mrs. J. S. Norvell of two miles north of Humphreys died at 11<br>a.m. today at her home there, following a stroke of paralysis<br>of last Sunday. She was 78 years old. Mrs. Norvell had been<br>in failing health for some time, although she continued with<br>her house work until stricken.<br>Besides the widower, the survivors include two sons, Howard<br>Norvell of Humphreys, and Wesley Norvell of the home address;<br>five brothers, John Gillispie, Havelock Neb.; Charles<br>Gillispie, Grand Island, Neb; George Gillispie, Valeda Kansas;<br>Sherman Gillispie, address not learned; W. H. Gillispie, of<br>Humphreys; two sisters, Mrs. Lew Dennis, Fairmont, Neb.; Mrs.<br>Ida Rentfrow, Rockville, Neb., Earl and Jimmie Norvell, two<br>nephews who made their home with the deceased, besides a number<br>of grandchildren.<br>The funeral arrangements have not been completed.<br>Note: Earl and Jimmie were sons of Fred and Sarah Ann Norvell,<br>and thus were her grandsons, not nephews. 2 SOUR S26"
"NI5191","Requested his grandsons act as pall bearers at his funeral.<br>Neil and Randy Smith, Larry Collins, and Lyndell Smith served<br>along with David Haddox and ?."
"NI5192","Ada was living with her daughter Evelyn Pittaway at the time of<br>her death.<br>She planned to name all of her children with an E in their<br>names, but Irvin was misspelled by the staff when they recorded<br>his birth."
"NI5193","Was accidentally shot and killed by unknown person while deer<br>hunting with brother Elsworth SMITH on Elsworth's farm near<br>Humphreys, MO. 2 SOUR S116"
"NI5203","Murdered her daughter Emily in a murder-suicide."
"NI5205","Murdered by her mother in a murder-suicide."
"NI5214","was living in Reger, MO and went to the VA hospital for<br>treatment of liver cancer."
"NI5223","Owned night club in Kansas City in the 1930's (12th and Vine).<br>Went to prison about 1942 for income tax invasion (according to<br>family stories)."
"NI5232","Korean War<br>Death and family details from his obituary from an unknown AZ<br>newspaper dated circa Wednesday 24 Nov. 1998.<br>Bueler Mortuary handled funeral arrangements.<br>Marine Corp, Vietnam War"
"NI5238","1900 Sullivan Census records he was born Dec 1880.<br>Charles is mentioned in his mother's obituary as living, but<br>nothing else is known after that. It is assumed by the family<br>that he went to live with his brother Howard after their mother<br>and father's deaths."
"NI5251","From Bible Records of Missouri, Volume III:<br>Margaret J. Phillips married Thomas Norvell born in Woodford County Kentucky. Her father called her Sam."
"NI5253","Served in the Civil War in 23rd Missouri Volunteer Infantry Company B"
"NI5287","twin to Mary"
"NI5345","William does not appear in the 1880 census and it is surmised<br>he has died before then."
"NI5352","William GILLISPIE died intestate. Nancy was appointed<br>Administratrix on 15 Nov 1878 (Linn County MO Probate Court Vol<br>D, p603 film C17612). On 19 May, 1879 after complaint by H. B.<br>MILLER about an unpaid debt and insufficient bond by Nancy, the<br>court ordered a new security (IBID, pg 637).<br>Court records on xx Nov 1879 (Linn County MO Probate Court Vol<br>E, p4 film C17612) First and final settlement approved. Widow<br>allowed dower of $400 and $80 for year's provisions.<br>Administratrix having failed to give add'l security, her<br>authority is revoked. Public Administrator appointed.<br>Linn Co. Patrons of the 1876 Atlas<br>Hometown - Lindley (Sullivan County)<br>Occupation - Tobacco grower<br>Birth State - Caswell Co., VA (probably Tazewell Co.)<br>First settled In Linn Co. - 1842"
"NI5392","Died at an early age during the Civil War.  James was married twice, his second wife was Sarah Elizabeth Bettie Brown.  They had two girls who died relatively young and a son named William Edward Stevens."
"NI5416","Edmund Gapper, the oldest son of Edmund and Mary, stayed in England. There is some confusion in the army lists, placing him both as Captain of the 83rd Regiment of Foot in 1812 and in the Royal Artillery. He seems to have been placed on half-pay in 1817, and retired on half-pay in 1821. He died in 1829. In 1830 his daughter Maria left for Canada to live with Mary (Gapper) O'Brien. Maria ultimately married a Canadian, Edmund Seager."
"NI5417","William Southby, served in the Royal Navy. In 1825 the two brothers, William Southby and Richard Gapper (born 1803) along with William's wife, Mary, traveled to Canada to buy land. They were able to afford to buy partially cleared land close to the town of York as opposed to forest in the wilderness, which would have been cheaper but involved extra labour to clear. Perhaps they had preferential treatment because of their army and church connections and Tory politics. There was an all-powerful Tory, Church of England establishment at the time called The Family Compact. The Church of England also had an arrangement whereby they kept seven percent of all land allotted to anyone. This was known as the Clergy Reserve.<br>William bought Lot 38 on the west side of Yonge Street in Vaughan Township, about a mile and a quarter north of the village of Thornhill, south of Richmond Hill. Richard's land was lot 41, three-quarters of a mile north of William's on the east side of Yonge Street in Markham Township. Both lots were constructed by previous owners."
"NI5418","Mary Sophia married Edmund O'Brien in Upper Canada. There, she kept a journal from 1828 to 1838, and sent it, in the form of letters to her sister Lucy Sharpe. These letters made the rounds of the family in England to inform them of life in the wilderness of Canada. She also very much wanted her sister and her husband the Rev. Sharpe to emmigrate, these jounals were her attempt to entice then to join her. At some point latter these letters were collected in England and sent back to Canada and ended up in the hands of one of her children. These letters were donated to the Ontario Archives . In 1968 these journals were edited and published as a book called The Journals of Mary O'Brien 1828-1838, edited by Audrey Saunders Miller. This book, though out of print is obtainable by any used bookseller specializing in Canadiana. I might be able to help you obtain one if you wish. The book is full of interesting information about pioneer life, but more importantly, information about the Gapper Family.<br>-From email from Julie Christian (yellowhouse6@sympatico.ca)<br>---<br>Mary Gapper married Edward O'Brien and ultimately settled in Shanty Bay on Lake Simcoe. She and Edward had six children."
"NI5419","Anthony was trained as a doctor and practised medicine in Bristol between 1823 and 1826.<br>In 1826 Anthony joined his William and Mary Southby and Richard in Upper Canada. He spent his time cataloguing biological forms of life and wandered the country in search of rare flora and fauna. He discovered a red backed vole, a kind of mouse, which was named after him 'evotomys gapperi' by Nicholas Vigors of the British Museum.<br>Anthony returned to England in 1829. He inherited the Southby family home, Bulford House, near Stonehenge, in 1835, and changed his name to Southby. In the census of 1861 Anthony is listed as aged 61, occupation: landholder and papermaster, and the employer of five men, one boy and three women."
"NI5420","Edumund O'Brien is a direct descendant of the Kings Of Ireland going back to the 10th Century. His pedigree is readily found on the internet at Royal geneology web sites.<br>Served in the Royal Navy, and then the Army, Scots Greys, and (having exchanged for foreign service) 58th Regt. and retired on half pay; came to Canada in 1830, and settled at The Woods, Shanty Bay, Simcoe Co, Ontario, Canada.<br>---<br>From A History of Simcoe County (p134-137):<br>Even before the survey of Oro in 1820, it was. the intention of the 'Government to devote part of it to the philanthropic uses of a coloured colony. A few coloured settlers were located, but for some reason or other the initial enthusiasm of the project died out, and nothing further -on the part of the Government was done until about 1830. In connection with this proposal they commissioned Lieut.-Col. Edward George O'Brien to act as Government agent for the location of the negro immigrants. Col. O'Brien then became a settler, and the founder of Shanty Bay.<br>He had, at the age of fourteen, entered the naval service as midshipman on board H. M. frigate Doris, but the peace with America in 1815 blighted his hopes of advancement in the navy. A lengthy extract from his jottings, made while in the service, appears in Thompson's Reminiscences, and describes his first experience of life at sea. Leaving the navy, he entered the army for a time and served in the West Indies, where his health failed him, but soon after he again went to sea .and made numerous voyages to the East. Illness forced him to leave the .service and come to Canada.<br>In his pretty log cottage at Shanty Bay he dwelt during the first years after his settlement, and his relations with the settlers of the neighbourhood were of the most friendly character. Mr. Thompson in his Reminiscences has preserved a glimpse of his residence as it appeared in 1833, and has also recorded various incidents in his career.<br>In those early years he was a commissioner of the Court of Requests at Barrie, and occupied the position of chairman of the Quarter Sessions for the Simcoe District. He was one of the first magistrates in this locality.<br>When the uprising of 1837 took place, he called together a company of stalwart settlers, and marched for Toronto; but before arriving there he received instructions from Sir F. B. Head, the Lieut.Governor, to proceed to Bond Head and remain there to take charge of the place, for there had been some disaffection in the district. After Simcoe had been erected into a county, Mr. O'Brien and his family removed to Toronto, where they resided for many years. He began business in the city as a land agent, and was subsequently Manager of the Provincial Insurance Company, until 1857. In 1848 he became partial proprietor of the Toronto Patriot newspaper, but on May 2 .5th of the following year occurred the great fire which destroyed the Patriot printing office. Shortly afterward Mr. O'Brien sold his share in that newspaper to Mr. Ogle R. Gowan.<br>Lieut.-Col. E. G. O'Brien's life, as well as that of his wife, have been warmly eulogized by their contemporary generation. Their charitableness caused them to be respected by people of all shades of opinion ; and it is recorded that to Mrs O'Brien, Toronto is indebted for its first ragged school. Several members of their family became distinguished in various ways. Lieut.-Col. Wm. E. O'Brien was commanding officer of the 35th battalion, Simcoe Foresters, resigning October, 1897, and was member of the Dominion House of Commons for Muskoka ; Lucius R. O'Brien was generally acknowledged to be the foremost Canadian artist in his day; while Henry O'Brien, K.C., of Toronto, is a well-known member of the legal profession. In the burial ground of the Shanty Bay church, which they mainly assisted to -establish, Col. O'Brien and his wife are buried, and over them an<br>Irish cross bears the following words<br>In loving remembrance of Edward George O'Brien, who died September 8, 1875, age 76; and of Mary Sophia, his wife, who died October 1q., 1876, age 78. This stone is raised by their children. He having served his country by sea and land, became A. D. 1830 the founder of the settlement and mission of Shanty Bay. She was a true wife and zealous in all good works. Faithful servants, they rest in hope."
"NI5424","The 1st Reverend Edmund Gapper appears several times in the first volume (1758-81) of The Diaries of a Country Person be Reverend James Woodforde.<br>---<br>Upon his death he left the Manor of Charlton Adam to his son Edmund, the 2nd Reverend Edmund Gapper.<br>---<br>Gapper, Edmund<br>(Male) <br>Title(s): Rev, Mr <br>Date: 1763 <br>Occupation(s): cleric(a) <br>Subscribed to The Histories of Lady Frances S- , and Lady Caroline S-. Written by the Miss Minifies, of Fairwater, in Somersetshire (Vol. 1), 1763, MINIFIE, MINIFIE. London<br>Subject: novel <br>---"
"NI5425","Of Baltonsborough.<br>Upon his death he left the Manor of Charlton Adam to his son Edmund, the 1st Reverend Edmund Gapper."
"NI5426","Of Sutton, in Wincanton.<br>In 1705 Thomas purchased  The Manor of Charton Adam from his wife's uncle, Edmund Seaman.  Upon his death he left the manor to his son Edmund of Baltonsborough."
"NI5427","In 1830 Maria left for Canada to live with Mary (Gapper) O'Brien.  Maria ultimately married a Canadian, Edmund Seager."
"NI5431","His paintings are in the National Gallery of Canada and some belong to the royal family in England, as he painted for Queen Victoria.  The Internet has a lot of information on Lucius."
"NI5434","of The Woods, Shanty Bay, Simcoe Co, Ontario, Canada.<br>M.P., Lieut-Col. 35th Simcoe Foresters, commanded the York and Simcoe Provisional Battallion in the North West, 1885 (medal)."
"NI5436","Elijah married Matilda Snodgrass 13 Aug. 1835 or 20 Feb. 1836 in<br>Hancock Co. IN . She died shortly after the birth of their son Joseph<br>S 14 June 1836. Indications are that he soon left Hancock Co. and<br>settled on some land in Morgan Co. IN. He entered land at the<br>Crawfordville land office in Morgan Co. 12 Nov. 1840 Certificate<br>No.32972. Oral history of Elijah says that he became an indentured<br>servant at an early age and never knew who his parents were. On his<br>death certificate it states he died in Marion Co. Iowa. One record<br>says he was a bonded servant and ran away from his master and escaped<br>to Indiana.<br>Notes, Source, Virginia Wheeldon:<br>Death Record : Knoxville, Marion Co., IA.<br>Census: 1850 listed in Morgan Co., IN"
"NI5440","dies of typhoid fever in service in mound city,Il"
"NI5560","Obituary of Euphemia GRAY BLEVINS (BURROWS), Macoupin County IL<br>Name of Deceased: BLEVINS, Euphemia (BURROWS) (GRAY)<br>Name of Newspaper: Carlinville Democrat<br>Date of Obituary: Oct. 29, 1902<br>Obituary: Death of Mrs. U. Blevins Monday morning at her home in<br>Shaw's Point township, Mrs. Euphemia BLEVINS died, aged 85 years.<br>The deceased was one of the oldest residents of that township.<br>Dec. 24, 1837, she was united in marriage to Andrew GRAY, Rev.<br>David GIMBLIN officiating. Mr. GRAY died in 1846. December 1st,<br>1848 she was united in marriage to S.A. BLEVINS, John LEWIS, J.P.<br>officiating. He died about five years ago. Mrs. BLEVINS had been<br>blind for some years and was in very poor health also. Her father<br>was one of the first settlers in Macoupin county. She was a<br>stepmother of William GRAY, of Virden."
"NI5562","Obituary of Columbus C. BLEVINS, Macoupin County IL<br>Name of Deceased: BLEVINS, Columbus C.<br>Name of Newspaper: Macoupin County Enquirer<br>Date of Obituary: Jan. 18, 1922<br>Obituary: Death of Columbus BLEVINS Shaw's Point lost one of<br>it's most prominent and respected citizens in the death of<br>Columbus BLEVINS, who passed away at the family home, Monday,<br>Jan. 16th at 7:30 a.m. after an illness of only 4 days from<br>pneumonia. He was aged 71 years, 1 month, and 14 days. The<br>deceased was born in Shaw's Point township just a short distance<br>from where the family home now stands and has spent his entire<br>life in that locality. He never was a member of any fraternal or<br>other Society or Church organization but was always proud to be<br>at the forefront in any Christian or charitable work that was to<br>be done. He was a good man with his neighbors and at his own home<br>where he was greatly loved and will be missed greatly.<br>He was married in about 1880 to Miss Cenia A. LAIR and to this<br>union five children were born, two of whom have preceded him in<br>death. Besides his widow, he leaves to mourn their loss, three<br>daughters, Miss Lucetta, a teacher in the Springfield schools,<br>Miss Olive, a teacher in the DeKalb high school, and Mrs. Nancy<br>UPTON of Atwater; also, one son-in-law, Cephus UPTON and two<br>grandchildren, Mary and Alfred UPTON of Atwater. Funeral services<br>will be held Wednesday, Jan. 18th at 11 a.m. at Bethel M.E.<br>Church, the services being conducted by Rev. Charles Upton.<br>Interment in Bethel Cemetery."
"NI5564","Obituary of Cenia LAIR BLEVINS, Macoupin County IL<br>Name of Deceased: BLEVINS, Cenia (Lair)<br>Name of Newspaper: Macoupin County Enquirer<br>Date of Obituary: Jan. 23, 1929<br>Obituary: Mrs. Cenia BLEVINS died at the home of her daughter,<br>Mrs. Cephas UPTON, Thursday, Jan. 17, 1929 in Atwater. She was 76<br>years, 11 months and 4 days old. She was born Feb. 13, 1852. Her<br>husband preceded her in death Jan. 16, 1922 and also two children<br>died in childhood. She is survived by three children - Mrs. Nancy<br>UPTON of Atwater; Miss Olive BLEVINS of Eureka, and Miss Lulista<br>BLEVINS of Washington, D.C. One brother survives, Charles<br>SNOW of Tulsa, Okla. Funeral services were held Sunday at 1:30<br>p.m. at the Christian Church in Atwater, Rev. J.H. Hostetler of<br>Hillsboro officiating. The pallbearers were James BOSTON, J.E.<br>BOSTON, John WESBROOK, J.A. COLE, J.W. PLAIN and George MASON.<br>Interment was in the Bethel Cemetery."
"NI5569","Family moved to Canada circa 1920."
"NI5575","Lead died at 79 years of age.  She had received a fractured hip in a fall in February.  Funeral services were held at the Crosby-Knould Mortuary in Omaha, and she burial was in the Douglas Grove Cemetary in Comstock."
"NI5603","Early censuses list his name as Morrison Lash.  He probably went by his middle name later in life."
