Glenna did our sewing she made us both just alike people sometimes thot we were twins.<br>CONCLUSION <br>Winfred Moody was president of the High Priests Quorum, of the St. Joseph Stake, and Bro ther Cheny was one of his councilers, Well Brother Cheny died and of (course) father had to go to the funeral, he dident tell mother because he dident want to worry her, but we children knew about it, About 2 P.M.mother went into a coma, father was sent for and when he returned she felt better so he told her where he had been. Yes she told him I knew where you were, I was there also, and I saw several people there who have been gone over there a long time, then she told him the names of the speakers there and the songs they sang, for she heard and saw the whole funeral service. To me this was a great testimony that there is a great hereafter, and that our loved ones are often allowed to visit us here.<br>Quote from Ida's story. The next day I was alone in the house , and Mother called me t o her bedside and said, Ida I must go and leave all of you soon,and you will have to take over the responsibility of being a mother to your brothers and sisters, especially to the little baby. I became frightened and ran out into the orchard and prayed for someone to come to help us, soon Aunt Lizzie was at the door, she said, How is your mother? I have the Relief Society sisters at my house quilting and had dinner ready to serve, A voice said to me Go to Malinda I said to myself that I would go as soon I got the dinner over with, Again the voice said Go to Malinda I ask one of the ladies to serve dinner and here I am, I never waited to hear more, I ran to the orchard again and thanked my Heavenly Father for answering my second prayer. and this is another wonderful Testimony to me that the Lord hears and answers PRAYERS.<br>Brother Ed quotes; Anyway we all grew up, married, made homes of our own and raised ou r families as best we knew how, Perhaps we have regrets for things we left undone thru the years, and perhaps we did things we shouldent have done. but such is life and thru the teachings of our dear parents, we have tried hard to bring up our children so that our parents behind the veil will be proud of their grandchildren, who have been taught to be noble and honorable.<br>Now we are getting older than our mother was when she passed on. I was only fourteen yea rs old when mother died just knew her that long; I wish I could put love and honor into my children as mother did with hers, it is hard to realize that mother accomplished so much in such a short life. Today her little babe she left is sisty two years old, a lovely woman, It wont be long now till we will all be with mother and father again. in a family group Over There I am seventy eight now and I hope I am ready to go home when my call comes."
"NI8817","SOURCE: THE JOHN WYATT MOODY FAMILY Past and Present Published by Dr. Thomas Moody Family Organization Inc. President, E. Grant Moody 1424 South College Avenue Tempe, Arizona 85281 Copyright 1985<br>pages 543-545 <br>FRANCIS WINFRED MOODY <br>Son of John Monroe Moody & Elizabeth Pool Moody <br>Francis Winfred, son of John Monroe and Elizabeth Pool Moody was born August 26, 1858 i n Salt Lake City, Utah. While a very small child he suffered from seizures that threatened his life . Through the administration of his father and several elders, he matured to manhood with no further incident.<br>In the fall of 1861 when the family moved to Dixie, Winfred was three years old. He stayed with his mother in Pine Valley until 1863 when his family moved to St. George. <br>At age 14 in 1872 he accompanied a friend to Salt Lake City. The boys passed through the empty town of Panguitch, its inhabitants having removed to a fort because of an Indian raid by one of the bands of Indians who refused to stay on a reservation, but roamed Utah and Idaho trying to get enough food to stay alive.<br>Winfred helped build the temple. He hauled cobble rock for the foundation, then dressed rock from the quarry on the west side of St. George. He was present at its dedication by Brigham Young. <br>He saw Brigham Young and George A. Smith when they would come to Dixie. The Sunday school children used to go and welcome them, cheering from both sides of the road. President Young would bow and smile at them as he passed, then the band and the children and the other settlers would fall in behind the carriage.<br>In the spring of 1879, Winfred went to Provo to attend the Brigham Young Academy. He said goodby to his family and girl friend, Miss Eunice Renbow Carter. He remained in school two terms. Then his father wrote asking him to come back. His brother John was in Europe on a mission, and John Monroe was having a hard time supporting the family without Winfred's help. Winfred had intended to finish school, but never got another opportunity.<br>When the Moodys moved to Arizona, Winfred followed some days later. He took time to call on Miss Carter, to whom he had previously given a ring. He told her he'd come back in two years, then hurried to catch up with the others. <br>But Winfred didn't go back for Miss Carter; he fell in love with Malinda Gimlin Lewis, 16, whom he met at the first Founder's Day Celebration of Smithville, picking her out as the most beautiful among a group of<br>girls coming down the street. On September 21, 1882, they started for St. George, Utah to be married;  his journal describes the trip. <br>There were 34 persons in the party which included his father John Monroe, Malinda's sister Laura, who was to become the plural wife of Peter McBride, and Malinda's mother, Sarah Jane Huntsman Lew is, who, as Winfred ruefully reported, carefully supervised the association of Malinda and Winfred but paid little heed to her older daughter and already married Peter. Malinda experienced poor health for the entire trip, suffering from chills and fever, thought to be malaria. <br>The group went by way of Snowflake to attend their stake conference. From here John Monroe and some others returned home, while those in the wedding group traveled northward to Lee's Ferry on the Colorado river. The group separated, some went directly to St. George via Kanab, but Winfred's party went by way of Panguitch (the former home of the Lewis family) and Cedar City. Malinda's illness put a cloud over the festivities in St. George. However, finally the long desired day came, it being the 7th of November 1882.<br>Winfred and Malinda were married by temple President John D. T McAllister. He learned that his brother John, who had returned to St George from his mission, was keeping company with his former fiance Miss Eunice Carter. <br>Winfred regreted being unable to see his aged Aunt Dorinda Slade in Pine Valley, but they decided to return November 9, 1882, coming by way of Pipe Springs and Kanab. In Sunset, Arizona they were invited to stay for conference and help with the music. We also ate at the long table as they all lived in the Order under the direction of Lot Smith. They passed through the Apache Indian Reservation and arrived in Smithville (Pima) on December 8, 1882. When they returned home, there was a wedding reception at his father's flat-roofed adobe house, the first party of its kind in the valley of the Gila River. <br>Winfred was 24 when he built a small house for his new wife. There she bore her first two sons; three more boys and six girls were to follow. Winfred supported his family principally by farming . The railroad had not yet been built, so in 1881 Winfred began periodically hauling freight from Wilcox and Bowie and San Carlos and Globe, Arizona. This provided some needed cash. Although this route cut through the Indian Reservation Winfred never carried a gun thinking that an Indian would kill him as quickly for his gun as for any other reason. <br>The restive Apaches would occasionally break out of the reservation plundering and killing. At one time, his wife Malinda was alone with her four small children when she heard that the notorious Apache Kid had broken out again. Frightened, she walked at night through the brush two miles, avoiding the public road, to her mother's house.<br>Suddenly the five of them were surrounded by the sounds of the rattling of several rattlesnakes. Not being able to turn back. Malinda offered a prayer, picked up the smallest child, Ida, lined up her three barefoot boys behind her, and walked safely through.<br>Winfred and Malinda became the parents of 11 children, nine of whom lived to adulthood . Except for a few years in Central, they lived in Thatcher in a brick house with two large rooms and a porch on the front. When Malinda's mother had to come live with them. Winfred moved the porch to the back and made a kitchen out of it so that they would have more room. One day Grandma Lewis backed up to the fireplace and her clothes blazed up. Winfred put out the flames with his bare hands, but she died of the burns. <br>The first Thatcher L.D.S. Church services were held under a bowery at Bishop John Monro e Moody's home June 3 1883. At one time Winfred served concurrently as Sunday School superintendent, ward clerk, counselor to bishop Samuel Claridge and as a member of the ward choir. In 1892 he began six years as stake clerk under Christopher Layton. missing only one meeting during this assignment. While freigh ting he would often travel late into the night in order to not miss a meeting. He often found it necessar y to use his personal journal for ward and stake records. (The L.D.S. Church Archives. Salt Lake City. Utah now holds this large diary which contains also the diary ofJohn Monroe and Elizabeth Pool Moody.) <br>Winfred was completely dedicated to his Savior and His earthly kingdom. Someone said tha the reason he was so poor was the time spent discharging his duties and in being strictly honest in payin g his tithing and taxes. But he felt secure in the Lord's love and watchful care. <br>Winfred worked on public projects such as constructing the Central and Union irrigation canals with their brush and rock diversion dams in the river. On October 18, 1886 he began assisting in makin g adobes for and whitewashing a schoolhouse. His cash contribution of nearly $100 was next to the highest made toward the $700 project. <br>His journal states that once he returned home from work to find Malinda suffering from chills and a raging fever. Sister Lee annointed her and Sister East administered to her  as was the custom in that day.<br>In 1892 he obtained a patent to his homestead in Thatcher. In 1894 he sold a sixty foot right-of-way through his land to the railroad for $100. Instead of this going to discharge debts. it was used to assist his<br>cousin William A.Moody to go on a mission to Samoa. <br>Malinda and Winfred were constantly called upon as practical nurses in the community. On March 28 1903, when she was 37 and expecting her eleventh child. Winfred wrote that Malinda, wore her self out<br>waiting on the sick, a work she loved. suffering from pneumonia as well as fatigue. She gave birth to a baby girl July 9. 1903. A nurse at $2 a day, daily visits by a doctor. and Winfred's own care helped her to recover from the childbirth but not from her lung infection. She died on July 28. 1903. If ever a woman was prepared to die she was. She did not fear death but would have liked to have lived to see her family raised.<br>Winfred was again in financial difficulty. He had built a fine $3600 brick home on his Central farm which together with costs of sickness required him to mortgage both of his farms. Furthermore, insects and drought had produced crop failures, but his faith and commitment to the Lord's work remained undaunted. <br>Sometime prior to 1907, Bishop William A. Moody had prevailed upon Winfred to provide nursing care for Brigham Stewart and family who were near death. The promised help was not forthcoming, requiring<br>Winfred to be on constant duty for 51 days until the family could care for themselves. This placed a severe strain on Winfred who himself had not healed from a recent circumcision, consequences being exema on his hands and cancer in his surgical wound. <br>As drowning men are want to grasp at any straw, on February 5, 1913, I left for Los An geles, California to be cured of a cancer I had for seven years.The medical quack took from him $800 plus 56 4 hospital cost. Francis returned home in April. Later, he returned again to Los Angeles and on December 2. 1913, the doctor again started to kill my cancer. After six weeks Francis returned home and here his journal ends.<br>Excruciating pain continued: after being bedridden for awhile, Winfred departed this world August 18, 1919.<br>His life had been one of devotion and selfless service. He had followed the creed, If business interferes with your church duty, then get rid of your business, and, If someone has to get cheated in a business deal, I'd rather be the one cheated than the one doing the cheating."
"NI8894","On 1910 McClain CO., OK census she is listed as Ellie not Nellie<br>On the 1920 McClain CO., OK census she is listed as Millie not Nellie"
"NI9273","Died at age 15"
"NI9302","Biography for Philip H. Betz, Bureau County, Illinois<br>Philip H. Betz, Clarion, was born in this county August 18, 1853. He is a son of Jacob Betz, who was born in 1813 in Germany. He came to New York in 1842. Two years afterward he came to Bureau County, where he bought a claim of Joseph Screach, in Clarion Township, where our subject now owns 390 acres. The grandfather of our subject was Adam Betz (see preceding sketch). The mother of our subject was Elizabeth (Fauble) Betz, who died in 1883. She was the mother of nine children, viz,: Jacob, George, Adam, Philip H., Mary, Sarah, Susan, Ruth and Lydia. Philip H. Betz was married here to Emma Eby, a daughter of Moses and Sarah Eby, natives of Pennsylvania. Mrs. Emma Betz was born August 26, 1854, in LaSalle County, Ill. She is the mother of Frankie A., who was born October 16, 1881, and Anna M., born April 26, 1883. Religiously Mr. and Mrs. Betz are connected with the German Evangelical Church."
"NI9304","Biography for George M. Betz, Bureau County, Illinois<br>George M. Betz, Clarion, was born November 4, 1845, in Clarion Township, south of Perkins Grove. He is a son of Jacob and Elizabeth (Fauble) Betz (see preceding sketch). Mr. Betz was reared here and has been engaged in farming and stock raising, which latter he follows mainly. On his farm of 311 acres he raises shorthorn and Jersey cattle, Clydesdale horses (of which two are imported), Jersey Reds and Poland- China hogs, and also a drove of 300 head of pure bred Cots wool sheep, which are renowned for their wool as well as their mutton. Mr. Betz is a firm beliver that it pays to raise different kinds of stock on a farm, and his excellent success proves the soundness of his theory. He pays, however, the most attention to the raising of short-horns, having a heard of 100 head of thoroughbred cattle. Mr. Betz was joined in matrimony July 13, 1871, in Mendota, Ill., to Ann M. Elby, who was born July 13, 1851, in Mendota Township, LaSalle Co., Ill., of which place her parents, Moses and Sarah (Haek) Eby, were pioneers. To Mr. and Mrs. Betz six children were born: Sarah I., Lizzie E., William A., George M., Eddie E., and an infant son. Mr. Betz is a firm supporter of the Republican party, and of every enterprise which will be a benefit to the community wherein he resides."
"NI9402","From Buried Treasures (Elnora History Committee, 1972):<br>Biography of Thomas Edwards by Lil Edwards<br>Page 61-62<br>I was born June 19, 1888 at Bagboura, a little village under the Quantic Hills near Taunton in Somersetshire.  There were five of us, four boys and one girl.<br>I left England at the age of 14, in 1901.  I came out with a man by the name of Tom Rich.  We sailed from Liverpool on the Tunicion. There were about 1,000 aboard the shop.  They served real good food on the ship, like plum pudding, and brandy sauce and such like.<br>It took 10 days to cross the Atlantic, and we landed in Montreal in the afternoon.  We stayed in Montreal for two days to see the sights, then I went by train to Chicago, and from there to Algona, Iowa. I stayed with Tom Rich for one year.  I then worked for a Mr. Ashelford, who had nine children, eight girls and one boy.  The next year, they had typhoid fever.<br>After that, I went to North Dakota for two years.  I came to Calgary with a man by the name of Tom Murph, then on to Innisfail by train.  The first man I met was Archie Gay.  They ran the King Edward Hotel at the time.  We were in Innisfail for three days.  Then we dound Mr. Malcolm, who was working for the Government, and we filed on a homestead.<br>We hired a livery team and a democrat, and a man by the name of Art Getchel drove us to see the land.  There was snow on the ground, and it took us three days as the democrat did not go very well over snow.<br>We got stoves, oats for the horses, and our groceries from town.  We then had to cut logs to make a cabin.  We put up in a sod shack that we dound, and we nearly froze.  The meat did not thaw out much, even by the stove.<br>We put our horses in the tent, and we got a little hay from John Ash, a rancher.  Gordon Walker was working for him at that time.  We dound when our hay was gone that we had to go back to Innisfail, where I got a job with a man named Fred Wade, for the rest of the winter.  In the sprint I got Mr. Wade's wagon and box and once again set out for the homestead to break up some land and build a cabin.<br>While I was there I got real sick, and so one of the ranchers came along and looked in.  You got the measles, he said.  While I was sick on the homestead, one of the horses died, and left me with just one horse.  I took the wagon back to Mr. Wade's with only one horse.<br>My first crop got hailed out, and I got burned out the same year, 1916.  I then went out to work for a living, and I batched for about eight years.<br>I met Lily Robinson in 1922, and we were married in 1924 on the old farm east 10 miles from Elnora, by Parson Clay.<br>In 1927 we went to England with our two children Bessie 15 months, and Tommy six weeks old.  We were in England for five months, and then came back, in September, when we stayed in town for the winter.  We moved out to the farm two miles east of town, when Eileen was nine months old.  After that, Shirley and Lionel were born.<br>In 1956, we moved to town.  Lionel was still going to school, and the rest had gone from home.  Tommy was working, Bessie married Avery Fraser, Eileen works in Calgary, and married Albert Svederus.  Shirly works in Calgary.  We celebrated our 47th wedding anniversary in August, 1971.<br>Tommy now works in Lethbridge, Bessie lives in Huxley with seven children, Eileen lives in Elnora, and has six children.  Shirley, married Bob Miller and lives in Calgary.  They have no family.<br>After giving us his story, Tommy Edwards, who had been in poor health for some time, passed away in March 1972.<br>---<br>Note: Proper spelling of the ship is TUNISIAN which arrived in Canada twice in 1901.  1st was June 15th Barnardo children bound for Peterborough, and the 2nd was Sept 27th with 221 Barnardo children, and children from the Waifs and Strays association of London."
"XI10058","Ashes Spread over the Pacific Ocean at the Columbia River bar"
"XI10130","Cremated"
"NI10414","Carl Pritchard was very well known in the SW Washington area, as a semi pro baseball player and as Sheriff and undersheriff for Cowlitz County. (See Cowlitz Historical Quarterly, June 2002, Early Town Baseball Rivalries Grew Costly by don Jenkins.)"
"NI10533","death is recorded in the register of Christ Church of Middlesex County, Virginia Colony. All of the records of St. John's Parish, King William County, Virginia (the birth place of Thomas) were destroyed in a fire."
"NI10546","Samuel Paxton Sr. was the son of James Paxton of County Antrim, Northern Ireland. He sailed, with his family, to America in 1730, to the colony of Pennsylvania. he settled with other Scotch-Irish in what was then pert of Lancaster County, today it is Cumberland Township of Adams County, Pennsylvania. They were active members of the historic Presbyterian Church at Marsh Creek settlement. <br>Samuel's eldest son John Paxton, died there in Pennsylvania, but his wife Elizabeth (Alexander) Paxton went south to the Valley of Virginia about 1747 with her five sons where they settled near Lexington in present Rockbridge County. They became the progenitors of the North River Paxtons in Rockbridge County from whom General Sam Houston and General Elisha Franklin Paxton are descended.<br>The North River Paxtons were very prominent in the history of Rockbridge County. Together with the Houstons, the Lyles, the McClungs, the McDowells, and the Stuarts, the Paxtons were definitely among the Scotch-Irish gentry families of Virginia's Shenandoah Valley.<br>Samuel's son Thomas Paxton had gone to Rockbridge County about 1742 and there became the progenitor of the South River Paxtons."
"NI10556","James Paxton was born in central England, attached himself to the army of Cromwell, and was probably the Paxton who officiated at the execution of King Charles. After the Restoration, James and his family fled to Ireland, and settled at Ballymoney, in County Antrim, Ireland. Here he found aid and comfort from his Presbyterian allies.<br>James died in Ireland. The dates are a matter of conjecture. If born in 1640, his was eighty in 1720; and it was about this time that his children are found in Pennsylvania. Thomas, son of Samuel or possibly his brother, was taxed in Chester County, Pa. in 1722 , and the other Thomas, son of Nathaniel, came with his parents in 1725. After the death of James, his sons came to America.<br>Hugh, their uncle, had died in Maryland, in 1709, and John, his only son, preferring Quaker jurisdiction to Catholic domination, had probably, removed to Lancaster County, PA. As the brothers arrived, they took up land, successively, to the West. <br>From The Paxtons: We Are One! by W.M. Paxton, of Platte City, MO. Landmark Print. Platte City, MO 1903<br>James Paxton was married about 1689 in Ballymoney, Ireland (Antrim) and had three sons: William Paxton; Samuel Paxton, born 1670; and Thomas Paxton, born before 1700."
"NI10557","Thomas Paxton was born before 1700 in Ireland and married Sarah. He came to America with his three brothers in approximately 1725. <br>Thomas Paxton owned land 4 miles south of Natural Bridge in what is now Botetourt County, Virginia.<br>On April 1 and April 20, of 1747, Thomas and his wife Sarah appeared at the trial of Rebecca Buchanan who was being tried for murder. (Chalkley's I-27)<br>Thomas and Sarah had 8 children. Elizabeth, born about 1715; Thomas Jr. , born in 1720; Samuel, born in 1733; Joseph, two unnamed girls and 1 unnamed child. He also raised Elizabeth Eakin, his orphaned grand-daughter. <br>Thomas died in 1782."
"DI10611","Battle of Chancellorsville"
"DI10612","First battle of Manassas"
"NI10704","Died young."
"NI10707","Samuel Paxton Jr., married Susan Atkinson, his cousin, who was sister of his brother Williams wife, and they moved to Cooper County, Missouri, where his sisters Jane had settled"
"NI10709","Died shortly after her marriage."
"NI10711","He grew to manhood on South River and because of his character and high conception of integrity, he won a place of enviable esteem and confidence in the hearts of the people. His adherence to the Paxton military tradition led him into the service of the county militia in which he was elected Captain. The title became inseparable from his name throughout his life. His advice was sought by those in need of guidance and his services were highly esteemed by those needing a strong arm on which to learn."
"NI10715","They settled in Cooper Co, Missouri."
"NI10720","Died young."
"NI10724","He was a farmer and Mary was a housekeeper (according to 1870 Census) in the South River area of Virginia. <br>From letter to Charlie & Dora Paxton from Mary Grove: Gave the land to build Neriah Church and graveyard. They first settled in Pennsylvania and drifted up the valley of Virginia. They are Scotch-Irish"
"NI10764","Died young."
"NI10765","Died young."
"NI11029","Moved to Indiana."
"NI11030","Moved to Indiana."
"DI11035","Died in the Battle of Lake Erie"
"NI11689","First white child born in Indiana 1847. Left Indiana with his<br>family in 1864 by wagon and ox teams. Among his stock were two<br>dapple grey mares that provoked the cupidity of the Indians to<br>such an extent that they followed the party for 4 days trying<br>to buy them . When they werre refused they drove the horses off<br>during broad daylight. This was along the Platte river where<br>they had constant skirmishes with the Indians for nearly 300<br>miles. They stopped in Stockton Ut ah and were among the first<br>to build homes in the area. Leaving Stockton Utah they<br>ventured on to th Sacramento Valley in California later moving<br>on to Los A ngeles California. After living in Los Angeles for<br>six years Daniel and some m embers of his family moved to the<br>state of Washington where he lived until his death."
"NI11690","After Daniels death in 1884, Ruth moved to Oakley Idaho to live<br>with her son Francis Marion Cummins. She is buried in the<br>family plot in Oakley Idaho dying in 1901. She is buried next<br>to her son Francis Marion."
"NI11691","Was one of the original settlers of Oakley Idaho. Born in Indiana and crossed t he plaines with his father Daniel Cummins in wagon train of 1864 to California then on to Utah where he met his wife Sarah Deseret Severe. Settled in Oakley I daho with his wife in 1880. Became one of the most prosperious ranchers in the section of Idaho."
"NI11719","Daniel C. Cummins was murdered 10 Feb 1896 along with John C. Wilson while living in a sheep camp near Oakley Idaho. They were working for Daniels Uncle, Francis Marion Cummins. Diamondfield Jack (Jack Davis) was convicted of the murders as he was a hired gunman for the cattle association and had many run in with the local sheep ranchers. After a long trial he was sentenced to hang. After serving 6 years in prison Diamondfield Jack was pardoned as two other cattlemen Jeff Gray & James Bower, finally confessed to the murder. He was released from prison and moved to Los Angeles California where he lived the life of a celebrity because of the trial. Diamondfield Jack was run over by a taxi cab and died in 1919."
"NI11965","Unsure if Loman is the correct last name because the 1930 census record is difficult to read."
"NI12008","At the time of her death Jennie (and Evert) had five grandchildren, thirteen grandchildren and four great-great-grandchildren."
"NI12018","Melvin was tending the family's sheep when they were stalked by coyotes, he ran to this shepards range home (camp trailer) and grabbed his rifle from under the bed, it discharged, shooting him through the mouth and he died instantly."
"NI12019","Died as a teenager, playing with a gun."
"NI12087","Based on information in Edmund Barrett Gapper's will, his wife's last name may have been Taggart."
"NI12429","Military Service: Elisted in the Revelutionary Army October 10, 1776 for Two years, rank Private. He was in the 12th Regiment commanded by Col. James Wood He transfered to Neville's co, 4th, 8th and 12 Virginia Regiment He was discharged October 10 1778. <br>He was given 100 acres of land on June 20 1783 (Richmond land Office, Warrent Number 921, Book 1 pg 180)<br>According to records two Vincent Tapps served in the war, under the same command that is why on was called sr. and one jr."

"NI14363","Moved to Los Angeles, California."
"NI14434","He came to Gloucester County, Virginia, about 1645, but before 1647. He patented land in 165 5. He received large land grants, including 6500 acres he owned jointly with Major Lawrence Smith. By 1660 he had received 6300 acres by head rights alone, having transported 126 people to Virginia. Some contemporary deeds spell the name Tolliver, indicating that the current pronunciation of the name was the one in use even then.<br>According to Historical Sketches of the Campbell, Pilcher, and Kindred Families, Robert wa s born about 1635. On March 26, 1666, Lawrence Smith, 'Gentleman,' and Robert Taliaferro, 'Gentleman,' located and had deeded to them a land grant of 6,300 acres jointly in Rappahannock County, Virginia. Robert Taliaferro lived in Rappahannock County, Virginia, in 1666, and in 1682 he removed to Gloucester County. This county was divided in 1692 into what has since been Essex and Richmond Counties. This cannot be accurate as a more reliable source gives his date of death as between November, 1670 and November, 1671.<br>. He has reference number 4DMZ-13. From Ancestral File (TM), data as of 2 January 1996.Inform ation from an early researcher found in GS film #1316359, Item 6. Madison, WI. Library: F232 K5C5 by Clarke: The first of the name in the Colony settled in Gloucester Co. in 1636, where he received a large grant of land. He married a daughter of Rev. Charles Grymes, of Middlesex and had issue: John, Frances, Charles, Richard and Robert. His sons were of the Protestant faith. Perhaps Robert came to America in search of religious freedom?"
"NI14438","He was a subject of the Duke of Venice who settled in London and was made a denizen in 1562 . Tagliaferro means Iron Cutter in Italian, lots of Tagliaferros in Naples, name may have originated in South Italy.<br>He has reference number KMFF-L4. From Ancestral File (TM), data as of 2 January 1996. He was a subject of the Duke of Venice. He paid 20 schillings for Letters of Denization in England March 4, 1562. Lived in various parishes in London until his death. Buried September 22, 1601 at St. Olave's Hart Sreet, London. Will dated 18 Sept 1601, proved 3 May 1602. (P.C.C. 29 Montague). Married Joane Lane 1 Jan 1583/4 at St. Michael's, Cornhill, London. Se subsequently married Thomas Gray of Whitechapel County Middlesex, widower, 15 May 1602, at St. Olave's, Hart Street. He was buried 12 June 1617 at Whitechapel and his will was dated 12 May and proved 17 July 1617. Robert, the first of that name in Virginia was the grandson of Bartholomew Taliaferro. This particular family of Taliaferro was the only one found mentioned in the probate records of the Prerogative Court of Canterberry and of London and that after 1647 the name entirely disappeared from these probate records. Letters of administration of the estate of Francis Talafero were granted on the 20th of August 1647 to his daughter Anne, not to his son Robert as we might have expected had he been in England at the time. Robert was then aged twenty years and nine months.<br>Portions of the will of Bartholomew TALLEFER read as follows: To my four sons Scipio Fraunces Isack and Jeromme Two hundred pounds sterling when they shal l be of the age of Twenty one years. To Elizabeth my daughter to be given at her marriage one hundred pounds sterling, meaning that she shall not marry until she be of the age of sixteen years or according to the will of her mother. To Jone my wife one hundred pounds sterling, if she marries again. If she does not, she is to have the profits of all my estate, and then one hundred pounds when my sons are of the age of twenty one years. I ordain my overseers of the things contained in this my Testament and Last will John Francisco Soprani Fraunces Rizzo and Phillippe Bernardi. I do give five pounds sterling to our parish of St. Ollaves on conditions that they shall discharge my family of the taxation of the poor of the said parish so long as my wife, sons and daughter shall jointly dwell in the same. And not discharging them of the said taxation they shall pay them nothing. Unto Margery my servant five shillings sterling. I declare that I have two obligations of Cornelius De Neme, one of one hundred pounds which is paid, but the other of one hundred and twenty five pounds is in force and is due to me. Made in the City of London the eighteenth day of September 1601 Subscribed in the presence of Jeromme Lopez Pompilio Gaetani Henry Valesi William Parkyns. May 3, 1602. Letters of Administration granted to Joan Taliaferro the relict of the said deceased."
"NI14522","He was a lieutenant of rangers in 1692. He was a justice of Essex County in 1695 and later sheriff. He served in the House of Burgesses in 1699."
"NI14536","He was a lieutenant colonel in the Spotsylvania County militia; sheriff of Spotsylvania Count y, 1730; justice of Spotsylvania County, 1720; and trustee of Frederisckberg. He lived in Spotsylvania County at Snow Creek.<br>According to The Family Register of Nicholas Taliaferro, Genealogies of Virginia Families,V ol. IV, Snow Creek flows into the Rappahannock River a short distance below Fredericksburg. When John Taliaferro. . .settled there, that section belonged to Essex County. . .The act creating Spotsylvania County (1720) specified Snow Creek as its Southern boundary. This threw John Taliaferro into the new county. . .According to the Westover Papers, John Taliaferro settled at Snow Creek in 1707."
"NI14545","William was educated in England. He inherited his father's plantation in New Kent County. O<br>n November 12, 1762, he was chosen a vestryman for Blisland Parish and served actively until he moved to Spotsylvania Cunty. He was also a county justice of the peace and colonel of militia in New Kent County. He must have been named commander of the county militia in 1764 or 1765 for his title, as recorded in the vestry book of the parish, changed from Mr. to Col. In 1766, William was trustee along with Alexander Bolling and William Allen, for the sale of Broadway, in Prince George County, Virginia. This was the property of Dr. William Stark, who married William's sister, Mary Bassett Daingerfield. There are no extant records to confirm his military service. He moved to Spotsylvania County in about 1770, when his wife, Sarah Taliaferro, inherited a 1300-acre plantation, possibly from her grandmother, Mary Catlett Taliaferro. The Blisland Parish vestry chose a replacement for him on October 23, 1770, . . .in the stead of Col. William Daingerfield, who is removed out of the parish.<br>By 1774, he and his family were living at Belvidera, on the Rappahannock River, seven mile s below Fredericksburg. Belvidera was built on a high bluff overlooking the Rappahannock. It was a rectangular, brick, two-story house of the simple design characteristic of rural dwellings in tidewater Virginia. The plantation was a working farm that was not comparable to the great mansions of the largest planters. The diary of John Harrower, who was employed by Col. Daingerfield as a tutor for his children from the summer of 1774 until Harrower's death in April, 1777, contains many details of Col. Daingerfield's way of life. He had a large plantation, many slaves, owned a chariot, and shipped 3600 bushels of wheat annually to England. But he was apparently plagued by financial problems. In February, 1782, he was forced to borrow 1000 pounds and secure the debt with his wife's 1300 acres on Snow Creek. Althugh he was able to repay the debt within a month, on August 2, 1782, he sold his New Kent County lands. Greatly distressed and agitated, he made his will on January 4, 1783. According to E. M. Riley, editor of The Journal of John Harrower (1963, Holt, Rinehart and Winston), Early the next day, a Sunday, he and Colonel Bland rode to General Spotswood's home for breakfast. Here they parted and Daingerfield set out alone 'down the Country.' Two weeks later a Fredericksburg lawyer, James Mercer, recorded the sudden end of the story with these words: '. . .can you believe it? Colo. Daingerfield cut his Throat at New Castle last week & is now no more! I really shall be afraid of a. . .Knife for a month to come'.<br>The appraisal of Col. Daingerfield's property listed 68 slaves valued at 3085 pounds; livesto ck worth about 468 pounds; and personal property appraised at about 3854 pounds. Mr. Riley comments, This was a not inconsiderable estate. The loss of the tobacco for which he sold his New Kent land was not sufficient to bankrupt him. Apparently he had become mentally unbalanced by worry from unknown causes."
"NI14546","He inherited the house and much of the land at Belvidera. According to E. M. Riley, He apparently led a rather dissolute life. When he died in 1842, Belvidera was sold by his creditors."
"NI14548","He was educated in medicine at the Medical College, Edinburgh, Scotland. He settled in Alexa<br>ndria, Virginia about 1800, but moved to Prince George's County, Maryland, about 1806. He served as a colonel of militia in the War of 1812, and died at Wood Cot, his estate in Prince George's County, Maryland."
"NI14561","William Henry Daingerfield moved to San Antonio, Texas, in October, 1837. He was elected may<br>or of San Antonio in 1838. He became chief justice of Bexar County the same year and in 1839 was appointed commissary of purchases of the Army of the Republic of Texas. He was senator from Bexar County in the Fifth and Sixth Congresses of Texas, 1840-1842, but resigned on February 5, 1842, to become Secretary of the Treasury. In February, 1844, he became Texas charge d'affaires to the Netherlands, where he remained until annexation. In 1860 he returned to Washington, D. C., and opened a law office nearby. He died in September, 1878, at his residence, Wood Cot, in Prince Georges County, Maryland.<br>Professional card, apparently published in the Marlborough Gazette: Wm. Henry Daingerfield , Att'y, may be found at his residence Wood Cot, Prince George's Co., or at the office of Messrs. Browning and Ewing, 15 N. A St., Capitol Hill, Washington. When in Marlborough, at the office of Samuel Hance. 1869."
"NF597","After living in Indiana they moved To Clay Co, Illinois."
"NF843","Married by Judge Mosier"
"NF883","Had 5 children"
"NF1009","Excerpt from Lincoln County, KY marriage records. Bond date.<br>Hiatt, Lucy married Ramsey, Seth on 06 Feb 1790 in Lincoln<br>County, Kentucky<br>Know all Men by these presents that we Seth Ramsey and William<br>Lampton are held & firmly bound unto His Excellency the<br>Governor of Virginia in the Sum of Fifty pounds Current money,<br>to the payment whereof to be made to the said Governor and his<br>Successors we bind our Selves our Heirs & firmly by these<br>presents. Sealed with our Seals and dated this 6th day of<br>February 1789. The Condition of the above obligation is such<br>that whereas there is a Marriage shortly intended to be<br>Solemnized between the above<br>bound Seth Ramsey and Lucy Hiatt for which a License has<br>issued. Now if there be no Lawful cause to obstruct the said<br>Marriage then this obligation to be void or else remain in full<br>force.<br>Sealed & delivered Seth<br>Ramsey<br>(Seal)<br>in presence of<br>his<br>John Reed William<br>X<br>Lampton (Seal)<br>mark<br>Mr Green Please to issue licence for a marriage intended<br>between Seth Ramsey and my Daughter Lucy Hiatt, & in so doing<br>this shall be your Warrant Given under my hand this 6 Day of<br>febeary 1789<br>Test Ritchea Boulware William<br>hiatt<br>(Seal)<br>Mordecai Boulware<br>[This parental consent indicates that Lucy Hiatt was not 18 by<br>06 February 1789 and therefore born after that date in 1771.<br>William Hiatt and Tabitha Noel were married by, but probably<br>not much before, 19 January 1771 when her<br>father Joseph Noel wrote his will and some of her sisters were<br>still unmarried. Boulware Vawter was one of the witnesses to<br>Joseph Noel's will. Ritchie Boulware, who came to Kentucky<br>from Essex County, was married to<br>Esther Ramsey. Marriage bond either 6 Feb 1789 or 1790]"

"NF3785","About 1825, Thomas and his wife of nine years, the former Dicie Cartwright, joined a wagon-train on the westward track and settled on the rich river-lands of Kanawha County, now in West Virginia."
